Draco Malfoy and the Mortifying Ordeal of Being in Love

by isthisselfcare

Summary

Hermione straddles the Muggle and Magical worlds as a medical researcher and Healer about to make a big discovery. Draco is an Auror assigned to protect her from forces unknown â€“ to both of their displeasure.

Features hyper-competent, fiery Hermione and lazy, yet dangerous, Draco. Slow burn.

Notes

This is a story that I wanted to read but that didnâ€™t quite seem to exist yet, and so I had to be the change I wished to see in the world.

Canon has been unapologetically picked over for the good bits â€“ call it canon divergent. Tonally, we are looking at low-stakes humour with occasional serious moments. My writing is inspired by (and looks breathtakingly jejune next to) the works of Jerome K. Jerome, P. G. Wodehouse, Saki, Dickens, Thackeray, and, of course, the inimitable Jane Austen.

There will be no filler content of the HP ensemble cast â€“ my focus is putting H and D in strange situations and seeing who murders who first.

Beta read by the wonderful femme-Ã©crivain.

An Unsporting Attack


art by catherine7mk, poster by nikitajobson

~

As a man of means, Draco Malfoy could have chosen to live a life of leisure, political meddling, and casual blackmail, like his father before him. However, his acquittal by the Wizengamot was accompanied by strong recommendations that young Mr. Malfoy strive for such laudable pursuits as the Common Good, Altruism, and Redemption in the Public Eye.

And so, after a few years of sowing his wild oats (and a great many curses) on the Continent, Draco had returned to London, where he made short work of the Auror training programme â€“ three years down to one and a half, if you please â€“ and joined that noble Office. Draco had been strategic in his choice of career, of course: being an Auror offered just enough heroics for positive coverage in the news and just enough Ministry-sanctioned murders to keep him interested in the job.

Draco was an excellent Auror â€“ something about very nearly becoming a Dark wizard himself gave him rather useful insights into the minds of naughty wizards and witches. The problem with competence, however, was that it was rewarded with increasingly complex cases by the Head of the Auror Office, a certain Madam Nymphadora Tonks.

And so, our opening scene: a Monday morning, sometime in January. Amidst the greying cubicles of the Auror Office, Tonks was doling out the monthâ€™s Class A assignments to her top Aurors like a vindictive Father Christmas.

â€œMontjoy â€“ youâ€™re off to Hethpool. Three Muggle children found dead with their livers removed. That hag coven from Stow may have regrouped.â€ A folder containing the case material was slapped onto Montjoyâ€™s desk.

â€œBuckley â€“ suspected necromancy and other foul play, Isle of Man.â€ Buckley accepted the proffered casefile with a grimace. â€œYouâ€™re to take Humphreys with you. Mind you be a good mentor and donâ€™t traumatise her too much.â€

Tonks rounded the corner to the next cubicles. â€œPotter, Weasley â€“ youâ€™re to continue with the vampires in the Dales, but if you donâ€™t make further headway, I will get personally involved. Half of Yorkshire will be sucked dry at this rate. Goggin â€“ some idiot is experimenting with Transmogrifian Torture on Muggle prostitutes in Glenluce. I wonâ€™t notice if you bring him in with a few missing appendages.â€

Tonks now came to a halt in front of Dracoâ€™s desk. â€œMalfoy. Since you did so well with the Lanark Lunatic last week, Iâ€™ll let you pick your poison.â€

Draco eyed Tonks guardedly â€“ poison was unlikely to be an exaggeration. â€œWhat are my options?â€

Tonks dropped two files onto Dracoâ€™s desk. â€œOption one, a wizard accused of inappropriate acts with trolls â€“ a real delight for the senses, that one. Or, option two â€“ a request from the Minister for Auror protection of a high-profile target.â€

â€œInappropriate acts?" repeated Draco, pulling the folders towards himself.Â 

â€œI donâ€™t know about your tolerance level, but Iâ€™ve quite lost my appetite.â€ Tonks jutted her chin towards the rightmost folder. â€œThere are photographs for your edification.â€

Draco made the mistake of opening the troll folder. He closed it again with a strangled sound of disgust. â€œIâ€™ll take the protection assignment.â€

â€œRight-o,â€ said Tonks, swiping the troll folder and its hideous contents from Dracoâ€™s desk. â€œThe troll-buggerer will go to Fernsby. Fernsby! Come here.â€

Fernsby emerged from a distant cubicle. Tonks slapped the folder into his chest. â€œYou are off to Morpeth. I hear the North Sea is lovely this time of year.â€

If Fernsby had reservations about the loveliness of a January sojourn by the North Sea, he kept them to himself. Tonks was rarely worth arguing with.

â€œProgress reports on my desk by Monday morning,â€ called Tonks to the office at large. A grumble of assent from the Aurors followed the request.

Tonks gave Draco a sharp look. â€œLooking forward to yours, Malfoy. Iâ€™ve a degree of curiosity about that one â€“ the target is working on some top secret project. They wouldnâ€™t even tell me what it's about.â€

Tonks made her way back to her office, managing to tread on an unsuspecting colleagueâ€™s foot only once.

Draco, now rather curious, pulled the folder towards himself. The protection request came straight from the Ministerâ€™s Office and Shacklebolt had requested a security audit, defensive warding, every confidentiality-enhancing measure known to wizardkind, escorting, if you please, and protective surveillance â€“ in sum, the bloody works.

Draco was preemptively irritated â€“ this sounded rather a lot like effort.

And who, pray, merited this extravagant treatment?

He flipped over a few more pages of Ministerial demands to find, finally, the Principal.

And it was Hermione. Bloody. Granger.

Her photograph was pinned to the top of a brief biographical note â€“ as though anyone alive today didnâ€™t know her and her hair. She looked seriously at Draco, blinked at him once, then left the frame.

Draco seized the folder and headed for Tonksâ€™ office. She was rarely worth arguing with, but this casefile merited an especial attempt.

â€œTonks â€“ I canâ€™t take this one. Youâ€™ll have to give it to someone else.â€

Tonks looked up from the parchment sheâ€™d been attacking with a quill. Her hair turned a quizzical mauve. â€œWhyever not?â€

â€œItâ€™s Granger. Thatâ€™s the Principal. Hadnâ€™t you seen?â€

â€œAnd?â€

â€œWe donâ€™t exactly get along,â€ said Draco in a vast understatement.

â€œAre you telling me that some school-time unpleasantness from fifteen years ago will interfere with your ability to carry out this assignment?â€ asked Tonks.

In the Foe Glass behind her, shadowy silhouettes clustered about, as though keen to eavesdrop on the drama.

â€œWe have a rather unhappy history,â€ said Draco.

â€œWorse than you and Potter?â€

This, Draco considered for a moment. Finally, he answered, â€œIn some ways.â€

â€œFine,â€ sniffed Tonks. â€œSwap with Fernsby. Iâ€™m sure heâ€™ll only be too happy to change out a cushy protection jobbie for the troll aficionado.â€

â€œ...Isnâ€™t there anything else I could take?â€

Tonks gave him a quelling look, emphasised by her eyes turning a dangerous, hawkish kind of yellow. â€œIâ€™ve just assigned the monthâ€™s missions, Malfoy, and I wonâ€™t have your complex about Granger domino its way through the entirety of it.â€

â€œI donâ€™t have a complex about Granger.â€

â€œGood. Then youâ€™ll do fine. Off you go.â€

Tonks waved her hand and her office door closed slowly, squeezing Draco out.

Draco strode back to his desk, half intending to ask Fernsby for the swap â€“ however, the gurgle of horror emanating from Fernsbyâ€™s cubicle was sufficient to change his mind.

Fine. Heâ€™d do the Granger thing. It was, at any rate, not troll pornography.

~

Draco sent Granger a coldly professional note stating that he would be pleased to meet with her at her earliest convenience to discuss the Ministerâ€™s protection request.

Granger sent back an equally cold note indicating that the Ministerâ€™s request was an overblown reaction on the Ministerâ€™s part and that she would be dealing with it shortly, and to please disregard it.

Draco did not respond, but enjoyed an afternoon off instead of informing Tonks of this fortunate development immediately.

Then Granger ruined everything by writing again, indicating that, to her disappointment, the Minister had not changed his mind, and was forging ahead with this (disproportionate and illogical, in her opinion) plan of action. Would Draco be available to meet at nine oâ€™clock this Thursday? The Granger Laboratory. Trinity College, Cambridge.

As he tossed the missive into the fire, Draco thought, Cambridge, of course. How could we expect anything less from Hermione Granger?

~

That Thursday, Draco arrived at Trinity College at the beastly hour of nine o'clock. The porter at the gate didnâ€™t glance twice at his robes â€“ many of the Muggles wandering about were wearing long black gowns â€“ but he did give Draco a sharp look when he said he was there to see Granger.

â€œDoctor Granger,â€ said the porter. â€œHave you got an appointment, sir?â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œName?â€

â€œMalfoy,â€ said Draco.

The porter consulted a chart. He found whatever he was looking for, apparently, because Draco was waved in towards the verdant quad at Trinity College. (â€œItâ€™s not a quad, we call them courts at Cambridge,â€ said the porter to some tourists, but Draco paid him no mind â€“ he knew a quad when he saw one.)

Grangerâ€™s note had included a few directions on how to enter the wizarding part of the College, which brought Draco to a magically concealed door at the south end of the quad. A Muggle plaque indicated that Kingâ€™s Hall had once stood here, but that it had been destroyed in the sixteenth century. Draco tapped the bronze plaque with his wand, as instructed by Granger, and the ostensibly destroyed Kingâ€™s Hall appeared before him. Draco decided that Granger earned a two out of ten in his initial security assessment â€“ at least rogue Muggles wouldnâ€™t immediately be able to find her. And, with that generous thought, he strode into Magical Cambridge.

At nine oâ€™clock on a weekday, Kingâ€™s Hall was a roiling bustle of scholarly witches and wizards, off to advance magical knowledge. Draco had spent years at the UniversitÃ© de Paris to earn his Bachelor's in Alchemy and his Mastery in Martial Magic (Duelling), but heâ€™d never set foot in an institution of higher learning in the UK. Kingâ€™s Hall retained its sixteenth century ambience â€“ dark, an excess of over-carved wood, and candlelight â€“ and vacillated somewhere between pure Gothic and early Renaissance in dÃ©cor.

As he surveyed the crowd before him (varyingly studious or eccentric-looking), Draco wondered how much of wizarding Britainâ€™s brain power was located within these hallowed halls. At any rate, there was at least one big brain on the premises. Quite lost amongst five staircases on the first floor, he decided to enquire for directions towards that brain.

â€œYou there,â€ said Draco, jutting his chin towards a spotty youth. The boy looked about twenty-two, serious, and clutched a text on Advanced Theoretical Arithmancy to his chest.

â€œYes?â€ asked the youth.

â€œIâ€™m looking for Granger,â€ said Draco.

The boy frowned at him. â€œProfessor Granger. Her offices are on the third floor, with the other Fellows.â€

â€œCheers,â€ said Draco, wondering how many more times he was going to be corrected regarding precious Grangerâ€™s title today.

He climbed the stairs and passed corridors where he spotted a variety of interesting things: classrooms, lounges, reading rooms, offices, an apothecary, a cafÃ©, and what appeared to be a small zoo. Finally, he came to a door which simply said, â€œGRANGER. Ring for attention.â€

See? There. No overzealous titles.

Draco rang for attention.

Then he peered into the narrow window that flanked the door and almost turned around to leave again, because the laboratory beyond seemed decidedly MuggleÂ and he mustâ€™ve taken a wrong turn somewhere, only it said â€œGRANGER,â€ right there.

His ring was answered by a Being in a bright white coat and strange translucent face-coverings.

â€œCan I help you?â€ asked the Being.

â€œIâ€™m looking for Granger,â€ answered Draco.

â€œHealer Granger doesnâ€™t take walk-ins,â€ said the Being, with a rather stiffened back. â€œIs she expecting you?â€

â€œShe is,â€ said Draco, adding this new title to the increasingly ridiculous running list.

â€œAll right,â€ said the Being, with what was probably a suspicious look, but Draco couldnâ€™t tell behind the goggle-things. â€œHer office is down to the right.â€

The Being moved out of the way. From the voice, Draco, was now relatively certain it was a human female, but the accoutrements made it difficult to say. In any case, Draco was in. His initial assessment of Grangerâ€™s security measures plummeted to a strong one out of ten.

It pleased him to give Granger a well-deserved horrid mark; it didnâ€™t please him to think of the work that would be involved bringing this place up to snuff.

He knocked on the office door.

â€œCome in,â€ said Grangerâ€™s voice. A blast from the past â€“ crisp, prissy, impatient.

Draco entered the office. Granger was sitting behind a tidy, if over-stacked, desk.

They stared at one another in a decidedly Awkward Moment, something that Draco, now a fully qualified and rather dangerous Auror, was not used to anymore â€“ and perhaps, judging by the unhappy set of her mouth, neither was Granger.

Time heals all wounds, but between himself and Granger, there were a great many to heal, and right now, fifteen years felt like a rather short time since they'd been children fighting each other on opposite sides of a war. Draco couldnâ€™t recall when he had last spoken to her directly, and he certainly knew heâ€™d never been alone in a room with her.

Granger rose to greet him with the following display of eloquence: â€œMalfoy.â€

â€œGranger,â€ said Draco, with equal eloquence.

She gestured to a chair across the desk. As he stepped towards it, Draco found himself being assessed by her. Her gaze flitted from his hair to his face, to the Auror insignia on his chest, and down his black robes to his boots.

Seeing that they were dispensing with the niceties, Draco shamelessly assessed her in return: the hair (a curling pile coiled high at her crown), the face (thinner, more severe than he remembered), the same strange white cloak as the Being, the black jeans (so Muggle), the casual trainers.

Draco opened his mouth to make a few vague opening remarks â€“ some chatter about Cambridge, or Potter and Weasley, or other such fluff â€“ but Granger jumped straight to the point.

The lack of finesse was quite typey for Granger. Some things didnâ€™t change.

â€œAll right,â€ said Granger at length. â€œA fortnight ago, I updated Shacklebolt on the progress of a certain research project. A research project which is not under the Ministryâ€™s purview, nor funded by it, by the by. I was sharing what I thought was a bit of good news with a long-time friend and mentor â€“ who happens to be the Minister of Magic. Apparently, the news was too good. Shacklebolt fears repercussions, as the project will have implications for a certain segment of the population.â€

â€œWhat implications?â€ asked Draco. â€œWhich segment?â€

â€œIâ€™d rather not say, as my hope is that you wonâ€™t be involved any further than this meeting. Shacklebolt is overreacting. I shall speak with him again this week and convince him that putting me under Auror surveillance is utterly unnecessary.â€

â€œAuror protection,â€ corrected Draco. Aurors of his calibre werenâ€™t assigned to two-bit surveillance jobs, thank you.

â€œCall it what you will,â€ said Granger.

â€œShacklebolt has his flaws, but a propensity for overreaction isnâ€™t one of them,â€ said Draco. (There wasnâ€™t much love lost between himself and the Minister, but there was a certain respect.)

â€œNo, it isnâ€™t one of his propensities. Which is why I was rather surprised â€“ dismayed, really â€“ by his decision to involve your office.â€

â€œIs it possible that he isnâ€™t overreacting?â€

The look Granger levelled at him was decidedly unfriendly. â€œNo.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t think that this â€“ breakthrough, or discovery â€“ of yours is putting you at any new risk whatsoever?â€

â€œNot at the moment. First, no one knows about this development, other than Shacklebolt himself and â€“ to varying degrees â€“ my staff, all of whom I trust implicitly. And, secondly, though Iâ€™ve made a breakthrough, I havenâ€™t quite solved the issue yet. That will be the work of at least another year. I wonâ€™t be on the front page of The Prophet asking to be murdered tomorrow.â€

Draco's eyebrow twitched upwards. â€œShacklebolt thinks youâ€™re going to be murdered?â€

â€œHe thinks â€“ probably rightly â€“ that some people wonâ€™t be pleased about my breakthrough.â€

Draco decided that he needed to speak to Shacklebolt. Perhaps heâ€™d be less cagey than Granger and disclose something useful to the Auror assigned to her. He found himself truly curious, now, about the nature of this Good Discovery.

His next question was carefully phrased. He didnâ€™t want to cast aspersions on Grangerâ€™s heritage (gods forbid; he was already on thin ice everywhere on that front), but there were things she mightnâ€™t know, as a Muggle-born. â€œMight Shacklebolt be aware of certain wizarding predilections or biases that you arenâ€™t, that would be a cause for concern?â€

Granger took a breath, as one might if one was summoning oneâ€™s remaining patience. â€œIf I told you Iâ€™d solved world famine, or something equally wonderful, would you pause to worry about the actions of a few naysayers?â€

â€œOne naysayer would be enough to dispatch a do-gooding researcher, especially one who keeps her laboratory secured with a third-rate locking charm and some chicken wire.â€

One of Grangerâ€™s knees began to bounce. It brought to mind a cat twitching its tail in annoyance.

â€œSo have you?â€ asked Draco.

â€œHave I what?â€

â€œSolved world famine.â€

â€œNothing so grand. That was an example.â€

â€œWhere do you keep your findings?â€ asked Draco.

Now it was Grangerâ€™s turn to raise an eyebrow, which was the entirety of her response.

Draco gestured to the office around him and the laboratory on the other side of the door. â€œIâ€™ve identified a dozen vulnerabilities already â€“ and thatâ€™s only what I saw in the five minutes it took to walk up here. If I wanted to work it out, I rather think I could.â€

â€œDo you?â€

â€œYes.â€

Seeing Granger smirk wasâ€¦ something. However, it rapidly disappeared. â€œIf weâ€™re talking of physical security, I havenâ€™t exactly had a reason to increase it beyond the usual measures until recently. I can assure you that Iâ€™m capable of warding my laboratory beyond a locking charm â€“ and keeping my data safe.â€

â€œPerfect,â€ said Draco. â€œProceed with that. Iâ€™ll be back in a few days to do a penetration test. If you satisfy that â€“ and implement any additional measures I recommend â€“ we may be able to convince Shacklebolt that you and your research are safe, and weâ€™ll be able to put this behind us.â€

This challenge was dolled out with a â€“ quite laudable, Draco thought â€“ minimum of arrogance on his part.

Grangerâ€™s eyes grew hard: the challenge was recognised and accepted. â€œFine. And when will this penetration test take place?â€

â€œIâ€™m not giving you a warning,â€ said Draco, rising. â€œDo you think a real-world threat would?â€

â€œBrilliant,â€ said Granger, rising too. Sarcasm roughened the edge of her words. â€œI do love surprises.â€

They did not shake hands and she did not see him out.

~

Draco scheduled a visit with the Minister of Magic later that week. He sauntered past the Ministerâ€™s sour-faced assistant on the designated day, wondering who had pissed in her Pixie Puffs.

Shacklebolt was as reticent with the details as Granger had been, but impressed upon Draco the importance of keeping Granger safe to complete her project, for the benefit of all wizardkind. It was all very grand and extremely vague.

The only positive was Shackleboltâ€™s evident pleasure that it was Draco who had ended up with the assignment. â€œI know you wonâ€™t hesitate to get nasty, Malfoy, if any malicious individuals were to make a move against her.â€

Draco accepted the backhanded compliment with a mock bow. â€œYouâ€™re warming the cockles of my heart, Minister.â€

Shacklebolt returned the bow with an inclination of his head. Then he grew sombre. â€œShe could change the lives of hundreds â€“ thousands â€“ for the better.â€

â€œAnd yet, neither she nor you will tell me what the project entails. Did she make you take a bloody Vow of Secrecy before she disclosed anything?â€

Shacklebolt raised his hands, not responding one way or another, and thus gave Draco his answer.

â€œShe would have the foresight,â€ said Draco, throwing a fistful of Floo powder into Shackleboltâ€™s fireplace. â€œCambridge.â€

This was it. Heâ€™d given her long enough to prepare.

It was late on Monday evening. King's Hall was quiet. Draco supposed that Granger was off having dinner or browbeating innocent undergraduates. He stood at the door of her laboratory, tapping his wand to his chin thoughtfully. However, before he had cast any kind of revelation charm or begun any sort of snooping, Granger rounded the corner.

â€œMalfoy,â€ she said, looking a little dishevelled and out of breath. Draco filed her timely arrival away for future analysis. She was too clever for it to be coincidence â€“ and yet, he hadnâ€™t cast a single spell that wouldâ€™ve made his presence known.

Granger had forsaken her Muggle clothing for green Healer robes. She looked both irritable and impatient, and quickly confirmed both of those conditions by asking: â€œTime for your vaunted test, is it? How long will it take?â€

Draco did not appreciate her tone, which suggested that this might be an affair of several hours. â€œThat depends on your warding â€“ Iâ€™m thinking a quarter of an hour at the upper end.â€

Grangerâ€™s eyebrow rose at the cockiness of this rejoinder. â€œGood. Just did a shift at A&E and Iâ€™m positively knackered.â€

She waved her wand and, with a rather impressive display of Transfiguration (not that Draco gave any sign that he was impressed), she transformed one of her hairpins into a glossy wooden chair, upon which she perched herself to observe him.

Draco didn't mind an audience, especially when he was going to systematically dismantle the audienceâ€™s attempts to keep him out, and teach her some humility.

Draco turned his attention back to the door. â€œA&E? I thought you were a researcher.â€

â€œThe MNHS is chronically understaffed. I take shifts at St. Mungoâ€™s to help out. Keeps my Healing skills sharp.â€

â€œGood of you.â€

â€œMm.â€

After a few revelation spells, Draco had to hand it to Granger â€“ sheâ€™d done her homework. Not a surprise, really. The protective enchantments that now warded the door to her laboratory were many, quite complex, and well-cast.

Draco got to work, but not without taking the piss just a little. â€œCaterwauling Charm? Insulting.â€

â€œIâ€™ve learned to work from the lowest common denominator up,â€ was the dry response.

The basic intruder charms that followed were dismissed with a few wand waves. The Salvio Hexia was a good warmup. Then Draco got into the good stuff: Foribus Ignis, Custos Portae, a hair-trigger Confundus aimed directly at his head, revealed only when heâ€™d peeled away the other two wards, a sneaky Blinding Hex that just seemed mean, a Balding Jinx that was decidedly unsportsmanlike, and a concealed Confringo on the door handle itself for anyone stupid enough to touch it.

Draco disarmed the latter â€“ a little touch and go, admittedly, and he did break a sweat â€“ telling himself that at least if his face was blown off, there was a Healer nearby who would be able to assist.

The door unlocked. It had taken all of four minutes. And yet, Granger looked unimpressed.

Draco swung open the door to reveal â€“ a stone wall.

â€œFunny,â€ said Draco.

His face showed none of his disquiet, but heâ€™d been wasting his time on an absolutely impeccable decoy. He waved his wand a metre further down the wall and the real door to the laboratory appeared.

Granger shrugged. â€œI needed my staff able to get in. They arenâ€™t experts at disarming wards, but they can handle a Finite Incantatem.â€

Draco entered the laboratory to continue his assessment, his neck rather stiff. His audience waved her chair back into a hairpin and followed.

"Normally I would insist upon us donning the proper PPE, per Trinity's wet laboratory protocols," said Granger. "But we've tidied for the day. I don't think you can hurt yourself on anything."

Once again, Draco didn't care for her tone, which, this time, suggested that he might otherwise off himself by accident.

He ignored the sterile white and steel surfaces that made up most of the space and moved to the shelves and cupboards at one end of the laboratory, which looked like a likely place for an active laboratory to store data. â€œI realise the purpose of this test is to see how far youâ€™d get and what you can discover about my research â€“ but do put things back in an orderly fashion,â€ came Grangerâ€™s voice, irritation lacing her words.

Draco, his back to her, permitted himself a healthy roll of his eyes â€“ one text was half an inch out of place. He pushed it back in. He waved his wand at the entirety of the collection to uncover Transfigurations or concealment spells, but there were none. Then he systematically did the same with the rest of the laboratory, seeking any hidey holes or caches or â€“ as he grew annoyed â€“ any magical trace whatsoever. There was nothing magical except the contents of the various vials and test tubes clustered in tidy groups along the laboratoryâ€™s workbenches.

â€œIf I stole these and had them analysed, what would I discover?â€ asked Draco.

The glow of his spell illuminated the vials of interest. Granger walked towards them and pointed. â€œGamma delta T cells. Antigens: MART-1, Tyrosinase, GP100, Survivin. All of magical provenance, which is why your spell is revealing them, but not otherwise noteworthy.â€

â€œI see,â€ said Draco, who did not see at all.

Draco felt the false modesty in the words; by very few, she meant none at all â€“ Iâ€™m surrounded by idiots and Iâ€™m the only one who can make sense of any of these horrifically named extracts.

â€œAnd those?â€ asked Draco, pointing to larger, rather more familiar looking vials along the back row.

â€œA find of critical importance, in the laboratory of a Healer,â€ said Draco, his annoyance lapsing into sarcasm.

Draco was doing his own stifling, but in his case, it was exasperation. She had wasted his time on a wild goose chase with those door wards, knowing that there was nothing of real use in the laboratory itself, unless one was in possession of about twelve doctorates to put it all together.

Now Draco turned to a corner of the laboratory that heâ€™d ignored as a matter of course. It was the most Muggleish area of the entire place â€“ a corner desk cluttered with glowing boxes of light. Heâ€™d have to watch that â€“ clearly, a weakness.

He walked towards the desk. And, for the first time since Draco had entered the laboratory, Granger actually perked up and looked interested in the proceedings. Now he was getting somewhere.

â€œ...Iâ€™d need to bring in a Muggle-born,â€ said Draco at length.

â€œThe cloud.â€

â€œYes. Iâ€™d be out the cost of the equipment, thatâ€™s all.â€

â€œSo your bog standard Dark wizard, up to no good, wouldnâ€™t have much to discover here.â€

As Draco snooped, scanned and searched for interesting magical giveaways in the rest of the office, Granger pulled off her Healer robes and dropped into the chair that Draco had occupied upon his first visit. She let out a sigh of unadulterated fatigue.

Draco glanced at her. Muggle clothing again, underneath. This time a long-sleeved top and some trousers that barely merited the name, more like opaque black tights, really. Was this decent public attire by Muggle standards? Shocking. He could see the precise outline of her calf and the exact shape of her knee.

He didnâ€™t spend too long musing upon the foibles of Muggle fashion, however, as the witch herself was a bit of a concern. He could see now how thin she was, how her collarbones shadowed, how her neck seemed too dainty to hold the mass of hair pinned upon her head. She was pale, peaky, and generally looked overdrawn.

â€œWhatâ€™s your schedule like, Granger?â€ Draco asked, as though continuing his querying about her travel patterns, but really wanting to get a sense of what exactly this woman did with herself, day in and day out.

Typically, Granger had a schedule ready â€“ colour-coded and planned to the hour. And there were many â€“ Granger was everywhere and did everything. After sheâ€™d left, Draco, being a pragmatic and sneakish kind of person, took advantage of the moment to cast a few discreet tracking spells upon a handful of her personal items: the trainers under the desk, hairpins (the blarmed things were everywhere), a half-finished mug of tea. â€œPortkey. For moments when you couldnâ€™t Apparate, or if you were trapped in an Anti-Apparition Ward. I havenâ€™t worked out the calculations.â€

Granger looked mildly impressed. Draco supposed that she was surrounded by the nationâ€™s greatest magical brains on the daily, and that he ought to be pleased that she was mildly impressed by a mere Aurorâ€™s paltry creation.

â€œAn on-demand Portkey would be something,â€ said Granger.

â€œPortus is a pain in the arse of an enchantment,â€ said Draco, trying to sound resigned, rather than sullen.

â€œHave you ever thought of making more of these rings? You could monetise these easily,â€ said Granger, holding the ring aloft.

â€œDo I look like I need money?â€ asked Draco.

Granger levelled a stare at him. Her back straightened. They had been dangerously close to lapsing into a civil conversation and she seemed to have forgotten who she was talking to. She sniffed in lieu of responding.

â€œAnyway, I canâ€™t mass-produce the ring.â€

â€œRight.â€ Granger was weighing the ring in the palm of her hand. â€œBecause this isnâ€™t just some trinket you put a few neat charms on.â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œThis is an Artefact.â€

â€œIndeed.â€

â€œA family heirloom, if I were to hazard a guess.â€

â€œYes.â€

Of course sheâ€™d spotted the concealment charm that made the ring look like a plain silver band. â€œYouâ€™re certain this ring wonâ€™t immediately attempt to amputate my finger? Iâ€™m not Pure, after all,â€ said Granger.

â€œDid you see a sign of Dark magic?â€ asked Draco. Too quickly â€“ heâ€™d sounded defensive. Blast.

â€œIf there was Dark magic, itâ€™s gone now,â€ said Granger.

â€œIâ€™ll need some time to go through this extremely comprehensive list of recommendations,â€ she said at length.

â€œI will,â€ she said.

â€œI suppose I want to say thank you. For working through this as you are. I havenâ€™t exactly been pulling my weight trying to find a solution to Shackleboltâ€™s request. The ring is a good idea.â€

â€œI think youâ€™re more than pulling your weight elsewhere,â€ said Draco.

House Call by Genius Inventor

Dracoâ€™s eagle owl was given a decent workout in the coming days as Draco and Granger negotiated back and forth on a few of the recommendations that heâ€™d made. Granger â€“ Shackleboltâ€™s orders on the warding of the Granger domicile arenâ€™t up for negotiation. Do let me know when would be convenient to come by this week for the warding. If you donâ€™t, I shall drop by at an inconvenient time by default. - D (for Draconian)

Malfoy â€“ Unsure if you heard my sigh of exasperation from London, so I am recording its occurrence here for your information. I am more than capable of improving the warding on my own property, or of hiring a warding firm. But, if Shacklebolt is insisting on your particular expertise, so be it. Granger â€“ I know what a doctor is. - D

~

So, what did the home of a nationally famous scholar / war heroine / Healer / Champion of Just Causes / Researcher-In-Danger look like?

A modest sort of cottage in Cambridgeshire, as it happened. Three bedrooms, at Dracoâ€™s best guess. Granger stood at the gate. As he approached from his Apparition point, she waved her wand to allow him to pass whatever preliminary wards she had set up.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong with your face?â€ she asked as Draco neared the gate.

Always to the point, was Granger.

â€œBludger,â€ said Draco.

â€œOh. It looks bad.â€

(It probably did, too; Zabini had a mean swing.)

â€œThatâ€™s going to make a lovely hematoma.â€

â€œIâ€™m fine. I came here to ward your house, not for a consult.â€

â€œCome in, then,â€ said Granger, a little snappish, pulling the gate open.

â€œRight,â€ said Draco, not deigning to request clarification. â€œGive us a tour and letâ€™s crack on.â€

â€œYou scolded me for placing a book half an inch out of place. Look at this disaster,â€ said Draco, piqued by the injustice.

â€œItâ€™s my digitising project,â€ said Granger. â€œItâ€™s a temporary disaster.â€ She gestured to a Muggle machine in the centre of it all, connected to a flattish version of a computer.

â€œDigitising?â€

â€œYes. She brought Draco through to the kitchen, a rather Muggle space, save for the variety of magical plants explosively taking over her window ledges and various potions aglow here and there. There mightâ€™ve been something magical slowly brewing in a cauldron at the hearth, but she swept him past it.

â€œConservatory?â€ asked Draco as they moved to the next room.

That seemed an optimistic appellation to Draco, who watched January sleet begin to drizzle against the glass ceiling with scepticism.

Then an odd, orange, squash-faced creature appeared, and wound its way around Grangerâ€™s ankles.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong with your cat?â€ asked Draco, bending over to regard the creature with concern.

â€œNothingâ€™s wrong with him,â€ said Granger. Both she and the creature looked at Draco with great offence. â€œHeâ€™s part Kneazle, and very intelligent. Arenâ€™t you, my darling? My sweetums? My angel boy?â€

As its ears were massaged by Granger, the cat regarded Draco with an expression of utmost disdain.

Then it decided that it had had enough of Grangerâ€™s attention and turned to leave, its absurd tail held high, so that Draco got a full view of its bumhole.

â€œCharming,â€ said Draco.

The tour continued to the cramped upstairs space. Three small bedrooms, as Draco had guessed, with predictable points of entry that he would have to ward.

The first bedroom appeared to be used as a study. Draco noted a kind of plinth in the middle of the space. On it rested a grimoire, very old and damaged, surrounded by the glow of stasis charms.

Draco did not wish to deal with bookish snivelling and did not pursue the subject, but he made a mental note of the object, for future prying.

The second bedroom was quite bare, save for a long mat on the floor, candles, and a cluster of orchids. What ritual was Granger preparing to cast here? He tried to make sense of the candle arrangement, but it didnâ€™t match the geometry of anything he recognised.

Finally, they came to Grangerâ€™s bedroom, which she permitted him a glance into with evident unease. Draco couldnâ€™t find a civil way to say, stop bloody fidgeting, I only need to see how the baddies might try to kidnap you; Iâ€™m not here to rifle through your knickers, so he said nothing.

An obnoxious jingle began to play somewhere in Grangerâ€™s vicinity. She pulled a palm-sized Muggle thingie out of her pocket and spoke into it. From what Draco understood, she was being summoned to the surgery by the means of this device.

She confirmed this by rushing past Draco to the stairs. â€œI have to go. I think youâ€™ve seen enough to orient yourself â€“ please set the wards to let Crookshanks in and out. He likes to roam. Iâ€™ll be back in a few hours.â€

â€œCrookshanks?â€ called Draco as Granger tripped down the stairs.

â€œThe cat!â€ said Granger.

She disappeared outside, but instead of the crack of Disapparition, Draco heard the sound of a motor. Granger was driving. A Muggle car.

The absolute weirdo.

Or perhaps not, he thought upon reflection, as he made his way back to the garden. If she was going to a Muggle surgery, sheâ€™d have to show up by Muggle means; an instantaneous Apparition at the door would raise questions.Â 

As he pondered the overfilled dual life that Granger led, Draco began to ward.

~

After about two hours of work, Draco pronounced himself satisfied. The wards would need to be recast every week or so, but no one would be able to waltz in sans Grangerâ€™s permission. Points of entry and egress were all reinforced with the Aurorâ€™s standard kit and a few of Dracoâ€™s own inventions; underground approaches would be flummoxed by a robust Depellens Penetrationem and aerial attacks would be rebuffed by a Caeli Praesidium. The usual assortment of intruder alarms was scattered about.

Frankly, for a witch of Grangerâ€™s relative fame, whose two closest chums were now Aurors, her protection measures had been paltry. But then, it was peacetime, and she was a scholar, now â€“ not a child chasing Dark Objects to murder an evil wizard seven times over.

The half-Kneazle stared balefully at Draco through the sleet from the shelter of the stoop. Draco added the creatureâ€™s magical signature to the wards and told him so. The creature blinked at him. Draco was unnerved.

Granger rounded the corner a moment later. â€œStill here, are you?â€

â€œI've just finished,â€ panted Draco. Warding was a magically exhausting task.

The half-Kneazle was given a great many kisses on his ugly head as Draco stood by and tried not to look wet and sweaty. And where was his thank you, if you please?

â€œAll right,â€ said Draco.

His entire look was complemented by the magnificent bruise starting to develop along his jaw. He pressed more of the salve into it, annoyed that Granger had been right about how bad it was going to get.

Draco decided that that was a suitable end to an unpleasant evening.

Imbolc

~

Two weeks passed, during which all was quiet on the Granger front. Her ring had been calibrated to alert Draco to extreme physiological or emotional shifts that might indicate immediate danger: significant spikes of fear, panic, pain, or an unusually high heart rate.

In general, Granger seemed to be miraculously even-tempered. There was one day when Dracoâ€™s ring tingled at him throughout the morning, signalling that Grangerâ€™s pulse was elevated at various points â€“ but not quite at the threshold signalling a wild panic.

He set it out of his mind and joined Goggin and a few junior Aurors for a hand-to-hand combat session. Tonks insisted that her Aurors not only maintained their Duelling expertise through rigorous practice, but also their abilities as physical fighters. Many had moaned about having to learn to fight like Muggles. Tonks had set them straight. A disarmed Auror with hand-to-hand training could still outmanoeuvre, disarm, or maim an opponent, if he kept his wits about him. A wandless Auror without those things was a very dead Auror.

Grangerâ€™s elevated pulse â€“ the fourth such incident that morning â€“ interrupted Dracoâ€™s spar. His momentary distraction earned him a solid uppercut from Goggin.

He called for a pause, clutching at his jaw, and used the Jotter to send Granger an annoyed message, consisting solely of punctuation: ???

She responded with a brief note: Losing a patient.

Draco didnâ€™t respond, mostly because he didnâ€™t know what to say, but also because Goggin had decided that the break was over and was now attempting to concuss him.

A while later he received the following missive from Granger: By the way â€“ going out of town tomorrow morning, just for the day. I know our agreement said 24 hours notice for departures and this is more like 12. Sorry, itâ€™s been hellish.

Where? was Dracoâ€™s response.

Somerset, was Grangerâ€™s.

Why?Â 

Holiday.

One of those asterisk holidays?Â 

Granger didnâ€™t respond. So, yes.

That evening, while Draco was at dinner, his ring signalled pain. But it wasnâ€™t physical pain. It was the heart-pain of grief, from somewhere in Cambridgeshire. The poignancy of the feeling surprised him. The sincerity of it. Granger truly was a Do-Gooder to the core. He supposed that she had got home and was giving way to the loss of her patient.

â€œDraco? Is everything all right?â€

Draco found himself being observed by the thoughtful blue eyes of Narcissa Malfoy. He realised heâ€™d stopped eating when the ghostly grief had suffused his senses.

â€œI'm fine,â€ said Draco. â€œJust thinking about work.â€

Draco hadnâ€™t told his mother that heâ€™d requisitioned the Malfoy rings. He was certain that she wouldnâ€™t agree with his repurposing, nor with his choice of recipient.

He cast about for a safe subject for discussion and remarked on the nicer-than-usual flower arrangement in the centre of the table. Floristry was one of his mother's hobbies.Â 

â€œDo you like it?â€ asked his mother, leaning over to touch a few delicate petals. She seemed in a pensive mood. â€œItâ€™s Imbolc tomorrow.â€

â€œImbolc?â€ The word was vaguely familiar to Draco â€“ some Pagan festival or other.

Narcissa pulled up an already perfectly placed blossom and replaced it even more perfectly in the bouquet. â€œYes â€“ it marks the end of winter. Your grandmother used to observe those old traditions when I was a little girl. The house would be decorated with snowdrops and daffodils on every surface, weâ€™d have a feast â€“ and weâ€™d feel hopeful, knowing that spring was finally on its way.â€

Draco made some polite reply. His mother watched him eat, her own hands folded onto her lap. She had something else to say.

â€œWhat is it?â€ asked Draco.

â€œAre you going to be home tomorrow? I've got some friends coming for tea.â€

Draco made a few quick calculations. Those few friends would most certainly happen to have lovely and accomplished daughters, who would no doubt come too. His mother had grown rather less subtle about her matchmaking since heâ€™d turned thirty.

Unfortunately for Narcissa (and the eligible young ladies), Dracoâ€™s own interest in anything longer term than dirty weekend escapades in Paris was nil. Heâ€™d done the longer term thing once â€“ a two-year engagement to Astoria â€“ and it had been sufficient to confirm that, no matter how Pure-blooded and well-bred the witch, he wasnâ€™t ready for marriage.

Grangerâ€™s note earlier that day offered a convenient lifeline. Draco grimaced and said, â€œIâ€™ll be working. Business in Somerset tomorrow.â€

Granger herself didnâ€™t know sheâ€™d have company, but too bad for her. Heâ€™d call it a spot check. Her safety against threats â€“ real or imagined by Shacklebolt â€“ was his highest priority, after all.

Narcissa seemed unsurprised at the ready excuse. â€œA pity. Next time, then.â€

Dinner concluded. Draco retreated to his chambers, where he took a long bath and nursed his training wounds.

His Jotter buzzed. He summoned it to find a note from Granger, a delayed response to his earlier question. Yes, one of the asterisk holidays. A spot of sightseeing. Iâ€™ll turn the ring if I need you.

That last sentence was Granger-speak for â€œI donâ€™t need you, do not come, you are not invited.â€

No doubt she would get shirty when he turned up. The thought elicited an unexpected tingle of amusement.

Then something that had been percolating in the back of Dracoâ€™s mind since dinner clicked into place. He got out of the tub, dried himself off with a few waves of his wand, and summoned Grangerâ€™s schedule.

Tomorrow was â€“ what had his mother said? Imbolc?

And that coincided with one of Grangerâ€™s asterisks.

Were there other such interesting coincidences? He ran through the rest of the dates. The next asterisk was a weekend in late March. Then one at the beginning of May. Then June. Then early August.

Abuzz with anticipatory triumph, Draco descended to the Manor's library, where he pulled out a few volumes on Celtic and Germanic Pagan traditions.

He was right. Grangerâ€™s dates matched the old calendars. Draco rolled the old words out on his tongue. Imbolc. Ostara. Beltane. Litha. Lughnasadh. Mabon. Samhain.

What was Granger up to?

Draco was officially intrigued.

~

Draco gave Granger the morning to set out on her Somerset adventure before he joined her. That permitted him an exquisite lie-in, some invigorating flying in the February wind, and the opportunity for a luxurious brunch. He kissed his motherâ€™s cheek with insincere regrets about missing tea.

Somerset was just far enough from Wiltshire that Draco had to Floo into a wizarding pub in Cannington before Apparating to Grangerâ€™s ring.

The Apparition took a moment longer than usual, with an odd sort of stretch in the final half-second, like it was trying to keep up with the destination. When he arrived, Draco understood why. Granger had been moving at a rather rapid pace, given that she was belting down a country lane in her car.

Granger shrieked as Draco materialised in the seat beside her. His head was in the passenger footwell and his boots were, by the feel of it, in Grangerâ€™s face. It was altogether not his most graceful arrival.

Granger swerved onto a verge and brought the car to a halt. Draco turned himself the right way up with difficulty as a barrage of questions came his way, including what the hell he thought he was doing, who did he think he was, how dare he, and whether or not he was actually insane?

Grangerâ€™s voice could be quite shrill. Penetrating, really.

â€œYou just Apparated to a moving target! Have you completely lost the plot? You couldâ€™ve been Splinched into a hundred different pieces, scattered about the A37!â€

â€œI didnâ€™t expect it to be a moving target,â€ said Draco, feeling dishevelled and a bit sick. â€œWhy are you driving?â€

â€œBecause you told me Apparition and Floo were traceable.â€

â€œWho cares if theyâ€™re traceable? Youâ€™re allowed to be on holiday. Nice morning for it, by the by,â€ he added, as rain pelted the car. â€œUnless your holiday has something to do with your project?â€

Granger glared at him.

â€œAha,â€ said Draco.

Seeing that the worst of the fracas had abated, Draco, having spotted a mirror just above Grangerâ€™s head, swivelled it towards himself. It was the perfect height to check oneâ€™s hair. Good sorts, Muggles, really â€“ they had their priorities straight.

Granger sputtered. â€œDid you just commandeer my rearview mirror to fix your hair?â€

â€œYou can have it back in a moment,â€ said Draco.

Granger was staring at him with an expression of dislike strong enough to unnerve a lesser man.

She swivelled the mirror back towards herself. â€œI need that. And get your overlarge feet off my dash.â€

â€œItâ€™s not my fault your car is so cramped,â€ said Draco, attempting to bring his legs in.

â€œItâ€™s not my fault youâ€™re a gangly marionette of a man who decided to Apparate into my Mini.â€

Before Draco had time to register his offence at this unfair comparison, she got to the crux of the issue: â€œAnd why are you here?â€

â€œIâ€™m conducting a spot check,â€ said Draco.

â€œA spot check,â€ repeated Granger, looking thoroughly unconvinced.

â€œYes.â€

â€œAnd? Have you established that Iâ€™m sound of mind and body?â€

Draco examined her critically. She seemed sound of body, from what he could see under the hat, anorak, scarf, and Muggle walking boots. Soundness of mind was less easy to gauge â€“ there was a sparkle of something dangerous in her eye.

â€œWell?â€ she pushed. â€œIâ€™m fine, as you can see. You can go away now.â€

Draco decided to take the high road and attempt some honesty. â€œIâ€™m also using this as a pretext.â€

â€œA pretext for what?â€

â€œAvoiding some unpleasantness at home.â€

â€œWhat sort of unpleasantness?â€

Relentless sort of witch. â€œMy mother is having ladies over for tea.â€

Whatever Granger was expecting, it hadnâ€™t been that. A queer expression flashed across her face, as of one holding back a laugh. â€œLadies over for tea?â€ she repeated.

â€œYes. What is so funny?â€

â€œI thought itâ€™d be something more â€“ more fearsome.â€ The held-back laughter faded. â€œAnyway, I donâ€™t want to suffer because youâ€™re afraid of some ladies. I donâ€™t need, nor want, you hanging about today. I have things to do.â€

â€œItâ€™s Imbolc today,â€ said Draco conversationally. "Did you know?"

Granger said nothing, but looked freshly annoyed.

â€œWhatâ€™re you up to in Somerset at Imbolc?â€ asked Draco. â€œI didnâ€™t know you kept the Old Ways. You donâ€™t seem the type for flowers and dancing about poles.â€

When Granger didnâ€™t answer him again, Draco settled himself into his seat. â€œIâ€™ve assessed the situation and â€“ since itâ€™s obviously to do with your dangerous project â€“ I will be monitoring you today, for your own safety. Per item eleven of my recommendations. Donâ€™t argue.â€

â€œI will eject you from this car,â€ said Granger.

â€œYou canâ€™t do that.â€

â€œI can. This button, here,â€ said Granger, pointing to a round thing on the dashboard. â€œItâ€™s a safety feature Muggles invented.â€

A whining whistle began to wail through the car. Granger jumped. â€œWhat is that?â€

â€œOh, that,â€ said Draco. â€œA safety feature wizards invented. I put a Sneakoscope in your glovebox, as you suggested. You lied to me about the eject button and Iâ€™m hurt.â€

Granger leaned over him and popped open the glovebox (â€œOw â€“ my knees!â€) to see that there was indeed a Sneakoscope therein. It whistled and flashed for a few moments more, then, given that there was no more lying going on, it stilled.

There was a long silence. Granger pulled back into her seat, leaned her forehead on the steering wheel, and appeared to be collecting herself.

â€œFine,â€ she said at length. â€œYou can stay for the duration of this distressing tea of your motherâ€™s. Just donâ€™t get in my way.â€

She turned the key and the carâ€™s engine kicked into life. â€œPut on your seatbelt. Or donâ€™t. I suppose I donâ€™t care if you die a gruesome death.â€

The Sneakoscope wailed again. Granger swore at it quite colourfully.

â€œWhat does that button really do?â€ asked Draco when the row had faded.

This innocent question seemed to set Granger off anew. â€œIt used to be the stereo system â€“ until someoneâ€™s warding messed it up. Now it only plays Austrian folk songs.â€

Draco pressed the button. Austrian folk songs began to play.

Grangerâ€™s hands were tight on the steering wheel as she pulled back onto the road.

It was clear that, in her opinion, Draco was the real Nuisance Auror.

~

Muggle signposting was excellent. As they made their way down progressively windier country lanes, Draco was able to guess at their final destination with a degree of certainty.

â€œGlastonbury,â€ he said. â€œInteresting.â€

Granger said nothing. Her displeasure at his presence continued and she was not hiding it. It mattered little to Draco â€“ a rainy drive through the English countryside with an angry Granger was a refreshing change from the usual too-small sandwiches and coquettish fortune-hunters.

Honestly, the winding drive, the Austrian music, the fuming witch â€“ it was absurd, it was amusing, it was fun.

Draco reached to press another button on the carâ€™s central panel, out of curiosity. Granger slapped his hand away.

She had decent reflexes, reflected Draco as he sucked on his stinging knuckle.

Instead of driving down the street that led into the town of Glastonbury proper, Granger made a detour to a car park at the edge of a forest.

There, a footpath wound into a woodland, rather soaked and frosty-looking at this time of year.

â€œWhatâ€™s this?â€ asked Draco.

â€œThe Mendip Way,â€ replied Granger, in that way she had of answering his questions without actually answering his questions. She got out of the car. â€œIâ€™m going for a walk. You may wait in the car.â€

May he? So generous. Draco â€“ after a brief struggle with the handle â€“ let himself out of the vehicle. He withheld groans as he stamped some feeling back into his legs.

Granger observed his emergence from the Mini with her hands on her hips. He felt her observing his choice of clothing (his Auror robes over his perennial suit) and footwear (perfectly functional dragonhide boots). She mustâ€™ve concluded that it would have to do â€“ or otherwise, that it wouldnâ€™t do, and would put him in peril, and that that was perfect.

At any rate, she turned around and began to walk towards the woods.

Draco saw her cast some rain-repelling and warming charms on herself. He imitated her; it seemed a good idea.

As they entered the Mendip Way, Draco cast a few detection spells, looking for evidence of other beings, magical or Muggle. However, it seemed that only he and Granger were mad enough to go for a ramble on a day like this. Save some roe deer in a nearby clearing, they were alone.

Satisfied that no madmen were about to vault out and attack Granger, Draco caught up to her in a few long strides.

It quickly became obvious that this wasnâ€™t just a walk for Grangerâ€™s health. She was looking for something. Or several somethings. She peered into the underbrush, touched the trunks of trees, gently caught the fronds of ferns in her palm and studied them. She took nothing, however, and so quashed any theories about ingredient gathering that Draco might have been entertaining.

They progressed in this manner for a good half hour, marked by a pause to refresh their fading Impervius charms.

Finally, Granger stopped, and pulled out a list.

Draco unashamedly peeked over her shoulder.

Singing Sedge
 Greater Bladderwort
 Royal Fern
 Ophioglossun vulgatum
 Wood-sorrel
 Mellifluous Honewort
 Helianthemum apenninum
 Helianthemum nummularium
Spiny Restharrow
 Tassel Moss

Granger used her wand to cross out the majority of the list. Only the Tassel Moss remained.

â€œWhatâ€™s Tassel Moss?â€ asked Draco.

Granger flinched away from him. Apparently, sheâ€™d been so much in her own head that sheâ€™d quite forgotten that Draco was there, much less noticed that he was skulking over her shoulder.

Her hand flew to her fast-beating heart (Draco felt faint echoes of it through the ring). He expected to be told off. However, her bad mood seemed to have been replaced by tentative excitement related to this list.

â€œOne of the rarer mosses in this part of England,â€ said Granger.

â€œWhy are you looking for it?â€

Granger began to walk again, her attention focused, this time, on dead logs, old stumps, and other likely habitats. â€œBecause it will confirm that Iâ€™m in the right place.â€

â€œThe right place for what?â€

â€œWhat theory?â€

(Draco, too, could be relentless.)

â€œSomething related to my project,â€ said Granger with irritating ambiguity.

â€œWhatâ€™s moss got to do with your Chimaera cells, or whatever?â€

â€œNothing â€“ at least, not directly.â€ She turned to look at him through the rain, as though to gauge what was worth telling him. â€œIâ€™m retracing the steps of an old, long-forgotten witch whose work included â€“ amongst many things â€“ descriptions of certain sacred sites in the British Isles.â€

â€œSo, the Vale of Avalon?â€

â€œSpecifically, Glastonburyâ€™s wells. Or at least, thatâ€™s my educated guess. Not much of her work is still extant today. All we have are fragments. She tended to wax lyrically on flora, which helps me narrow down possible locations by cross-referencing the rarer plants. Of course, she was writing hundreds of years ago, so things may have changed. But few places on the island will support both Singing Sedge and Mellifluous Honewart. They typically thrive in radically different ecosystems, as you no doubt knowâ€¦â€

No, Draco didnâ€™t know â€“ in fact, heâ€™d never even heard of these plants â€“ but he nodded instead of admitting it.

When Draco next looked up, for a heart-stopping moment, Granger had disappeared â€“ he snatched his wand â€“ then he saw her backside poking over the edge of the path. She was on her hands and knees, examining a rather wet ditch.

Whatever had caught her eye, it wasnâ€™t what she was looking for. She regained her feet. She didnâ€™t look disappointed, however â€“ she looked determined. And muddy.

â€œTassel Moss looks as youâ€™d imagine,â€ said Granger. â€œTiny tassels across the top. Itâ€™s the sporangia â€“ unusually big in the genus. They turn pink in the summer â€“ of course, weâ€™re a little too early for that.â€

Was this woman a genius at Herbology, on top of everything else? Draco wondered how much of Potter and Weasleyâ€™s limited scholarly success was due to absorbing her knowledge by intellectual osmosis.

She was, frankly, overwhelming.

Granger carried on along the path, squatting down occasionally to observe things. It was altogether rather a peaceful ramble, with the charms keeping him dry, the sound of the rain and the occasional brave songbird, and verbalisations from Granger telling off various mosses because they werenâ€™t the right one.

For the first time since heâ€™d taken the Granger casefile from Tonksâ€™ hands, Draco felt glad of the decision. This was certainly more pleasant than most of his work as an Auror â€“ fewer hexes and eviscerations coming his way, for a start.

And, bonus, it got him out of tea with the ladies, and promised many more opportunities to do so. That set would be tut-tutting at Granger over their teacups â€“ Granger with her hat askew, her face smeared with dirt, clambering about in ditches instead of finding herself a rich husband. â€œI think I found it!â€ called Granger.

Draco pushed through some brambles to be, once again, presented with a view of Grangerâ€™s bum. Familiarity breeds fondness â€“ he was rather developing an appreciation for it.

â€œGranger, whatâ€“â€

â€œItâ€™s meant to smell like candy-floss. And it does!â€ said Granger, rising with a leap.

There was dirt on the tip of her nose. In the shadows of the great oaks around them, her dark eyes shone with excitement. A curl of hair clung damply to her lip. Her cheeks were pinched pink by the February wind. Her smile flashed at him, a brief, rare thing.

Draco realised with a shock that Granger was pretty.

She clapped her hands together and squealed at the clump of moss, as though it was a treasure worth thousands upon thousands of Galleons.

Before Draco could process his realisation, a hoarse scream echoed from some distant corner of the woods. To his amusement, Granger leapt to his side immediately, her wand raised.

The queer screaming continued. When Granger saw that he hadnâ€™t reacted and didnâ€™t seem alarmed, she asked, â€œWhat is that horrid racket?â€

â€œOh.â€

â€œSome slag of a vixenâ€™s asking to get her back blown out.â€

â€œI see,â€ said Granger.

Another scream. Draco wanted to laugh â€“ Grangerâ€™s expression had gone rather prim.

â€œThatâ€™s it?â€ asked Draco. It had seemed rather easy.

Knowing her, that was probably not an exaggeration. They walked back to the car. Without Grangerâ€™s constant hops into the vegetation, it was rather quicker than the way in.

Draco shrank his Auror robes into a handkerchief, which he pocketed. Then he modified his suit to fit the current Muggle fashion, a little more relaxed in its tailoring. â€œNo.â€

â€œYes.â€

She did not, to her credit, cast any aspersions on his ability to behave like a Muggle.

The Keepers

They drove in silence for a little while. Granger looked preoccupied. Her thumb tapped at the steering wheel and she was worrying her lip.Â 

â€œItâ€™s going to be busy this afternoon,â€ said Granger at length. â€œAt the Gardens, I mean. Letâ€™s try to keep a low profile. We have to go through the gift shop to buy tickets to go in, but after that weâ€™ll be able to go into the gardens themselves and avoid the worst of the crowds.â€

â€œI can keep a low profile,â€ said Draco.

Granger gave him a side-eye in lieu of response.

â€œDoes the water have magical properties?â€ asked Draco. â€œWhy do the Muggles even know about it?â€

Granger sat up straighter and took a breath, and Draco realised that had activated Swot Mode.

â€œThe wellsprings in this area have been in use by both Muggles and magical folk for millennia,â€ said Granger. â€œIt wouldâ€™ve been too difficult to wipe the entire thing from so many minds after the Statute of Secrecy, I suppose. But, to answer your question, Muggles only know of two water sources in Glastonbury: one they call the White Spring, and one they call the Red Well. No real magical properties in either, though Muggles have ascribed their own spiritual and mythological significance to both. They have stories linking them to the Holy Grail, and King Arthur (heâ€™s meant to be buried in Glastonbury Abbey), and other bits of legend.â€

They were now approaching the outskirts of town. Granger turned at a sign pointing to the Chalice Well Gardens.

â€œBut,â€ she continued, â€œthereâ€™s a third wellspring, one that you wonâ€™t find in the Muggle brochures. Itâ€™s called the Green Well. That one has bona fide magical properties. â€œFor your project.â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œAnd why at Imbolc, specifically?â€

â€œYouâ€™re being rather too inquisitive,â€ said Granger. Draco felt that she meant meddlesome, but had chosen the more polite option.

â€œI suppose the well reaches its highest magical potency at Imbolc,â€ said Draco.

Granger made no answer.

â€œIâ€™m right, arenâ€™t I?â€

He saw her glance at the glovebox, wherein lay the Sneakoscope, promising to give away blatant lies.

â€œStop being so curious,â€ said Granger.

â€œThatâ€™s a bit rich, coming from you.â€

She scoffed. â€œBeing curious is literally my job. Iâ€™m a researcher. Your job is to protect me from Forces Unknown, not interrogate me on a highly confidential, proprietary project.â€

Granger pulled into a parking spot, turned off the car, and waited for his retort.

This witch was â€“ something. Draco had never endured such unrelenting points and counterpoints. He rather felt that, if heâ€™d been keeping track of the score, heâ€™d be the losing party.

â€œIâ€™m not a bodyguard.Â I wasnâ€™t assigned to you to clomp along brainlessly behind you,â€ said Draco.

â€œNo. Youâ€™re a highly trained, highly competent Auror and this is an utter waste of your time.â€ Granger took a breath, visibly suppressing her irritation at the entire situation.

The opening compliment elicited a tiny spark of delight, quickly suppressed by Draco. He didnâ€™t care what Granger thought of him.

A group of Muggles passed the car, distracting the both of them. Mutually deciding on an unspoken truce â€“ very temporary, Draco was sure â€“ they climbed out of the car.

The car park was busy. Muggles in families, Muggles pushing prams, Muggles in outfits that seemed exceptionally outlandish, even for Muggles.

â€œIâ€™ll warn you now, there are a lot of New Agey types here,â€ said Granger as they joined the crowd headed towards the entrance.

â€œNew Agey?â€

â€œHippies. Wiccans. Pagans. Woo-woo types.â€ Granger seemed to be struggling for a definition. â€œMuggles who are very spiritual and believe in magic â€“ or greater powers, anyway â€“ to some extent. They collect crystals and things, and perform rituals they read about in old books.â€

â€œAh,â€ said Draco, though he didnâ€™t really understand. â€œI thought Muggles were meant to be relentlessly logical.â€

â€œSome are,â€ said Granger. â€œSome are â€“ rather less than logical. Or perhaps some part of them remembers magic. Or subconsciously knows it exists. Or maybe they just want to believe in somethingâ€¦â€

They entered the busy gift shop â€“ bustling, cloyingly over-scented.

Draco examined some offensively perfumed candles, labelled â€˜For Relaxation.â€™ â€œWhy doesnâ€™t someone tell them theyâ€™ve over-synthesised these things to the point where any minor magical property is utterly lost?â€

Draco now found himself being steered by Granger and parked in a corner of the shop, like a Draco-shaped Mini Cooper.

â€œStay here,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™ll get us tickets. Donâ€™t break anything.â€

Thank goodness for that last tip; he mightâ€™ve begun to pulverise things out of sheer excess of spirit, otherwise. Shoving his hands into his pockets, Draco stood in the corner and watched Granger go. The crowd around her didnâ€™t look at her twice. She really did blend in. As for him, he was the subject of more than a few upward glances â€“ his height, his white-blond hair, his â€˜spiffyâ€™ suit.

Granger had now joined the slow-moving queue for tickets. Having his Principal away from him in a busy spot was not something that Draco was keen on, from a purely professional standpoint. He performed some surreptitious Legilimency on a random sampling of the people in the shop. The crowd was comprised mostly of Muggles. There was one wizarding couple, but they had no ill-intent â€“ nor any idea that Granger was here. Would they recognise her if they saw her? Maybe â€“ but Draco couldnâ€™t delve into their minds so precisely from this distance.

Grangerâ€™s instructions to keep a low profile were rather hypocritical, given that she had just struck up a conversation with the Muggles in the queue behind her. Draco, annoyed, cast a surface-level Legilimency on the family to check for sinister intentions. Nothing of interest â€“ they were just friendly tourists.

He grew aware of a presence lurking about him, peeking at him from around one shelf, then around the other. He pretended to be interested in the smelly candles.

Eventually, she showed herself. She was a shop assistant, heavily draped in diaphanous scarves, observing Draco with bulbous eyes. A name-tag was pinned to her jumper: Eunice.

â€œHello,â€ she said to Draco. â€œMight I help you find something?â€

Draco caught her gaze and read her immediate thoughts. Nothing ominous, save for the fact that she thought him dreadfully handsome.

â€œNo, thanks,â€ said Draco, turning back to watch Granger between candles. She was finally nearing the front of the queue.Â 

Instead of taking this as the firm dismissal it was, Eunice fluttered closer to Draco, her eyes glued to his face.

â€œYour aura is... disturbed,â€ she said.

Draco felt like he was being addressed by a Muggle incarnation of Trelawney crossed with a large moth.

â€œI donâ€™t think these candles will do you good,â€ said Eunice.

â€œI agree with you there,â€ said Draco.

The sarcasm was lost on her. She nodded to herself and palpated the air around Draco, as though grasping at something.

â€œIâ€™d suggest something stronger, like one of our cleansing incenses,â€ said Eunice, drifting down to point at a different shelf.

Draco watched Granger make a beeline to the cafÃ©-bar. Would she kindly hurry up and save him from the moth?

Eunice was now holding her hand towards him with her eyes closed. She shook her head gravely. â€œYour heart chakra is underactive.â€

â€œIs it?â€

â€œThe Venus Incense, I think,â€ said Eunice. She grasped a packet and waved the pungent thing under Dracoâ€™s nose. â€œAlthough, with your need for grounding, perhaps the Saturnâ€¦â€

She rummaged around the shelf and said things about transmuting energy and ascending to the celestial plane. Draco spied Grangerâ€™s hat bobbing in his direction through the crowd.

â€œI have to go,â€ he said, making his escape.

â€œOh, do you?â€ Eunice seemed put out. She slipped something into Dracoâ€™s hand. â€œMy card. I do chakra realignments. Do reach out â€“ our energies are quite compatible...â€

Eunice floated away just as Granger arrived, bearing coffees.

â€œWho was that?â€ asked Granger, observing the retreating flutter of scarves.

â€œEunice,â€ said Draco. â€œShe gave me this. Do you need your chakras realigned?â€

Granger exchanged one of her coffees for the proffered card. Something had been scribbled hastily on it.

â€œOoh, she gave you her number.â€

â€œWhatâ€™s that mean?â€

â€œThat Eunice fancies you,â€ said Granger, looking amused.

â€œMost women do.â€

Granger snorted, like this was a wickedly funny joke instead of a universal truth. She caught herself, sobered up, and looked at him with fresh wonder. â€œYou're funny, Malfoy.â€

â€œI live to serve,â€ said Draco, to cover his vexation.

Granger returned the card to him. â€œToo bad you donâ€™t even know what a mobile is. Poor Eunice was quite barking up the wrong tree.â€

â€œShe thought me dreadfully handsome.â€Â 

â€œShe also thinks your chakras need realigning. Letâ€™s not get too wrapped up in the soundness of Eunice's judgements,â€ said Granger crisply.

Let it be known that if any man needed his ego checked, a simple exchange with Granger would quite set him to rights.

Draco sipped at the coffee Granger had brought. It was, remarkably, not terrible. â€œHow did you know I like double espressos?â€

Granger shrugged. â€œIt seemed your style.â€

â€œBold? Bitter?â€

â€œOverpriced.â€

Draco hid his scoff in the cup.

Granger set them on a course towards the gardens. The rain began to let up and make way for tentative sunlight. The gardens were unexpectedly lovely, even if the Muggles in charge didnâ€™t have access to the warming charms and magical additives that made wizarding gardens such a spectacle through winter. Draco thought his mother might even appreciate the place. Though it was February, there was colour about, thanks to careful plant selections. Musical gurgles of water from wellsprings everywhere added auditory interest and the whole thing was gently illuminated by hundreds upon hundreds of candles tucked away in stony recesses.

Signposts here and there asked visitors to maintain silence, out of respect for those meditating. Granger cast a silencing charm around the two of them so that they could talk.


The Red Well at Glastonbury. (Photo: britainexpress.com)

They came upon the Red Well â€“ aptly named, with its rust-coloured water. Draco read the plaque with passing interest. As Granger had noted earlier, the Muggles had fabricated some fanciful bit of Christian mythology suggesting the Holy Grail was buried here. There were also a few references to Arthurian legend.

â€œThe Muggles know about Morgan le Fay?â€ asked Draco, an eyebrow rising at the sight of such a famous witchâ€™s name on a Muggle placard.

â€œYes â€“ but sheâ€™s a figure of myth,â€ said Granger. â€œMost of them donâ€™t think she really existed.â€

Draco tutted. Imagine.

Next, they strolled through the well house that contained the White Spring â€“ a dark, wet-smelling place, where Muggles had decorated the rough stone walls with candles and small shrines to deities real and imagined: Saint Brigid, the Lady of Avalon, the King of the Faeriesâ€¦

â€œHere we are,â€ said Granger, as they made their way down a quieter, less-used path round the back of the well house. â€œThere should be a sort of platform to take us down to the Green Well. Weâ€™ll have to use our wands to get in â€“ letâ€™s Disillusion ourselves in case any Muggles pass by.â€

Granger was now a Granger-shaped patch of garden in front of Draco, glimmering in the weak February sun.

They stopped (well, Granger stopped, and Draco ran into her) at what looked like a manhole cover, tucked halfway under a bush. Across its weathered, cast-iron surface, were two large circles, intersecting under dead leaves and moss.

â€œThat symbolises the interplay between the physical and spiritual worlds,â€ said Granger. Draco could make out her ghostly wand gesturing at it. â€œYou might recognise the shape â€“ the Red Well is constructed the same way. Letâ€™s get on. Itâ€™s the platform down.â€

They stood together on the manhole cover, rather squished.

â€œIncantation?â€ asked Draco, getting a mouthful of Grangerâ€™s invisible hair for the trouble.

â€œVesica piscis,â€ said Granger, mimicking the circular symbol with a wand-wave.

The manhole cover shuddered. Granger crept closer to him. She smelled like a gorgeous combination of rain, wet forest, cappuccino, and soap.

Then, without a by-your-leave, the platform dropped out from under them.

The gorgeous-smelling witch clung to Draco and pierced both of his eardrums with her shriek.

Thank the heavens for those silencing charms, thought Draco as they fell.

A thick cushioning spell met them at the bottom of the drop. Which was excellent, as Draco hadnâ€™t intended to break both of his ankles today.

He and Granger landed, bounced painfully into each other â€“ he was quite certain he elbowed her in the tit; she narrowly avoided his groin with her knee â€“ and collapsed, spread-eagled, on a thick bed of glowing fungi.

â€œWow. A first class voyage,â€ drawled Draco in the dark.

â€œGah,â€ responded Granger with something less than her usual acumen.

Draco rose. Granger was somewhere on his left. She didnâ€™t seem to be making out quite as well as he was â€“ she was rather shocked.

â€œC-couldnâ€™t they set up a levitation charm?â€ she asked weakly. â€œI thought that thing was a lift. I didnâ€™t expect a h-harrowing plummet to my death.â€

Draco groped about in the dimness to find that his coffee was a lost cause. A pity.

They dismissed their Disillusionments and, when Granger managed to find her feet, began to walk down a passage illuminated by large, bioluminescent mushrooms. The sound of trickling water echoed throughout. Draco saw that even the walls were wet with a constant stream of moisture.

As they entered a kind of long, low-ceilinged cave, Draco saw that there were other witches and wizards about. In a corner was what looked like a kind of bookshop, which Granger eyed longingly. There was also a counter that served as an apothecary. The entire place was lit solely by the glow of the mushrooms, which were everywhere â€“ the floor, the walls, dangling from the ceiling.

â€œOmphalotus luxaeterna,â€ said Granger. â€œPretty, in a slimy sort of way.â€

If she added a â€œLike you,â€ Draco was going to hex her â€“ his ego had taken enough abuse today.

She didnâ€™t. (It was almost disappointing that sheâ€™d let the occasion slip.)

They came at last to the Green Well â€“ a bubbling green-lit wellspring, flanked by two statues in the penumbra. At least, Draco had thought they were statues â€“ until they moved.

â€œThe Keepers of the Well,â€ said Granger, who seemed unsurprised at the sight. â€œRight. You stay here. I need to do the talking. They have to be dealt with politely. And respectfully.â€

Ignoring the insinuation that he couldnâ€™t be polite or respectful, Draco said, â€œI think Iâ€™d rather come.â€

His eyes strained to get a sense of what, exactly, lurked in the mushroom-speckled darkness.

Grangerâ€™s irritation flared immediately. â€œYou said you wouldnâ€™t get in the way. Youâ€™re not even meant to be here. This is delicate. And critically important.â€

â€œFine,â€ hissed Draco. â€œIâ€™ll stay here.â€

He was within hexing range, anyway.

Granger advanced. Draco peered at the two black-draped, hunch-backed forms. Were they witches? It was hard to tell in the dark. If they were witches, they most certainly had Hag blood, somewhere up the family tree. As well as a few other things, no doubt.

Their twin pale stares, as luminescent as the mushrooms around them, disconcerted him. He found himself gripping his wand as Granger stepped up to the nearest of the Keepers.

His first thought, as he processed this situation, was that Granger was either stupidly brave, or absolutely fucking reckless. Secondly, he didnâ€™t like this at all. These beings felt Dark. Old. Dangerous.

Yes, Tonks, she was killed by a Hag. Yes, I was right there. Yes, I let her walk right up to it. Yes, she was disembowelled right in front of me. She wanted to pop by for some fancy water from this well, you know; nothing else would do.

â€œHere for a fill, dearie?â€ croaked the Keeper to Granger. The husky, dry voice echoed eerily.

â€œYes â€“ if I might? I have an offering,â€ said Granger. Her figure was a slight silhouette, backlit by the luminescence of the Green Well.

â€œShow me,â€ said the Keeper.

The creature leaned towards Granger. There was something hungry in her movements. Dracoâ€™s wand-hand twitched. If the thing moved any closer to Granger, he had a decapitation curse ready to be unleashed.

Granger, as always, was well-prepared. From somewhere in her anorak (where?!) she produced three large satchels, which she passed into the claws of the creature. â€œGrain, offal, gold.â€

The second Keeper shuffled over, stuck her talon-like fingers into one of the bags, and pulled out a handful of glinting Galleons. (And where had Granger come by an entire sack of Galleons, by the by?)

The first Keeper gestured Granger forward. â€œHavenâ€™t you got a vessel, child?â€

The thing wheezed in assent. At a gesture from the Keeper, Granger plunged the flask into the Green Well.

The second Keeper stared at Draco, as though aware of his tightly gripped wand and the well-practised curses that awaited on his tongue. She sniffed the air in his direction.

â€œPut the wand away, little boy. This girl wonâ€™t be meeting her demise here.â€

â€œIt is.â€

The first Keeperâ€™s white eyes caught Dracoâ€™s. There was ancient magic in them. He dared not perform Legilimency on this old mind.

Cold dread trickled down Dracoâ€™s spine, though the creature hadnâ€™t spoken a direct threat. He wondered whether his Darker curses would even be of use against these things â€“ perhaps he should be thinking Light.

â€œDonâ€™t you start with the rhyming,â€ said the first Keeper to her sister. â€œWe donâ€™t want to mess with his melon.â€

â€œLove and light, my girl,â€ said the first Keeper.

â€œThey were bloody She-Dementors, and youâ€™re never to deal with that kind of creature again, without telling me first. They stepped onto the platform. Draco heard the invisible Granger take a deep, steadying breath.

And just like that, they were back in the Chalice Well Gardens, blinking in the sunshine. â€œFucking â€“ damned â€“ sodding â€“ gah!â€ said Granger into Dracoâ€™s chest.

His voice seemed to bring her back to herself. She held him for a moment longer, then took a shaky breath and stepped away with a muttered apology. Draco glanced about for Muggles and, seeing none, he cancelled their Disillusionment.

â€œThat was awful,â€ she said.

â€œYou could land head-first on your way down, next time, make a bit of a milkshake for her...â€

Draco stared at Granger. Perhaps it was Healer humour, but she could be grisly when she worked off her adrenaline. Maybe it was a good thing she didnâ€™t play Quidditch. Draco studied her. She looked genuinely crestfallen that he was going to ruin a third activity on todayâ€™s list. He decided to be charitable. â€œTell me what it is and Iâ€™ll decide if itâ€™s dangerous or not. Perhaps Iâ€™ll wait in the car.â€

~

As it turned out, Grangerâ€™s moment of pure self-indulgence? Her terrible indiscretion? Her vice?

â€œYes. At Tynstesfield.â€

â€œA library. I shall have to report it.â€

â€œOf course. It must be.â€

â€œAnd I donâ€™t know when Iâ€™ll be back in Somerset.â€

â€œFine. You can visit your blessed Titsfieldâ€“â€
