Draco gave the glovebox a harrowing glare.

â€œHoisted by your own petard,â€ said Granger.

All of her previous annoyance had dissipated. She was most definitely holding back a grin.

The wail faded.

â€œIâ€™m going to throw that blasted thing out of the window,â€ said Draco.

â€œDonâ€™t. Iâ€™ve grown rather fond of it.â€

Thanks to some rather zippy driving on Grangerâ€™s part (â€œSpeed limits? A suggestion, really,â€ as the Sneakoscope sang) they made it to Tynstesfield half an hour before closing.

Granger was able to partake in the library and the orangery, and Draco enjoyed a poppyseed cake from the cafÃ©, and they watched the sunset together, and only quarrelled four times.

Finding Serenity

Chapter Notes

This chapter contains some French. I am half French but I didnâ€™t want to annoy readers with excessive use of another language, nor encumber the text with translations. Iâ€™ll indicate that they are speaking in French and put the dialogue in English. Please read with much nasalness, uvular fricatives, and overuse of â€˜euh.â€™

After their Imbolc outing, Granger all but disappeared from Dracoâ€™s life. He visited her laboratory and home once a week to recast the wards, but their schedules rarely coincided, and he saw her cat more often than he saw her.

Occasionally, his Jotter would buzz, and inform him that Granger was attending X public event at Y location. As her assigned Auror, she left his attendance to his discretion, though she made it clear his presence would be superfluous at best and bothersome at worst.

Most of the events took place in secure magical locations â€“ panels at St. Mungos or Huntercombe, symposia at magical universities â€“ so Draco had rarely seen a need to exert himself and attend. In the unlikely event of a research panel devolving into a Situation, they had the rings.

Tonks, seeing that Dracoâ€™s reports had become rather rote and that the Granger assignment was taking up only a little of his time, gleefully piled on additional missions. The cruel reward for competence was More Work and Draco wondered whether Potter and Weasel and their general bumbling wasn't the better plan, after all.

And so, Draco found himself bunking with Buckley in a dingy hotel in Manchester, where they were gathering intelligence on a group of Dark artefact smugglers.

Buckley was a good sort. He was a newish Auror, over-eager and keen to prove himself, which meant that Draco could take on a more â€“ well, he would call it managerial â€“ role, and delegate the majority of his surveillance shifts to the lad. This would, as Draco nobly explained to Buckley, permit him to garner more hands-on experience. Buckley nodded with enthusiasm and put Draco in mind of a puppy.

He thus foisted off the three A.M. watch onto his zealous young colleague and went to bed.

Draco felt as though he had just fallen asleep when his ring burnt him awake: pain and an elevated heart rate, reverberating from Cambridgeshire.

It was half four. Nothing good ever happened at half four. Draco leapt out of bed and pulled his cloak over his pyjamas.

He was too far across the country for a direct Apparition to Granger. He blasted a fire into the hotel foyer's dusty grate and Flooed to a Cambridge pub, and from there Apparated to Grangerâ€™s ring.

Draco materialised in Grangerâ€™s spare bedroom, the one he called the ritual room.

Granger was contorted into a dreadful, sweaty knot on the floor. Draco cast a flurry of Homenum Revelio and Finite Incantatem, looking for the invisible assailant who was obviously castingÂ Crucio on her.

â€œMalfoy?â€ came Grangerâ€™s strangled voice from the floor.

Dracoâ€™s revelation spells showed absolutely nothing.

â€œWhat the bloody hell are you doing?â€ asked Draco.

Granger collapsed out of the horrid tangle and found her knees. â€œYoga. What the bloody hell are you doing?â€

Draco had seen this mysterious term on Grangerâ€™s schedule. â€œThatâ€™s yoga? What kind of self-inflicted martyrdomâ€“?â€

Now that he had ascertained that there was no immediate threat, Draco could take in the scene. There were candles flickering in a corner and soft music was playing. Granger was outfitted in those ridiculously form-fitting Muggle clothes, khaki green this time. Her hair was pulled into a French braid, thick as Dracoâ€™s wrist.

Granger was looking at him like he was an absolute bellend. â€œI was trying a Taraksvasanaâ€“â€

â€œA what?â€

â€œA scorpion handstand â€“ Iâ€™ve been working towards it for weeks, and I almost had it, until you came in like a bolt from the blue and frightened me out of my wits!â€

Draco was feeling increasingly foolish. He pulled his cloak closed to cover his pyjamas. There was little he could do about his bare feet. â€œWhat, pray, is the point of yoga?â€

â€œFlexibility. Strength. Balance. Finding serenity.â€

Draco eyed Granger with cynicism at the last bit. â€œHave you found it?â€

â€œNo,â€ said Granger. She got to her feet with evident irritation. â€œKindly recalibrate your ring so you only show up in a real crisis.â€

She flicked the Elektik lights on. Her cheeks were flushed. A trickle of perspiration was running down her neck. Her chest still heaved from her exertion. Draco could smell salt, female sweat, and the burnt wick of a candle.

His idiot brain took this image and immediately created several new neural pathways that had never existed previously, connecting the idea of Granger with the concept of sexy.

It was an extremely unwelcome development and Draco wondered whether he should lobotomise himself on the spot.

A gravelly meow interrupted his thoughts. The bandy-legged cat had wandered in. It trotted up to Granger and then, upon noticing Draco, favoured him with a hiss.

Draco did not hiss back, but it was a near thing.

â€œIâ€™ll just leave then, shall I?â€ said Draco.

â€œDo,â€ said Granger. â€œGoodbye.â€

Draco Disapparated out.

~

Draco had expected (and rather desired) nothing but annoyed silence from Granger after heâ€™d barged in on her like an unhinged maniac. However, he was surprised to receive a message from her the next day â€“ and not just a message, a bona fide apology.

Malfoy: Iâ€™m sorry about my behaviour yesterday. I shouldâ€™ve been more appreciative that you arrived so fast when you thought something was the matter. Will warn you next time I try a Taraksvasana. -Hermione

Apologies werenâ€™t part of Dracoâ€™s natural lexicon. His upbringing, both at home and at school, didnâ€™t encourage the practise. Sorry was an admission of wrongdoing, a sign of guilt, an obvious weakness.

There was something nice about receiving one, however. It warmed the soul, really. He wasn't sure which part he liked the most â€“ Granger mulling this over for a day and then apologising, or Granger admitting sheâ€™d been wrong, or Granger appreciating him.

Instead of dismissing her note from the Jotter, Draco saved it in one of the back pages. Heâ€™d have to ask Potter how rare Granger apologies were, and whether he ought to have it framed.

â€œDraco, darling, youâ€™re distracted.â€

His motherâ€™s voice, with an undertone of reproach, called him back to reality.

Reality was an unfortunate place â€“ tea in the stuffiest parlour at the Manor, with his mother, her friend Madame Delphine Delacroix, and Madame Delacroixâ€™s daughter.

Todayâ€™s debutante was Rosalie Delacroix. Beauxbatons educated, Pure-blood, objectively beautiful.

Draco put the Jotter away. â€œPardonnez-moi, mesdames. Que disiez-vous?"

â€œVous avez un Jabbering Jotter!â€ exclaimed Rosalie. â€œThose have only just begun to cross the Channel to us in France. We canâ€™t get enough of them. Even my mother, who is so traditional, adores hers.â€

â€œIndeed,â€ nodded Madame Delacroix. â€œI couldnâ€™t get my husband to reply to an owl, not for love nor money â€“ but these make it so easy. A true innovation. England should be proud of these â€“ Weasleys, was it? These FrÃ¨res Belette?â€

When the conversation drifted away from him, Draco sent a response to Granger: Do advise of future scorpion pushups. P.S. Apologies from you may become my new drug of choice. -D

Draco looked up, a vague smile on his face, to find Rosalie chattering about an upcoming gala that her father was going to host. Draco had missed the beginning of it. In support of orphans, or something, probably.

â€œWe would be so delighted to see the two of you there,â€ said Rosalie, her hands clasped into a knot of entreaty. â€œItâ€™s such a good cause. They helped Father so very much, you know.â€

The orphans helped Augustin Delacroix? Draco didnâ€™t care enough to seek clarification. His Jotter buzzed. He checked it under the table to see a note from Granger: You do realise that Iâ€™d have to do bad things that warrant apologising for.

You do a great deal of bad things. Iâ€™ve compiled quite a list of your illicit activities, responded Draco.

â€œ...Quâ€™en pensez-vous, Draco? Would that suit you?â€

Draco raised his head. Madame Delacroix had asked him a question that heâ€™d only partially heard, something about his schedule in March. He answered in the affirmative â€“ of course, yes, heâ€™d be happy to clear his calendar for such a noble cause. His mother beamed at his easy acceptance and indicated that she, too, would be delighted to come.

Granger answered, If only illegal extension charms were the worst of my sins.

No, responded Draco, I know the real extent of your depravity.

She anticipated him. I see that the library visit will haunt me.

Draco grinned into his teacup. His mother saw the smile and, encouraged by what seemed like his good mood, asked the ladies if theyâ€™d like to see the gardens. Rosalie declined, claiming to have caught a bit of a chill. Madame Delacroix and Narcissa left for the gardens.

Draco sobered up as he found himself in a forced tÃªte-Ã -tÃªte with Rosalie.

The pretty witch spoke charmingly of anything she thought might catch his attention â€“ Quidditch, his job, the weather. Draco listened with only one ear, because it wasnâ€™t about hags wanting to use his skull as a sippy cup and it was therefore rather dull.

He found himself wishing to be continuing a conversation with another witch, one whose newest message had just buzzed in his pocket.

The talk turned to mutual friends, to upcoming dinners, to other frivolities. Rosalie agreed enthusiastically with every point Draco made, no matter how inane, instead of whipping counter-arguments back at him. She laughed at his mildest jokes instead of retorting with something snappy. She clung to his every word â€“ uncritical, eager â€“ instead of challenging him. She complimented him to excess.

It made for rather weak conversation.

When Draco realised who he had unconsciously made into Rosalieâ€™s foil, he was taken aback. Since when had Granger become the yardstick by which he measured female company?

The conversation â€“ such as it was â€“ lasted twenty minutes. Eventually, Rosalie convinced Draco to add a page to his Jotter for her, under the pretext of sending more details for the gala. Draco shrugged in absent-minded agreement. (It was a careless moment he would later regret, as Rosalie was a proficient Jotter and wrote to him incessantly thereafter.)

The ladies returned from their tour. Smiles were smiled, goodbyes were said, and Draco sighed in relief when Henriette the house-elf escorted their visitors back to the Floo parlour.

Later that night, Narcissa drifted into Dracoâ€™s study to probe. â€œRosalie is a sweet girl, isnâ€™t she? You seemed like you were getting along.â€

There was such a quiet optimism in her voice, Draco wondered if it wouldnâ€™t be kinder to lie. But that would give his mother hopes, and dashing them later would be all the crueller.

â€œI suppose we got along well enough,â€ he said.

She detected the lack of enthusiasm immediately. â€œBut?â€

â€œRather a milquetoast kind of girl.â€

Narcissaâ€™s thin hands clutched before her in disappointment. â€œOh.â€

Quarrelling with his pale, sad mother was never high on Dracoâ€™s to-do list. He tried to be gentle as he admonished her. â€œWeâ€™ve had this conversation before. I donâ€™t need, nor want, you to hand-pick witches for me.â€

â€œI only want to help you.â€ Narcissa's thin fingers clasped at each other. â€œI want you to find someone who is educated, and lovely, and who will be a devoted companion, and give you children, and fill this great empty house with laughter again. Rosalie would be all those things. Any number of the witches Iâ€™ve introduced you to would be all these things.â€ She paused, then added, â€œI only want you to be happy, Draco.â€

â€œI am happy.â€

Another sigh from Narcissa. â€œAt your age, your father was married, you know â€“ and had you â€“ you were four or five by then...â€

â€œI am not my father.â€

Narcissa, seeing that she would make no further headway here, glided towards the door.

â€œI donâ€™t think she exists,â€ she said over her shoulder as she left.

â€œWho?â€

â€œThe perfect witch youâ€™re apparently waiting for.â€

~

Granger wrote to Draco about a week later, advising him that she was speaking at a Muggle conference that Thursday.

Where? he asked.

Magdalen College, Oxford, said Granger. Thurs 2-5pm. Iâ€™m on at 2.30. I doubt I shall be murdered but leave your attendance to your expert judgement.

Yes, Granger, thank you for the cheek: he would use his expert judgement.

Audience? he asked.

Muggle doctors, said Granger.

How many? asked Draco.

150, said Granger.

Dracoâ€™s eyebrows rose. He sometimes forgot quite how small the wizarding world was. There were probably less than a hundred fully fledged Healers in the entirety of the UK. Maybe three or four hundred if you included Mediwitches and other field medics.

Iâ€™ll look in, said Draco.

Spiffy prof. look please, said Granger. Donâ€™t embarrass me.

Draco didnâ€™t deign to answer her.

The day of the conference came around. Draco Apparated a small distance away from Magdalen College and walked to the auditorium Granger had specified, at the time she specified, wearing the clothing that she had specified.

Bossy sort of witch, was Granger.

The volunteer at the registration table was gently Confunded into thinking that Draco was a registered participant, and he was let in with a name badge and a programme. He took stock of the building, discreetly casting revelation spells when Muggles werenâ€™t looking. The foyer, cloak room, and toilets were free of any naughtiness, as were the back rooms. The handful of people he covertly cast Legilimency on were who they were meant to be â€“ brainy Muggles, here to become even more brainy.

Draco found a shadowy alcove near the front of the auditorium from which to survey the place. He was about twenty metres away from the stage, from which vantage he could see Granger seated at a long table, along with three of her fellow experts. They were chatting amongst themselves as the crowd filed into the auditorium.

From a risk assessment standpoint, Granger couldnâ€™t have been more exposed, sitting as she was under a literal spotlight. Draco pried through the minds of the people in the front row and found nothing but eagerness to begin and high levels of admiration directed towards the doctors on the stage. Then he peeked through the minds of the unseated people idling on the stairs at the edge of the auditorium, as he was, and found only volunteers, students sneaking in, and a bearded gentleman wearing large ear-coverings, whose chief role seemed to be managing blinky boxes with wires coming out. There wasnâ€™t a single witch or wizard present, as far as he could tell.

Satisfied that there were no immediate threats, Draco cast precautionary wards across the front of the stage and settled into his alcove. As the conference began, he flipped open the programme. It informed him that todayâ€™s panel would feature international leaders in immune cell engineering and immunotherapy.

This told Draco very little, of course. Cancer was a decidedly Muggle ailment. Wizarding folk were rarely afflicted with it, and when they were, it was quickly resolved. However, it seemed that this was not the case with Muggles, for whom it was a serious condition, and nigh incurable in some forms.

Enter Granger and her cohort of fellow brains. Their talks today included such thrilling questions as FL and CLL: A New Care Paradigm and Hodgkinâ€™s Lymphoma: Mitigating Toxicity while Preserving Cure.

Draco decided that it would be quite safe to leave Granger to her CLLâ€™s. The only threat in this room was death by obscure acronym. Just as he was about to leave â€“ he rather fancied a nap â€“ the mediator announced that Dr. Grangerâ€™s presentation was next.

Draco watched her walk across the stage and decided to stay.

She was a small figure on the stage, by far the shortest amongst the panellists. She smiled at the audience as she approached the Muggle voice-amplification device on the podium. Her movements were confident and poised. She didnâ€™t have notes, but the large screens behind her projected diagrams and bullet points.

She made a few opening remarks that included a joke that went completely over Dracoâ€™s head, but the auditorium filled with laughter. Her presentation focused on the advancements of something called CAR T cell therapies in B-cell malignancies. She made eye contact with everyone, took questions throughout, was challenged, counter-challenged the challengers, and defended her position without skipping a beat.

She was confident, she was clever, and in this room, she was important.

Granger in her element was a rather impressive thing.

After finishing her presentation, Granger returned to the table and her fellow panellists discussed her talk. At some point, Draco wasnâ€™t even certain that Granger and her interlocutors were even speaking English anymore, as they cross-examined each other on EBV and TNK-cell lymphomas and their diagnostic challenges, and the architecture of liquid biopsy research. Granger made a pun about MALT1 degradation which was, apparently, uproariously funny.

Draco entertained himself by performing Legilimency on the panellists. Not a single one thought that Granger was an insufferable swot. He found only respect, admiration, and a surprise crush from the male doctor on her left.

Draco learned that something called quantitative radiomics analytics existed. Their predictive values were discussed at length. These Muggle doctors were another thing entirely, brilliantly working through the impossible, dedicating their entire lives to it. How had he ever thought Muggles base and ignorant? Draco shook his head.

Granger mustâ€™ve caught the movement of his white-blond hair in the shadows. When saw that it was Draco, she gave him a brief smile of acknowledgement â€“ bizarre feeling, that â€“ and carried on with her current dissertation, her hands making wide arcs as she explained something.

At length, conclusions were drawn, closing remarks were made, and the conference ended with much applause. The participants milled about, with Granger and the panel at the centre of the crowd.

Draco, feeling rather mushy in the brain from all the new words and Legilimency he had performed (perhaps the Keeper wouldnâ€™t need such a thick straw after all), decided that he was no longer needed here.

He made for the exit, but Granger caught him as he passed the stage.

As usual, small talk was dispensed with. Instead, he found his Muggle disguise being assessed by her, her gaze accented by a raised eyebrow.

â€œPassable,â€ was the pronouncement on the outfit.

â€œWhy the eyebrow?â€ asked Draco.

Granger pointed at the name tag that the Confunded volunteer had affixed to Dracoâ€™s lapel.Â â€œHello, Professor Takahashi.â€

â€œAh,â€ said Draco. â€œYes. Thatâ€™s me.â€

â€œAnd how is Tokyo at this time of year?â€

â€œVery nice,â€ said Draco.

â€œProfessor Takahashi is from Kyoto,â€ said Granger. Her arms were crossed, but there was amusement in her eyes. â€œRather ballsy to pose as one of Japanâ€™s most renowned clinical oncologists.â€

â€œI am nothing if not ballsy,â€ said Draco, flipping his hair. â€œDid you know that the good Dr. Driessen fancies you?â€

Now Grangerâ€™s second eyebrow joined the first, at her hairline. â€œWhat?â€

â€œHeâ€™s going to ask you out for drinks tonight.â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œYes. He also liked the skirt,â€ said Draco, gesturing to the high-waisted, close-fitting garment in question. (He also quite liked it, incidentally; Muggle fashion and its emphasis on bums was growing on him.)

â€œUgh â€“ I mean, heâ€™s very nice, but â€“ wait â€“ how do you know this?â€ Grangerâ€™s hand flew to her mouth. â€œYou did not perform Legilimency on innocent Muggles.â€

â€œPart of my risk assessment protocol.â€

â€œIs that allowed? Bit of a violation of privacy, isnâ€™t it?â€

â€œAurors have privileges,â€ said Draco. â€œAnyway, Shacklebolt gave me carte blanche to use whatever means necessary to keep you safe. Except for murder â€“ Iâ€™ve got to get permission for that. Thereâ€™s a form and everything.â€

Granger seemed ninety percent sure he was joking, but she was nevertheless eyeing him like he was the most unprincipled, depraved Auror ever produced by the Ministry, and it was just her luck that sheâ€™d been saddled with him.

Dr. Driessen popped by and, to Grangerâ€™s evident dismay, asked her if sheâ€™d join him for drinks that night. Draco appreciated the guts, if not the subtlety of the approach.

A few things happened very quickly. Granger moved to Dracoâ€™s side, her hand found his chest in a gesture of affection, which conveniently hid his ridiculous nametag, and she announced that, unfortunately, she was already spoken for that night, but perhaps another time?

Dr. Driessen looked up at Draco, at his hair (perfect), his jawline (also perfect), his eyes (perfect, and icy, and perfect) and decided that he was quite outranked.

Smart man.

â€œOf course,â€ he said, backing off and looking flustered. â€œSo sorry â€“ I didnâ€™t realise. Where are you two going?â€

â€œErâ€“â€ said Granger.

â€œThe Turf Tavern,â€ supplied Draco.

â€œClassic!â€ said Dr. Driessen. Then, with a wag of his eyebrows to Draco, he said, â€œJust across from the Bodleian. Youâ€™ll have to keep Hermione on a tight leash.â€

â€œOh yes,â€ said Draco, wrapping his arm around Grangerâ€™s waist. â€œI always do.â€

He felt Grangerâ€™s hand on his chest twitch.

â€œWell â€“ lovely to see you, as always, Hermione,â€ said Dr. Driessen.

â€œGoodbye, Johann,â€ said Granger with a rather fixed smile.

Granger was tense as the man walked away â€“ her body felt coiled and ready to leap away from Draco.

â€œDonâ€™t jump away like youâ€™ve been burnt,â€ muttered Draco. â€œHeâ€™s watching. Act natural.â€

Granger cleared her throat and let her hand slide down Dracoâ€™s chest, taking the nametag with it. She stepped away from him slowly and tried to make it look natural. (It did not.)

Draco himself vacillated between amusement at her discomfiture and alarm at how nice the curve of her hip had felt against him, and how good she smelled (again).

Granger peeled the Japanese professorâ€™s name off her palm. She looked discombobulated, which mirrored Dracoâ€™s sentiments nicely.

â€œSorry,â€ she said. â€œI had to come up with something, and you were conveniently â€“ there.â€

â€œUse me as a prop anytime,â€ said Draco, scanning the crowd instead of looking at her.

Granger was accosted by other colleagues, who had heard that she was going to the Turf, and they were going too, so theyâ€™d see her tonight, and her first G&T was on them, pip pip, etc.! Granger smiled faintly and waved them off.

â€œThis may have been a mistake,â€ was her sombre conclusion. â€œYou can leave. Iâ€™ll make up an excuse for you.â€

This was a fine suggestion, except for one small problem: upon a meticulous reflection lasting eight seconds, Draco had decided that he rather wanted to go.

â€œBut I want a G&T,â€ said Draco.

Granger was still muttering to herself and not listening. â€œIâ€™ll tell them you felt sick, or something.â€

â€œSick? Iâ€™m the picture of health.â€

â€œIâ€™ll say you ate something funny.â€Â 

â€œI think not. There are hundreds of Muggle doctors here â€“ if I say Iâ€™m sick, theyâ€™ll all descend on me and try to cure me. I donâ€™t want anyone sticking a stethoscope up my bum.â€

â€œNo one sticks stethoscopes up anyoneâ€™s bums,â€ said Granger in loud exasperation.

Two conference participants who had been passing by gave Granger a shocked look.

Granger watched them go, aghast.

â€œOops,â€ said Draco.

Grangerâ€™s jaw was tight. â€œYou are positively the worst.â€

She turned and walked briskly away.

Draco found himself grinning.

And, speaking of bums, let it be known that Draco absolutely did not check hers out, nor did he find the view pleasing at all, nor did he slow down on purpose to watch her.

Separately, with no connection whatsoever to Granger's bum, Draco concluded that robes were overrated.

The Turf Tavern was a stupidly busy place, especially so when the conference had disgorged hundreds of thirsty participants into Oxfordâ€™s streets. Draco found a table while Granger got them drinks (G&Ts all around) and they found themselves crammed on a bench amongst a dozen of the finest immunologists and oncologists in the world, getting progressively more drunk.

Draco was asked what he did for a living. Granger had gone rather worried-looking when the question was posed (tch â€“ had she no faith?) but Draco had a well-practised cover story at the ready. Tonks insisted on every Auror developing a few Muggle biographies, and some backup wizarding ones, and she quizzed them on their covers routinely to keep them on their toes.

Draco shared his favourite. This evening, he was a pilot. Few Muggles knew very much about the technicalities of flying, so, unless he encountered a real pilot â€“ unlikely, surrounded by tipsy doctors â€“ he was safe. And, of course, he had a genuine passion for wizarding flying, which lent a certain veracity to his tales of aeroplane heroics.

â€œFlying isnâ€™t that hard, you know,â€ he said to the table. â€œKeep the blue side up.â€

Laughter. The doctor beside him indicated that such simple principles applied in medicine, too: keep the guts in. More laughter.

Draco caught a wonder-filled glance from Granger, a mixture of pleasant surprise, and who the fuck are you. He twitched an eyebrow at her. She looked away, nonplussed.

When asked when heâ€™d arrived in Oxford, Draco said, â€œThis morning.â€ When asked what he was doing in Oxford, he said â€œDoctor Granger.â€

Granger choked on her drink. More laughter. When Draco next stole a glance at her, Granger looked like she was going to lure him into a lonely alley and, there in the darkness, strangle him.

Who knew that teasing the swot of the century could be such a glee-filled activity.

Someone else joined their table to raucous cries of welcome â€“ the real Professor Takahashi. Granger shuffled closer to Draco along the bench to make room.

Draco bent over and whispered, â€œAsk him if he had any troubles with his registration.â€

Granger kicked him.

She spoke politely with the professor â€“ Draco heard snippets of their conversation about Kyoto â€“ but his focus kept drifting to the feeling of Grangerâ€™s shoulder pressing into his arm, and her leg touching his under the table.

A waiter arrived bearing more food and drink. Someone had ordered an enormous platter of cheese toasties â€“ oily, salty, and served with onion chutney. Narcissa Malfoy wouldâ€™ve had a heart attack just looking at the greasy things, oozing with three different kinds of cheese.

Granger passed Draco the platter in an ambivalent kind of way, as though she expected him to turn his nose up at Muggle pub food.

Draco took one. It was the best filth heâ€™d ever eaten.

Someone, somewhere, rang a triangular instrument, and called for those who wanted to join tonightâ€™s pub quiz to form teams.

Some of the doctors at the table took this as a sign to depart. Others appeared amused at the timing, and eager to join in.

â€œI love pub quizzes,â€ said the grey-haired woman on Dracoâ€™s right. â€œHalf the fun is learning youâ€™re a colossal moron.â€

â€œBet we get trounced by some freshers,â€ said the doctor across from him.

â€œNonsense,â€ said a third. â€œWith Hermione here, this'll be a doddle. You are staying, arenâ€™t you, Hermione?â€

Granger glanced at Draco. â€œWhat do you think? If youâ€™re tired, you can go back to â€“ back to our hotel.â€

Draco appreciated the attempt at providing him an escape, but he didnâ€™t take it. He had rather an excellent buzz going, and he wanted to try this pub quiz thing, and there was the warmth of a woman at his side, and it was all rather nice. â€œPish tosh â€“ of course Iâ€™ll be staying.â€

There were cries of â€œBrilliant!â€ and then there was a general kerfuffle as everyone looked for paper and pens.

Draco was of absolutely no use for the first handful of questions, which focused on Muggle politics and sports. However, he did know how many keys a baby grand piano has (88), and what year Cessna was founded (1927), and which countryâ€™s national anthem had 158 verses (Greece; all 158 had been sung at the last Quidditch World Cup).

There were a few biology and science questions which the doctors hammered into the ground with an unnecessary level of detail. Draco learned that Picolax was used for something called colonoscopy preparation; one of the doctors nodded grimly and said, â€œNight of a thousand waterfalls,â€ and Draco was too frightened to ask for clarification. Then they quibbled with the host over the definition of â€œsubcutaneousâ€ and quite intimidated the poor lad until he gave them the point.

The history and art questions wouldâ€™ve sideswiped the whole team, but for Granger, who pulled them through. Then â€“ to general groaning â€“ they were hit by mathematics exercises, and the team of youngsters beside them whizzed through the lot and left the doctors sweating in the dust.

â€œEngineers,â€ said one of the doctors. â€œWe never stood a chance.â€

Granger, still stuck on a problem, looked vexed.

Then geography, then music, then zoology, which Granger was solidly capable of handling with occasional assistance from her colleagues. Draco didnâ€™t even attempt to help; he was on his fourth drink, and working out what monotreme meant was too deep a philosophy for him to pursue at the moment.

In the end, their team won â€“ largely thanks to Granger.

â€œWeâ€™ll have Hermione registered with English Heritage as a national treasure,â€ said one of the doctors, giving Granger a pat on the shoulder.

Granger smiled, but her gaze quickly returned to the maths problem that had tripped her up, scrawled out on a napkin.

The winning team received vouchers with some kind of monetary value. The doctors handed over theirs to the young engineers who had come in second, saying it hadnâ€™t been a fair fight, since their combined years at uni were greater than the poor engineersâ€™ years alive in the first place.

The evening wound down. The place grew quieter as most of the crowd left after the quiz, except for Draco, who was rather enjoying the drinks, and Granger, who was still working on the maths thing.

Eventually, she poked one of the youths at the table next door and asked for an explanation.

â€œItâ€™s Borelâ€™s paradox,â€ said the boy.

â€œOh!â€ said Granger. â€œObviouslyâ€¦â€

The mystery was unlocked and she scribbled out the solution on her napkin. Then she threw down her pen with finality and stood up.

â€œLetâ€™s go,â€ she said.

Draco rose to his feet with care, waiting to see how much the drinks were going to catch up with him. It wasnâ€™t too bad, considering. The cheese toasties turned out to be rather absorbent.

â€œHave a nice night, you two,â€ said the barkeep with a wink at Granger.

Granger gave him a rather sickly smile and all but ran for the door.

Outside, neither of them was quite walking with their usual level of booze-free confidence, though Granger was certainly getting on better than Draco. At one point, she pulled him to her, just as he had been about to collide into a lamp post.

â€œYouâ€™re meant to be watching over me,â€ she said. â€œNot the other way round.â€

â€œThat pole came out of bloody nowhere,â€ said Draco into Grangerâ€™s hair.

She stepped away from him until he was firmly at armâ€™s length. â€œHow are you getting home? And donâ€™t say Apparition. Iâ€™ll Stun you if you try.â€

Draco was quite certain that, even in his giggly state, heâ€™d be quicker on the draw than her, but, nevertheless. â€œFloo, I sâ€™pose.â€

â€œThereâ€™s a connected hearth at my hotel. This way.â€

Draco followed her through Oxfordâ€™s storied streets. The booze was settling and the philosophy began to flow. He felt generous and at ease with the world. â€œThose Muggles today â€“ they were all rather clever.â€

â€œYes,â€ said Granger.

â€œYouâ€™re rather clever. With all the â€“ the diagrams, and the malts, and carts, and things,â€ said Draco. It felt important that she know this.

She gave him a sideways glance in the dark. â€œThank you. And please stop, youâ€™re frightening when youâ€™re nice.â€

â€œIâ€™m frightening?â€

â€œGo back to making fun of my hair.â€

â€œFine. Itâ€™s horrid. You should shave it off.â€

â€œBetter,â€ said Granger.

â€œDonâ€™t actually, though,â€ said Draco.

â€œAre you sure?â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œHere we are,â€ said Granger. She pushed open the door of a small wizarding inn. The reception desk was empty and the fire in the hearth was low.

Granger waved her wand at the embers and they blazed back to life as though sheâ€™d cast a full Incendio.

â€œAre you a dab hand at fires, on top of the extension charms?â€ asked Draco in the face of this demonstration.

â€œA bit,â€ said Granger, with unconvincing false modesty.

â€œI heard you set fire to Snape in first year,â€ said Draco, â€œbut I didnâ€™t believe it.â€

â€œGood â€“ thatâ€™s utter bollocks,â€ said Granger, not meeting his eye.

â€œYouâ€™re a bad liar.â€

â€œOff you go,â€ said Granger, sidestepping the remark and gesturing him towards the fireplace. â€œIâ€™m shattered and need my bed.â€

â€œBut I want the story about setting fire to Snape,â€ said Draco.

â€œGo home, Malfoy.â€

Seeing that he was getting nowhere, Draco threw Floo powder into the fireplace. â€œYouâ€™re positively no fun. Malfoy Manor.â€

The flames glowed green. His last sight, as he looked back, was of Granger, her arms crossed, her hip cocked to one side. Her dark eyes observed him like he was a fresh maths theorem to unpuzzle.

On one hand, it flattered his ego to have intrigued the Great Brain. On the other, given her propensity for solving things, it rather frightened him. He didnâ€™t want to be solved.

â€œGood night, Malfoy.â€

Draco stepped into the fire.

Ostara; Contrariness of Granger

Dracoâ€™s next warding visit to Grangerâ€™s house was marred by what was, in retrospect, a slight lapse in judgement. As weeks had gone by and he had made little further headway on discovering the nature of her research project, his mind turned to a certain Object of Interest in her study: the tattered grimoire on the plinth. The one that she had threatened to cry about.

And so, one morning in early March, when Draco was preparing for his perennial visit to Grangerâ€™s cottage, he sent her a note indicating that heâ€™d be going into her house, if that was all right, because he hadnâ€™t warded the windows individually, and it was bothering him.

Granger acquiesced with a dry, If you really find it necessary.

Yes, he did.

Draco timed his visit to coincide with one of Grangerâ€™s lessons at Trinity, to ensure that he wouldnâ€™t be disturbed as he snooped. When he arrived, her cat â€“ perhaps sensing something nefarious afoot â€“ took up a position of power on the roof, and stared at him as he recast the outside wards.

â€œOnly doing my job, cat,â€ said Draco, making a great show of it.

The cat regarded him with cynicism.

He entered the cottage and warded the first floor windows with alacrity, then bounded upstairs to do the others. Grangerâ€™s bedroom was done first, with minimal looking about, because the cat was at the door, and watching him. Then the yoga room.Â Then, finally, he came to the study.

The grimoire was still on its plinth, open in the middle, still surrounded by the green glow of stasis charms. Draco warded the window under the watchful eye of the cat and drifted towards the tome.

The catâ€™s stare grew more penetrating.

Draco peered at the visible pages. Through the stasis charm, the words were blurred and seemed to dance. The script was laboured and heavy. It wasnâ€™t English â€“ in fact, bits of it looked French â€“ Anglo-Norman, perhaps? In that case, this was an old book â€“ five centuries, at least.

From the bits that he could understand, he was looking at an elaborate description of a landscape: a green hill under dancing bluebells, and gleaming thistle-down, and the velvet-soft leaves of Faliâ€™s Gossamer.

That was all that Draco could make out, the rest was too damaged. He remembered Grangerâ€™s moment of volubility at the Mendip Way, something about descriptions of flora giving her clues for her mysterious pursuit. None of the plants mentioned here had featured on her list, however. This must be a different site.

He dearly wanted to see the bookâ€™s cover.

He glanced at the cat. The cat all but shook its head.

â€œJust a quick look,â€ said Draco to the cat. â€œI might be able to help her, you know.â€

The cat whisked its tail in disapproval.

Draco did it anyway. Using his wand as a lever, so that he didnâ€™t touch the book at all, he lifted the cover enough to peek at the front.

It was entitled, Revelations.

The cat meowed a wrathful meow.

Draco let the cover fall back into place and left the cottage rather quickly.

~

Draco didnâ€™t know how, but Granger suspected something. First his Jotter went off with a series of messages, questioning him about whether he had touched the book. Draco denied, denied some more, and then Stunned the Jotter so it would stop buzzing.

Then Granger somehow got hold of Boethius, and used Dracoâ€™s own owl to send him increasingly heated queries. Draco sent Boethius off with a missive to a friend in Italy, which would keep him out of Grangerâ€™s hands for at least a week.

Then a Howler landed on his lap in the middle of a briefing with Tonks. It got as far as, â€œMALFOY, DID YOUâ€“â€ before Draco incinerated it.

Tonksâ€™ eyebrows rose. â€œWas that Hermione?â€

â€œYes,â€ said Draco.

â€œThat explains that,â€ said Tonks. She gestured to the Foe Glass behind her. One of the shadows looked rather familiar in form: a slender woman, a pile of curls on her head, her hands on her hips, silhouetted against the grey.

â€œI suppose sheâ€™s having violent thoughts about me by proximity to you,â€ said Tonks. â€œWhat did you do?â€

â€œNothing,â€ said Draco, which was essentially true.

Tonks stared at him for a long time, her fingers tapping against her desk. â€œI will assume that whatever you did was done in your professional capacity as an Auror, to ensure her continued protection.â€

â€œThat is always my primary objective,â€ said Draco.

Tonks gave him another long look, then turned back to his report on the Dark artefact smugglers. â€œBe careful, Malfoy.â€

Thus dismissed, Draco returned to his cubicle.

He had barely sat down when a silver otter dove at him out of nowhere. It called him a nosey prat and a bloody liar, and advised him to jump off a bridge.

Draco sent his own Patronus back with a request to Granger to kindly keep her loud otters to herself: he was working.

For a short while, that was that.

Draco kept an eye on Grangerâ€™s schedule to spot breaks in her calendar during which she might decide to come and find him in person. She did not, possibly because she was saving lives or other such tomfoolery.

That was when he noticed that another of her asterisk holidays was coming up rather soon â€“ that weekend, in fact.

So â€“ Ostara is coming up, he Jotted casually that evening.

Her response was instantaneous, if off-topic. That book was NOT yours to touch.

Where are you going at Ostara? asked Draco.

You are NOT invited, said Granger.

Donâ€™t need an invitation, said Draco.

I do not need supervision by prying nitwits, said Granger.

See you soon, said Draco.

She didnâ€™t respond.

Bit pouty, sometimes, was Granger.

~

The Not-Invited Prying Nitwit had a lovely lie-in on Saturday before getting ready to Apparate to Granger.

Frankly, after her hijinks with the Keepers of the Well, she had lost any privileges she mightâ€™ve had to make calls about whether or not she needed Auror supervision. Draco had no faith that Granger wasnâ€™t about to throw herself into a den of vampires to get her hands on some other obscure flask.

Those virtuous reasons aside, the timing of Grangerâ€™s weekend escapades continued to serve Dracoâ€™s purposes. Today, Grangerâ€™s frolic, whatever it was, coincided with one of his motherâ€™s luncheons. Draco was glad of the excuse to be away, even if his mother promised that she had no ulterior motives and that the presence of any young, eligible witches would be coincidental.

Draco Flooed to the Mitre, the usual Cambridge pub, and from there he Apparated to Grangerâ€™s ring, which brought him to her kitchen.

And, lo and behold, there was the ring, but there was no Granger.

â€œYouâ€™re bloody joking,â€ said Draco to the ring on the kitchen table.

Only the cat responded â€“ a pitiful meow at his mistressâ€™ absence.

â€œYour witch is a pain in my arse, you know that?â€

The cat curled itself into a sad orange loaf at Dracoâ€™s feet.

Draco pocketed Grangerâ€™s ring with a mutter. Then he pulled out his wand and cast his tracking charm. Good thing he made contingency plans.

In front of him glowed a map, and on that map were points of light brighter than the rest.

Grangerâ€™s old trainers remained, it seemed, in her laboratory at Trinity College. The tea mug was somewhere in this cottage. The handful of her hairpins that Draco had charmed were rather scattered â€“ some at the laboratory, some at St. Mungoâ€™s.

A single hairpin was currently gambolling through Uffington, for reasons unknown.

Reasons that Draco was rather eager to discover.

Draco Apparated to the hairpin.

â€œSurprise,â€ he said as he materialised before Granger.

She jumped a metre into the air, which was satisfying, and then swore at him, which was even more satisfying.

Draco looked around to find himself at the top of a green, wind-swept hill. It was a strange kind of formation: tall, but flat across the top. The turf below his feet was rich, green, and deliciously springy, except where it was interrupted by large splotches of chalky white. All around him undulated a lovely vista of rich pasture-lands, meandering hedgerows, and wandering sheep-paths.


Dragon Hill, where legends tell of St. George killing a dragon, whose blood burned the turf to bone-white chalkiness where it ran. (photo: nationaltrust.org.uk)

Now Draco turned his attention to Granger herself, who was all kitted up in her Muggle walking gear. Her hair was in a high ponytail, which lent her a sporty kind of air over her usual scholarly bun. Her nose was pinkened by the March wind.

Her brow, of course, was marred by a frown.

â€œHow the bloody hell are you here?â€ asked Granger.

â€œWhere are we?â€ asked Draco.

â€œHow did you find me?â€Â 

â€œWhatâ€™s in your anorak?â€ asked Draco, because it looked suspiciously puffy.

Granger zipped the anorak a little tighter. Her bright eyes grew dull with a sudden veil of Occlusion. â€œNothing. There â€“ Iâ€™ve answered one of your questions, now you answer mine.â€

â€œThat was a lie, though.â€Â 

â€œWell, thatâ€™s all youâ€™re getting from me,â€ said Granger. She began to make her way down the hill and away from Draco. â€œI donâ€™t want to speak to you.â€

â€œDon't you? Because you exploded my Jotter, commandeered my owl, and then sent me a Howler and an angry otter. Oi â€“ where are you going?â€

â€œAway from you,â€ said Granger.

Draco was annoyed â€“ had he missed whatever sheâ€™d come here for? Her Ostara thing?

He mustâ€™ve. She was hippity-hoppiting her way away from him, looking altogether too pleased. He shouldnâ€™t have had quite such a luxurious lie-in.

â€œGranger! Get back here. Weâ€™re not done,â€ said Draco, hippity-hoppiting behind her down the hill.

â€œIâ€™m done here,â€ said Granger with an exaggerated lightness of spirit. â€œI wouldnâ€™t know about you.â€

â€œYou need to wear the bloody ring,â€ called Draco to Grangerâ€™s bouncing ponytail.

She clambered on, ignoring him. Then, without an iota of warning, she bent over. Draco narrowly avoided ramming into her with what would have been full pelvic contact.

Yes, Tonks. She broke her neck falling down a hill. I thrusted into her too hard. Yes, it was an accident. Yes, sheâ€™s dead. Please return my body to my mother in the fewest pieces possible.

â€œWhatâ€™s this?â€ she asked.

â€œSpecifically, gossamer. Do you know what kind of gossamer?â€

â€œFaliâ€™s. Itâ€™s Faliâ€™s Gossamer.â€

â€œGood for Fali.â€

â€œBut you knew that, because you read the book.â€ Grangerâ€™s faÃ§ade was cracking. She looked slightly manic under it.

Granger, who had turned to continue her descent, whipped back around. Her ponytail slapped Draco in the face, a severe injury for which she did not even remotely apologise.

â€œD'you know what else wasnâ€™t in our agreement? You breaching my trust and touching my things!â€

Ah, there it was: the shrieking.

â€œI didnâ€™t do anything to your book.â€

â€œYou werenâ€™t to touch it in the first place! That book is beyond price!â€

â€œNo. Iâ€™m through with your surveillance device.â€

â€œFine,â€ called Draco to her retreating back. â€œIâ€™ll tell Shacklebolt that Iâ€™m through and heâ€™ll have you actually put under surveillance. Granger stopped. She made a strangled noise.

Draco took that as agreement.

He stomped towards her.

â€œHand,â€ he said.

Granger stuck out her hand.

Draco grabbed it roughly. He wanted to put the ring on equally roughly, to show her how cross he was, but he didnâ€™t, out of fear of breaking her finger. There was a moment of blessed shriek-free silence while he slipped the ring back on.

â€œOh!â€ came a voice.

Some Muggle walkers had just popped around the side of the hill.

Cries of delight followed: â€œAn engagement!â€ and â€œWhat a lovely couple!â€ and â€œCongratulations!â€ and â€œWhat a beautiful spot for it!â€

Anyway, Draco hadnâ€™t known that Avada Kedavra could be cast using only oneâ€™s eyes, but Granger was doing it quite competently.

Then she turned to the Muggles and made some sounds of agreement and false joy to move them along. Draco did not join in because he was dead.

The walkers eventually bimbled off, having wished them well in their wedded life and provided inane advice to Draco.

Granger was grasping her sprig of gossamer destructively. As soon as the Muggles left, she flung it at the ground and asked why this was her life?

Draco assumed that the question was rhetorical and so did not respond. He pulled out his wand and walked to where the Muggles had rounded the corner.

â€œWhat are you doing?â€ asked Granger.

â€œIâ€™m going to Obliviate them all,â€ said Draco.

â€œDonâ€™t,â€ said Granger with unexpected vehemence. â€œMemory charms are not to be used lightly.â€

â€œButâ€“â€

â€œI donâ€™t care,â€ said Draco, because he didnâ€™t. â€œI thought you cared. You just garroted me with your eyes.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t care?â€ Granger looked, for once in her life, perplexed. â€œI thought youâ€™d care.â€

â€œWhy would I care? They're Muggles.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. Never mind. Are we done here?â€

â€œAre you done here?â€

â€œYes,â€ said Granger.

â€œThen so am I,â€ said Draco.

Granger stamped off through a kissing gate to a car park.

Draco lingered long enough to watch her manoeuvre the car off the grassy verge and onto the winding country road.

She drove off without a backwards glance.

Her registration plate said CRKSHNKS.

Draco Disapparated with an irritated crack.

~

A few days later, Draco got ready for Wednesday night Quidditch, which he hosted on the Manorâ€™s well-manicured pitch.

Kitted up and ready to go, he flew towards the pitch, where the usual miscreants were waiting: Zabini, Davies, Flint, Doyle, and other old school mates, and a handful of whatever players theyâ€™d rounded up for tonightâ€™s game.

â€œOi oi,â€ waved Flint.

â€œThe Chief Toff has arrived,â€ announced Doyle.

â€œWind your neck in, Doyle, or I shall do it for you,â€ said Draco, angling his broom down to their altitude.

Doyle raised his Beaterâ€™s bat at Draco in mock threat. â€œIâ€™m more equipped to be bashing heads in.â€

â€œFive on five?â€ asked Davies, edging his broom between them and obviously eager to get started.

â€œLetâ€™s do it.â€

They played. It was after eight when they started, but the pitch was magically illuminated, and permitted a long game full of questionable rule interpretations and feats of near death. The Snitch was an elusive thing that night: neither Draco nor the opposing Seeker had much luck, and they were both subject to taunting by their teams as a result.

Midnight came around and Davies said shit, the missus was going to have his head for staying out so late. They agreed to call it a draw, given the uselessness of their Seekers and the otherwise even score, and to carry on next week, and celebrate the eventual winner with too much drink.

Pops and cracks reverberated across the pitch as the players Disapparated home, leaving Draco with the whole thing to himself.

Now he could have some fun.

He flew lazily upward in long loops, farther and farther up, until the pitch was a green rectangle far below, and the Manor was a dollâ€™s house, softly glowing in the night.

Then he angled his broom down and plummeted into a Wronski Feint. He pulled up at the last minute, barely holding in the whoop of joy that wanted to burst through his lips, and spiralled his broom back towards the black sky.

Once again, the pitch was a small green rectangle below, but Draco flew up even higher, until he fancied there mightâ€™ve been wisps of clouds between him and the earth.

He dropped again, relishing the wind on his face, the paralysing sensation of the plummet, the adrenaline bursting in his veins. It was glorious. It was freedom.

He pulled out of the dive at the last moment possible, his heart singing in his ears, his toes clipping the grass.

The soft, but distinctive, pop of an Apparition echoed across the pitch. He looked about for who it was, ready to tease Davies for running away from his wife.

But it was not Davies.

It was Granger.

Had she come to berate him about that damned book? Draco flew in low and drew his broom to a hovering halt in front of her. â€œWhat the hell are you doing here?â€

But Granger didnâ€™t look angry. She looked confused. Her wand was held aloft, sparkling green Healing sparks.

In fact, she looked as though sheâ€™d just rolled out of bed. Her hair was in a long plait rife with escaping curls. She wore Muggle shorts and a large, well-worn University of Edinburgh jumper. Her legs and feet were bare.

â€œI â€“ I felt youâ€“â€ she stammered, gazing about at her new surroundings in bewilderment. â€œYour heart rate was through the roof, and your adrenaline spiked, and it was horrid, Iâ€“â€

â€œNo, it was wicked,â€ corrected Draco, still catching his breath.

â€œâ€“I thought you were about to die!â€

â€œHang on â€“ how did you feel it? How the hell are you even here?â€

â€œThe bloody ring!â€ said Granger, waving the hand with the ring in question in his face.

â€œImpossible,â€ scoffed Draco. â€œItâ€™s only one way.â€

â€œThen how am I here, you utter crumpet?!â€

This was a fair point and Draco was forced to consider that he might have to revisit his charms. His ire rose, however, because the malfunction was most certainly her fault. â€œThe only crumpet here is the one who took off the ring when she wasnâ€™t meant to and damaged something. That spellwork is delicate.â€

Granger held her hands aloft, as though she couldnâ€™t believe the absurd turn of the conversation. â€œI didnâ€™t come here to argue about who is the bigger crumpet!â€

â€œItâ€™s you,â€ said Draco. â€œAnd since you came barreling here in your pyjamas to ascertain my wellbeing, I can confirm that Iâ€™m fine. You can go. Iâ€™m sure you have better things to do.â€

This statement of fact was, apparently, the wrong thing to say. Grangerâ€™s shriekiness increased. â€œBetter things to do? Me? O, no. My life is a lovely plinky plonky time!â€

â€œGrangerâ€“â€

â€œI love nipping down to the Quidditch pitch in the middle of the night! In March! Barefoot! To trade insults with Draco Fucking Malfoy! Positively adore it! Iâ€™ve so little to do, Iâ€™ve been thinking of taking up lawn bowling! Ships in bottlesâ€“!â€

She cut herself off, having mercifully been interrupted by something touching her neck. She flinched away. â€œWhat isâ€“â€

At the nape of her neck, glinting teasingly at Draco, was the Snitch.

Draco glided closer and plucked it away. â€œBeen looking for this bugger all night.â€

â€œWonderful. S-so glad I could help,â€ said Granger.

Her teeth were clenched â€“ but it wasnâ€™t out of anger, Draco belatedly realised â€“ it was from the cold.

She took a breath and appeared to be assembling what remained of her dignity. â€œSince youâ€™re quite all right, might you take me to the nearest Floo?â€

Why the hell did she need him to take her anywhere? Draco landed beside her, realising at last that Granger did not look well. She was white-lipped, pale, and shivering.

â€œDid you Apparate from bloody Cambridgeshire?â€ asked Draco with dawning comprehension.

â€œIt took a few s-sets,â€ said Granger through her clenched teeth. â€œI d-did a double shift at St. Mungoâ€™s this morning â€“ so between that and long-distance Apparition, I am rather drained.â€

Draco cast a warming charm on her, his irritation at the situation now giving way to anger. She had depleted herself of far too much magic on his account, the reckless idiot. â€œWhat, exactly, was the plan when you arrived to save my life with almost no magical reserves?â€

â€œI was going to put a plaster on the injury,â€ said Granger, but the sarcasm was blunted by the violent tremble that shook her shoulders. â€œS-sod off with the lecturing â€“ I wasnâ€™t thinking. I was asleep and the next thing I knew, this damned ring was screaming at me that you were about to die.â€

Draco felt that he should be touched, though his displeasure at her imprudence rather overshadowed it.

"Right. So I might've been in the middle of a duel with a gang of Dark wizards and you decided to pop along barefoot, magicless, in your jimjams. Bloody brilliant.â€

â€œIt was a reaction!â€ hissed Granger. â€œIâ€™m sorry I didnâ€™t pause to evaluate my options when I thought you were in the midst of dying! Iâ€™m a Healer; odds were strong Iâ€™d have been able to do something about your â€“ yourâ€“â€

â€œMy non-existent grievous injury. Right.â€ Draco hopped back onto his broom and drew near her. â€œGet on. Iâ€™ll fly you to the Manor. You can Floo home from there.â€

â€œNo,â€ said Granger, backing away.

Draco assumed, with no small degree of exasperation, that her objection was the flying.

â€œFine.â€ He jumped back off his broom and held out his elbow to her instead. â€œIâ€™ll Apparate us to the Manor. Letâ€™s go. You look about to faint.â€

Granger backed away again. She looked even paler. â€œNo â€“ not the Manor. Please. Apparate me to the Swan. Iâ€™ll Floo from there.â€

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong with my bloody Floo?â€ asked Draco, close to losing his patience and snatching her arm to force a Side-Along. â€œMy motherâ€™s in France this week, if thatâ€™s what youâ€™reâ€“â€

â€œNo. Itâ€™s not your mother. I just â€“ I just donâ€™t want to go back there. All right?â€

She wrapped her arms around herself. At this moment, the formidable Hermione Granger looked small, pale, and afraid.

Draco realised, horridly late, that it was his home she was objecting to. That the Manor still held the horrors of the War.

He was an idiot.

He offered his elbow again. â€œThe Swan, then.â€

She took it. Her hand was light on his arm and, against his sweat-soaked Quidditch kit, it felt cold.

They Apparated into the cloak room of the Swan, the boisterous wizarding pub that served as a waypoint for Wiltshire Floo travel. The voices of the pubâ€™s patrons rumbled cheerfully through the walls. Draco cast a Notice-Me-Not on himself and Granger, which served to avert gazes from them as they exited the cloak room and made their way to the hearth.

Draco noted that Granger was still holding his elbow â€“ in fact, she had begun to lean on him.

He tossed a handful of Floo powder into the fire and Granger gave the name of the wizarding pub nearest her cottage, the Mitre.

â€œYou haven't enough in you to Apparate home from there,â€ said Draco.

â€œMy cottage isnâ€™t on the Floo network. I was going to walk â€“ it's only a few minutes,â€ said Granger.

Draco made a sound of disbelief. â€œYouâ€™ve proven that youâ€™re an idiot once tonight, but I see youâ€™re doubling down. Iâ€™m coming with you.â€

It was evidence of the true level of Grangerâ€™s fatigue that she did not argue the point. They stepped into the hearth together and were spun and jostled along two dozen fireplaces until they were spat out at the Mitre.

Draco was quicker to find his footing than the exhausted idiot of a witch, who made a brave attempt at standing that was more of a sideways collapse into him. He snaked an arm around her waist and Apparated them to her kitchen.

An orange blur whizzed into the room as the crack of Dracoâ€™s Apparition echoed. There was an immediate meow of concern as the cat noted the sagging form of his mistress against Dracoâ€™s side.

â€œAre you still with us?â€ asked Draco, giving Granger a jostle. â€œShould I call someone? Should I take you to St. Mungoâ€™s? Say something, or I shall send my Patronus to Potter and launch a wholescale panic.â€

â€œDonâ€™t.â€ Grangerâ€™s grip on his arm tightened. â€œItâ€™s just â€“ just magical exhaustion. I spent all day Healing. The long-distance Apparitions were â€“ stupid. Give me a replenishing potion â€“ the reddish vial on the worktop, there.â€

Draco propped Granger up on a chair, where she sat back with a sigh. He floated the vial in question towards them and snapped off its waxy stopper.

â€œIâ€™m the utter crumpet,â€ said Granger, before downing the entire thing.

Draco felt that he ought to get that in writing.

The cat was winding its way about Grangerâ€™s feet with a chorus of anxious meows.

â€œI agree,â€ said Draco. â€œShe needs rest.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t understand him,â€ said Granger, dropping the empty vial onto the table with a feeble gesture. â€œStop pretending.â€

â€œHe said thereâ€™s a sofa somewhere under the mess of books in the front room that you should go lie down on.â€

â€œDo not touch those books,â€ said Granger, combative even through her faintness.

The cat made a sustained wail.

â€œBed, then. I concur,â€ said Draco.

Draco didnâ€™t give Granger a chance to object. He slipped one hand into the crook of her elbow and Apparated them both upstairs, where he deposited her onto her bed.

It was obvious, as he looked around the dim room, that Granger had indeed departed in as much of a hurry as sheâ€™d claimed to. The bed was in disarray, as though she had forgotten that she had a blanket over her when sheâ€™d leapt to her feet. The bedside lamp was askew as though sheâ€™d hit it. Her Muggle mobile device was face-down on the floor.

Draco rearranged these things with a few wand waves. The cat, which had bounded up the stairs after them, leapt onto the bed and joined Granger with a reproachful sound.

The cat settled into Grangerâ€™s armpit like a furry water bottle. Granger pulled the cover over herself with a weak hand and stroked the catâ€™s head with the other.

Draco, who had been waiting to see if the replenishing potion was having the desired effect â€“ and that Granger wasnâ€™t going to die on his account â€“ suddenly felt as though he was intruding.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ said Granger. â€œFor being â€“ complicated. About your house.â€

â€œI donâ€™t care,â€ said Draco. â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter.â€

â€œI know that the awful things that happened there are ancient history.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t need to keep excusing yourself. Go to sleep,â€ said Draco, taking a bigger step towards the door.

â€œI know itâ€™s not rational,â€ said Granger, making an irresolute gesture to the ceiling. â€œButâ€¦â€

â€œStop thinking, Granger,â€ said Draco, even though he knew that was an oxymoron of a request. He walked out of the room. â€œBye.â€

â€œIt was just to use the Floo,â€ said Granger, softly, mostly to herself, now. â€œBit pathetic, really.â€

Draco took a long step back into the room. Somehow, he couldnâ€™t let that one slide. â€œItâ€™s not pathetic to not want to revisit the place where you were tortured.â€ (He wanted to add, you idiot, but he felt that he may have maximised his quota on that front, tonight.)

Granger said, â€œMm,â€ in an absent way.

â€œItâ€™s gone?â€ asked Granger of the ceiling.

â€œYes. Itâ€™s just gardens now. Greenhouses. Flowers, medicinal herbsâ€¦â€

â€œWhat herbs?â€ asked Granger.

Why did she have to know everything in excruciating bloody detail? She was exhausting.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ said Draco. â€œMy mother donates the useful stuff to apothecaries. Go to sleep.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good.â€ Granger's voice had taken on a softer, more absent quality. The replenishing potion was knocking her out to begin its work.

â€œYes.â€

â€œIâ€™m happy that something good could come out of such aâ€¦â€

â€œSuch a terrible place?â€ supplemented Draco.

â€œYes.â€Â 

She said nothing further for a few moments. The moonlight through the window caught her face in soft light: delicate, wide-eyed, still pale. Her hair was a dark coil across the pillow, slowly unfurling.

Draco felt as though he were seeing double. In her oversized jumper, tucked up in bed, with her hands over the blanket, she looked like the girl he remembered from school. But that vision dissipated to leave him with this portrait of a lovely, tired witch, who had brought herself to the brink of total magical depletion to get to him, because she thought he was in danger.

She had done this to herself for him.

It was a peculiar sensation.

Grangerâ€™s eyelids began to drift downwards. Draco edged towards the door, intending to leave the cottage by foot before Disapparating outside as quietly as he could. She was asleep now, certainly â€“ sheâ€™d been quiet too long.

â€œMalfoy?â€

Draco muttered a curse. â€œYouâ€™re meant to be sleeping.â€

Now her words were blurred at the edges. She was drifting towards unconsciousness, but still fighting it.

â€œYour Patronus is lovely,â€ said Granger. Her eyes were closed.

â€œErâ€¦ thanks.â€

â€œWhat is it?â€

â€œGo to sleep, Granger.â€

â€œBut what is it?â€

â€œSleep.â€

â€œIs it a kind of dog?â€

â€œYes. Go to sleep."

"What kind?"

"A Borzoi.â€


Behold the Borzoi: the fierce, rare, aristocratic wolfhound of the Russian royals. Aloof, tall, and blessed with great hair. (Photo: Paul Croes)

â€œOh. The Tsars used to have those.â€

â€œThey did. Go to sleep. This isnâ€™t a pub quiz.â€

â€œHeâ€™s a rude thing, though heâ€™s pretty.â€

â€œIâ€™m leaving now,â€ said Draco.

â€œHis fur looked so softâ€¦â€

Finally, silence fell.

Now only the cat was awake, staring at Draco.

Draco noted that the yellow stare was not as hate-filled as it usually was. If anything, it seemed approving.

The Party / Orphans, Or Something

Chapter Notes

Ah, the party scene. Weâ€™ve read it a thousand times and we still love it. No trope subversion here, only maximum indulgence of a favourite fanfic moment.

March drew to a chill, damp, close, and with it came the day of the Delacroix fÃªte. Draco was reminded of the occasion when his afternoon nap was interrupted by Henriette the house-elf.

As Draco yawned with delicious languor, Henriette began to quiz him on his evening attire.

â€œThis purple would be so becoming on you, Monsieur,â€ said Henriette, holding a rich robe aloft for Dracoâ€™s inspection. â€œLike a Roman emperor, non?â€

â€œThe black robes, please,â€ said Draco.

â€œThis silver, perhaps? With your eyes, it would be so fetching...â€

â€œThe black, Henriette.â€

Undeterred, Henriette produced the black dress robes, but also a set of constellation-spangled midnight blue ones. â€œOr perhaps?â€ she asked, holding the blue ones up higher.

â€œDid my mother put you up to this?â€ asked Draco, eyeing the insistent elf.

Henrietteâ€™s large ears twitched backwards. â€œMadame suggested that you might be amenable to trying something else. Madame would like you to not look as though you were attending a funeral.â€

â€œI rather fancy looking like an undertaker. The black ones â€“ leave them on the bed.â€

â€œAs you wish, Monsieur,â€ sighed Henriette, spreading the robes onto the bed.

She curtseyed and Disapparated.

Henriette was a well-spoken, well-trained French elf, but far pushier and more opinionated than the English elves that Draco had grown accustomed to in childhood. However, his mother loved her, and Draco had to admit that her cooking was a far sight better than the stodgy fare prepared by her UK brethren.

Draco showered, perfected his hair, pulled on the hard-won black robes, perfected his hair again, and observed himself in the mirror to confirm that he was devastatingly good-looking.

He was.

Which was excellent, because tonight, Draco Malfoy was going out on the pull. It had been far too long since his last shag (some witch at Pansyâ€™s last birthday party, at his best recollection) and he had been feeling the lack of action in the past weeks.

It was time to rectify the situation. The Delacroix party would make for an excellent opportunity. There would be witches aplenty â€“ perhaps Mademoiselle Rosalie Delacroix herself, if she was interested, musedÂ Draco as he applied his cologne.

Satisfied with his toilette, Draco descended to the Floo parlour.

â€œHenriette, did my mother leave yet?â€ he called as he threw Floo powder into the hearth.

â€œOui, elle est partie,â€ said Henriette. â€œShe left about two hours ago, Monsieur. I believe she thought youâ€™d be on your way shortly after.â€

Oops, thought Draco. â€œThe Seneca,â€ he said out loud, and he stepped into the flames.

~

Draco dusted himself off on the Senecaâ€™s hearth, assisted by a pretentious-looking youth bearing a charmed feather duster.

A moment later, he found himself accosted by Theodore Nott.

â€œThereâ€™s fashionably late, and then thereâ€™s you,â€ said Theo. â€œBordering on rude, I think: itâ€™s half eight and youâ€™ve missed the speeches.â€

â€œCareless of me,â€ said Draco, straightening out his robes. â€œSummarise.â€

â€œVery pretty words about the True Magic of Gratitude, and also please give money.â€

â€œI canâ€™t believe I missed such a momentous address.â€

A sniff interrupted them. â€œAh. The usual blackguards.â€

Zabini had spotted Draco and Theo as they made their way into the crowded Rose Room, where canapes were being circulated amongst a beautiful crowd.

â€œDidnâ€™t know they let riffraff like you lot in here,â€ said Zabini. His dress robes were impeccably tailored â€“ possibly even more so than Dracoâ€™s.

He and Draco stared at each other hard, until Zabiniâ€™s face split into a broad grin. â€œGood to see you two â€“ the few, the brave, who arenâ€™t married and popping out sprogs.â€

â€œHere to join you in the eveningâ€™s debaucheries,â€ said Theo with an elegant bow. â€œWhat are our plans tonight, gentlemen? Chaos and mayhem?â€

â€œDrinks, dancing, and finding a lovely lady to cuddle with,â€ said Zabini, casting his gaze around the crowded room.

â€œWhat heâ€™s having, but more fucking and less cuddling,â€ said Draco, also observing the surrounding crowd.

â€œOho,â€ said Zabini. â€œLeave me the brunettes.â€

â€œFine,â€ said Draco, thinking vaguely of Rosalie and her ilk. â€œI fancy something blonde anyway.â€

â€œRedheads for me, then.â€ Theo relieved a waiter of three dirty martinis and passed them around. â€œDrink up â€“ theseâ€™ll put some hair on your chest. Barkeep is generous with the vodka.â€

They drank, they bantered, they drifted in and out of groups of friends and old enemies. Draco learned by the by that the eveningâ€™s event was in support of a new ward at St. Mungoâ€™s â€“ something about Delacroix Seniorâ€™s life being saved had turned his mercenary mind to more philanthropic pursuits. So, not orphans. Whatever.

The lights were dimmed and, in the centre of the room, space was cleared for a dance floor. Draco found Rosalie and attempted conversation, but Rosalie was giggly and seemed rather attached to the arm of some French Pure-blood or other whose name Draco couldnâ€™t remember. He decided that she was a lost cause and continued his cruising.

Two or three other witches that Draco was acquainted with crossed paths with him as he made his rounds. They were charming, eyelash-fluttering, and obviously willing, but he wasnâ€™t feeling the spark (or, less romantically, the remotest twitch in his trousers).

He divested himself of them one by one, distantly registering that, attractive and willing as they were, he found them clingy and bothersome more than anything else. Miss Luella Clairborne was particularly tenacious; Draco had to lie that his mother was summoning him to make his escape.

What was wrong with him? Luella wouldâ€™ve been willing to give him a quick gob job behind a curtain, probably, but that wasnâ€™t what he wanted. Nor did he want to bring her home with him. Nor did he want to have her in one of the Senecaâ€™s luxurious rooms. So what did he want, exactly? Not her, anyway. Not any of them.

To make good on his lie, Draco joined his mother amongst a circle of St. Mungoâ€™s higher-ups. Narcissa looked pointedly at Rosalieâ€™s French companion and pressed her lips together in lieu of saying, There, you see? All the good ones are snapped up and you, my son, will die alone.

Draco was fine with dying alone. At this precise moment, he simply wanted to find a witch who awakened something in him, to bed once or twice and get some of his randiness out of his system.

A slender thing in an open-backed dress kept catching his eye as he made his way around the room. She was chatting with a mixed crowd of former Hufflepuffs and upper echelon Ministry employees, but her figure kept disappearing from view as the speakers mingled. It was bloody. Fucking. Granger.

Draco wasnâ€™t certain where Granger fell on his motherâ€™s list of people to blame for Luciusâ€™ eventual decline and death in Azkaban. Nor did he know how that weighed against Narcissaâ€™s own freedom, as well as Dracoâ€™s, in which Granger had also played a part.

April came and went in a foggy drizzle. Draco saw little of Granger, whose schedule seemed even more impossibly crammed than it had been previously.

He forced an interaction â€“ a wellness check, really â€“ on a Friday evening when she, wonder of wonders, had nothing on the agenda. It seemed a convenient time to pop by and recast her cottageâ€™s wards.

It was pouring, as it was wont to do when Draco had to work out of doors. He cast the strongest rain-repellent charms in his arsenal upon his person and got to work.

The lights were on â€“ Granger was home. He could see her silhouette in the warmly lit cottage, curled on the sofa with a book. Eventually, the shape of the cat appeared at the front roomâ€™s window to observe Draco. The cat mustâ€™ve made a sound, because Grangerâ€™s figure followed soon after.

She peered outside and gave Draco a small wave, then came out to stand on the doorstep, wrapped in an overlarge Muggle jumper. Muggles still worshipped the Greek goddess of victory, apparently; Nikeâ€™s name figured in prominent letters across Grangerâ€™s chest. Her legs were clad in those Muggley leggings. Draco supposed that they had last parted on decent terms â€“ they mustâ€™ve, since her first words werenâ€™t go away.

He aimed his wand high and cast a silvery grid of light above Grangerâ€™s cottage.

â€œWhatâ€™s that one called?â€ asked Granger as the geometric filaments spread overhead. â€œItâ€™s beautiful.â€

â€œNever heard of it,â€ said Granger, watching the silvery sheen dissipate into the rainy sky.

â€œItâ€™s one of mine,â€ said Draco. â€œThereâ€™s a point of weakness at the apex of most parabolic wards. This one is like armour â€“ based on geodesic polyhedrons. Strong, but a real bugger to cast.â€

This was an understatement â€“ the thing was exhausting at this scale, over an entire dwelling, but Draco, being a prideful sort of wizard, didnâ€™t like to admit that.

He wiped at the mixture of sweat and rain that dripped down his brow and eyed Granger. He was satisfied that she was alive and that she had remembered to eat in the last week. He could make a clean report to Tonks in good conscience.

â€œBanoffee pie. I fancied some but the village bakery closed early today. And, well, I had bananas.â€

A drawer burst open and a large spoon flew towards Draco. It was adorned with cat ears.

â€œReally,â€ said Draco, as the spoon floated into his hand.

â€œThat was a novelty gift,â€ said Granger, attempting to snatch the spoon from him.

â€œNo. Iâ€™m always civilised. Letâ€™s be barbarians.â€

Granger pushed a plate into his hand regardless. He laughed when she attempted to serve a â€œpieceâ€ to him, which collapsed into a glob of cream and caramel sauce.

Draco disregarded the plate and ate directly from the pan, and Granger soon followed his heathenish ways, and they shared a heavenly mess of buttery biscuit crust, condensed milk, whipped cream, and the occasional wonky banana slice. Draco only ate three (3) cat hairs.

Draco had done a great many sinful things in his life, but demolishing a banoffee pie with Granger, with their shoulders brushing and their fingers sticky with toffee, felt so delightfully naughty, it gave him a frisson.

The Calming Draught was drunk and, finally, Granger climbed on. Her seat on the broom was tense and pinched up. Her grasp was white-knuckled through the mittens. Her eyes were closed. The Calming Draught clearly took more than a few seconds to kick in.
