Draco flew. He took them on a few low circles around the shed to get acquainted with Old Glory. The broom was a stiff old harridan, but she was doughty enough to make headway through the northern wind, encumbered with the two of them. She was steady in the air, far more so than Dracoâ€™s flighty models at home, which twitched away at the touch of a finger. For a voyage over this arm of the North Sea, Old Glory would do well. Slow and steady.

Draco informed Granger of this fact in an attempt at reassurance. A gurgle was his only response.

Given that Grangerâ€™s hands were occupied with strangling the broom, Draco cast wind-breaking spells over the two of them, so that they might hear each other talk. He also cast warming charms, which made Granger shudder gratefully against him, which felt interesting.

Dracoâ€™s final adjustment was having a passenger, which was a rare occurrence for him. The weighting felt different and the steering trended downward.

The few times heâ€™d doubled up on brooms had been for dates and those flights were succeeded by landings in a secluded location and a good snog. Draco rather doubted that there would be sexy bum wiggles against his groin on this flight: Granger clung to the broom like grim death, unmoving, as though she had been Petrified onto it. Only her hair eluded the stiffness. The few strands that escaped her bun softly touched his face. She smelled like shampoo and antiseptic.

Draco leaned forwards and put his hands on the broom in front of Granger, ready to go. She felt small and fine-boned between his arms.

â€œCosy,â€ said Draco.

â€œUrk,â€ said Granger in an eloquent verbalisation of her terror.

Draco turned them northward and began to pick up speed. Granger, eyes closed and all, felt the change, and expressed violent wishes with regard to Dracoâ€™s fate in this world and the next, which would have made a more delicate man weep.

Draco merely said, â€œSteady on, Granger,â€ and slowed them down by 0.01 percent.

â€œTo the Holm of Eynhallow, old bird,â€ said Draco, giving the broom a pat.

Next stop: the sea.

The Orkney Isles


graphic by fronchfry111

Draco had enjoyed a great many flights in his young life, but that trip across the North Sea ranked as one of the most savagely beautiful heâ€™d ever experienced. He was almost glad for the old broom â€“ it forced a level of care in his flying, and attention to the winds, that his newer brooms didn't. The flight was quite technical. The cross-winds were many, and the weather capricious, so Draco chose a low flight path about ten metres above the surge.

The air was salty and cold and splashed across their faces like kisses from ghostly mermaids. As they reached open waters, a Great Skua joined them in their flight. It observed Draco with a beady eye, its wingtip a mere metre from his face. Then it dropped to the seaâ€™s surface, skimmed wings with its dark watery double, and soared away again.

As they flew northwards, the skies cleared to reveal a fragile scatter of stars in the sky. Below them, the reflected constellations spilled and plunged into the waves. The sight was sublime. It made Draco feel small and inconsequential.

The Calming Draught mustâ€™ve kicked in, because Granger felt a hair less tense between his arms, though her mittens were still twisted hard around the broom. As far as Draco could tell, her eyes were still closed and she was missing all of these breathtaking vistas. But, he supposed, whatever got her through it.

Something big broke the water below them.

â€œGranger â€“ look! Thereâ€™s a Hippocampus! No, thereâ€™s two of them! Hippocampuses! Hippocampi?â€

â€œOh!â€ gasped Granger, finally opening her eyes.

She looked down to where the enormous, sleek heads of the horse-like creatures had split the waves. One disappeared again, but the other breached, its huge tail arcing just below them, then vanishing without a splash into the waves.

Draco slowed, wanting to turn back and observe them, but the first Hippocampus had appeared again ahead, closely followed by its mate. He urged the broom to catch up. The creatures picked up speed and Draco matched them, skimming the waves just at the height of their manes.

They raced.

Draco asked the broom for more. The majestic creatures moved below and beside them with no sign of exertion save the pearling mist that burst out of their wide nostrils.

One, slightly smaller, was sea-glass green, her mane as white as the foam cresting around her. The other was larger, blue as the sea-swells, and just as swift, keeping close to his mate.

Saltwater soaked them. Draco pressed on, and he was a wave, and the sea-horses were waves, and they flew and crashed and foamed, and they surged on, and now they were the wind, and now they were the brine, and now they were seafoam before the storm.

The wave-riders turned west towards the open ocean. Their pale eyes peered at Draco and Granger, and the male threw back his gorgeous head, as though challenging them to follow towards unknown shores. Draco knew that he could not.

The pair disappeared like swift-finned spirits, a vision fast-fading against the elusive sea.


Masterpiece by the wildly talented nikitajobson.

Then there was only Draco, breathless, and Granger, shuddering, and the cloud-foamed waves.

Neither of them spoke.

The broom resumed her course.

Now, on their left and right, there loomed the dark forms of landmasses. They had entered the Orkney Isles.

The wind grew less cutting and the seas less rough.

Ahead of them, a small island glowed like a jewel amongst the dark seas, alight with Beltane fires. The broom, sensing her destination near, put on a fresh burst of speed.

Draco spotted a flattish rock face by starlight and came in for a landing. Granger mustâ€™ve closed her eyes again, because when her toes hit the ground, she squeaked, and wouldâ€™ve tumbled off the broom but for Dracoâ€™s arm around her waist.

Draco dismounted. Grangerâ€™s activity wouldâ€™ve been more accurately described as a kind of sagging tumble into the moss.

â€œThat was brilliant!â€ Draco spun under the stars, holding his arms aloft. â€œExhilarating. Fucking magical.â€

Granger said nothing. Draco cast a Lumos at her. She appeared to be hugging the earth.

â€œYou all right?â€

â€œJust a moment,â€ gasped Granger.

Draco left her to compose herself. He cast a few spells inland, which informed him that there were about a hundred witches and wizards on the island, and almost an equal amount of fires, great and small.

Granger had regained her feet. Draco, seeing how bloodless she still looked, offered her his arm in a kind of gentlemanly automatism. She took it, her own grasp all a-tremble.

They advanced towards the centre of the island with the Beltane fires and the sound of a cheerful fiddler guiding them in. As they walked, Draco began to notice immense shapes on either side of them, only perceivable because they were a black opacity, permitting no light of the stars through them.

â€œStanding stones,â€ said Granger.

â€œThere are henges this far north?â€ asked Draco.

He didnâ€™t actually care whether or not there were henges this far north, but questions of that nature were sure to awaken the swot in Granger and distract her from her jitters.

He was right. Granger began in a weak kind of voice which gained in strength and enthusiasm as she progressed. â€œYes â€“ this is one of the oldest stone circles in the UK. The megaliths are thought to date back to about 3200 BCE. Theyâ€™re around three metres tall â€“ absolutely breathtaking in daylight, Iâ€™d imagine. This henge is called the Ring of Eynhallow.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll have missed most of the merrymaking, I think,â€ said Granger as they grew close enough to the crowd to hear voices. â€œToo bad. Iâ€™d hoped to see some of the rituals in personâ€¦â€

â€œWhich rituals?â€

â€œOh, old protection magicks. Handfastings. Offerings to the Aos sÃ­. Lots of jumping over fires and other silliness, too. I donâ€™t know why wizards think thatâ€™ll impress a witch, but then, wizards do a great deal of things I donâ€™t understand. Like viper neckties.â€

Now Granger fell silent, mulling over that particular bout of idiocy. â€œBut, well â€“ at least Iâ€™ll have got what I came here for.â€

They were near the centre of the ring now, walking amongst many peat fires and carousing witches and wizards. Granger was staring at the fires in restrained excitement. Her grasp on Dracoâ€™s arm grew tight.

As Grangerâ€™s attention was elsewhere, Draco pointed his wand at a few passersby and cast nonverbal Legilimency. He was satisfied that this was a low risk situation â€“ the general mood was festive and tipsy and no one cared who they were.

The peak of the celebration was over and things were drawing to a jolly close. Tents were being put up here and there on the periphery of the fires, while around others, groups were settling down for some whisky-fueled philosophy.

Draco and Granger were accosted by friendly merry-makers and invited to join their fires. Granger politely declined and steered them to a quieter end of the henge, where a small fire burned low.

â€œLetâ€™s wait for this one,â€ she said.

â€œI suppose it has to go out naturally?â€ asked Draco. â€œNo dousing charms?â€

â€œNo dousing charms. Beltane ash at its most primitive.â€

Granger Transfigured two stumps into cushy ottomans, which she and Draco pulled towards the fire.

After the bitterly cold flight, the heat was positively magnificent. Draco sat close, but Granger was near enough to roast her knees and set fire to her hair. She pulled off her mittens and held her hands close to the flames.

â€œOf the thousands and thousands of Beltane fires tonight, why these ones, specifically? In the most desolate corner of the UK?â€ asked Draco as his face began to thaw.

Granger had a ready answer, of course â€“ and seemed delighted that heâ€™d asked. â€œBecause the fires on this Holm are from a very specific fire â€“ the very one that Cerridwen used for her cauldron. I donâ€™t know if you remember her taleâ€¦â€

â€œOnly whatever was on her Chocolate Frog card,â€ said Draco, vaguely recollecting a witch with masses of dark hair. â€œLooked rather like you, come to think of it.â€

â€œPsh,â€ scoffed Granger. â€œI can only dream of becoming a fraction of the witch she was. She was a mistress of Transfiguration, amongst many things â€“ she could transform into any creature at will. She makes todayâ€™s Animagi look jejune. Anyway â€“ Iâ€™ll spare you the treatise â€“ you mightâ€™ve noticed that these flames look a little redder than normal fire?â€

Draco nodded; the flames were indeed ruddier than usual. â€œI assumed it was the peat.â€

â€œNo. Theyâ€™ve kept her legendary flame alive, for generation upon generation, in these islands. Isnâ€™t it incredible?â€ Grangerâ€™s eyes were bright. â€œWhat a thing to witness. What a thing to feel, on my own hands. Itâ€™s surreal. Itâ€™s extraordinary.â€

â€œWhat do you need the ash for?â€ asked Draco, since she was being so voluble.

Granger clamped her mouth shut.

Draco shrugged. It had been worth a try.

He dug into the pockets of his cloak to pull out the provisions from Thurso. He passed the cured meats and cheese to Granger and tucked the flask of mulled wine against the fire to warm up again.

Granger looked surprised, though whether it was at the foresight or the unexpected kindness, Draco wasnâ€™t certain. She tore the packet open. â€œIâ€™m actually starved. Thank you. This was so thoughtful of you, Iâ€“â€

Draco cut her off to waylay further fluff. â€œDidnâ€™t bring any Banoffee pie in that anorak?â€

â€œNo,â€ said Granger. She fished about in one of the pockets. â€œI do have a few protein bars, though. They might be a bit squishedâ€¦â€

Draco didnâ€™t know what a protein bar was, but it tasted like cheap chocolate, which was glorious on his tongue after all the sea salt.

They ate. Granger was mannerly about it, taking small bites interspersed with further commentary on Cerridwen. Draco wondered, for the first time, what her family was like, and whether they were well off Muggles? She had a sense of decorum and a kind of innate dignity that spoke of good breeding.

â€œHippocampus would be correctly pluralised as Hippocampuses, I think,â€ said Granger. â€œI think Hippocampi would be an incorrect attempt at regularising Latin â€“ Hippocampus is a Greek word. â€œIâ€™ll take your word for it,â€ said Draco, fetching the warmed mulled wine.

â€œIâ€™m not a linguist, so you shouldnâ€™t.â€

Draco proffered the flask to her.

â€œIâ€™ll make us some goblets,â€ said Granger, plucking protein bar wrappers from Dracoâ€™s lap.

â€œSo proper,â€ said Draco. His mother might actually like Granger.

â€œThis wine has been heated by the flame of Cerridwen. We arenâ€™t sucking it out of a flask like sixteen year olds behind The Hogâ€™s Head.â€

Granger Transfigured the wrappers into handsome golden goblets.

Draco wouldâ€™ve informed her that she was quite the mistress of Transfiguration herself, but he didnâ€™t want her to develop an inflated ego. She nevertheless caught the way he tested the weight of the goblets. She smiled into her scarf.

â€œNice sheen on the gold,â€ he admitted.

â€œA pretty illusion,â€ said Granger, looking pleased. â€œBut thank you.â€ She paused and hesitated before adding, â€œI heard youâ€™ve an interest in Alchemy, so your approval means more than the average wizardâ€™s.â€

â€œMy approval should mean more than the average wizardâ€™s in all things,â€ said Draco, studying the goblet in the firelight.

Granger raised her eyes to the night sky.


by the incredible RunningQuill_art

Draco filled their goblets with the mulled wine. â€œWhile we're on the subject of Alchemy â€“ youâ€™d tell me if your project involves the creation of a Panacea, wouldnâ€™t you?â€

â€œLetâ€™s not get ahead of ourselves,â€ said Granger, though she was grinning.

â€œAre you creating a Panacea?â€ he asked, leaning towards her. â€œIs that what Shackleboltâ€™s so worked up about?â€

She met his eyes without hesitation. â€œNo. Donâ€™t be ridiculous.â€

â€œHm.â€

â€œIâ€™m afraid youâ€™re developing rather too high an opinion of me. Iâ€™m a mere Healer, muddling along with my Muggle methods and paltry magical know-how.â€

â€œPaltry,â€ repeated Draco with a scoff.

â€œDâ€™you want more cheese? This oneâ€™s rather too sharp for me...â€

Draco took the cheese and mulled over his mulled wine. Perhaps it wasnâ€™t an outright Panacea that she was working on, but he rather felt the scope was similar. He had a plan to pry the information out of her, however. He simply had to be patient.

The fire crackled on, eating away at its remaining peat. They stared into it, and, as the night wore on, found themselves almost hypnotised by the dance of the flames. The fiddlerâ€™s song turned mournful and grave.

The fire, the peat smoke, the earth â€“ it smelled like history, like new becoming old, and old becoming new.

Perhaps it was the wine, perhaps the late hour, perhaps the lingering potency of Beltane night, but the moment took on a dreamlike quality to Draco. Granger became a chiaroscuro-painted vision of a witch, her windblown hair melding into the shadows behind her, her eyes catching the red firelight. Her hands were stretched to the fire and it seemed to Draco that the flames were attracted to her, and that she could have stroked them, if sheâ€™d wanted to.

Granger yawned and the spell was broken.

Her sleepiness wasnâ€™t a surprise. It was edging towards Dracoâ€™s usual bedtime, which meant that it was far past Grangerâ€™s.

She put her mittens back on and cast a warming charm around herself and Draco. The fire was low, but still burning.

Peat fires, Draco realised, took a very long time to go out.

Granger fell asleep on his shoulder.

Draco, who had himself been growing tired, suddenly found himself alert and ill at ease. This was an entirely new display of vulnerability that he wasnâ€™t prepared to deal with. Her breathing was slow and steady, her mittens curled into her lap.

Dracoâ€™s Transfiguration skills were decent, but not good enough to Transfigure a tent out of the remains of a cured meat packet. He settled for elongating Grangerâ€™s ottoman into a kind of lopsided chaise longue. She slid into the new configuration without waking.

Then, because she seemed small and even more vulnerable lying supine under the open sky, he threw his cloak over her. He topped this off with another warming charm over the two of them, since the dying fireâ€™s warmth was decidedly giving way to the nightâ€™s chill.

He cast a few wards, in case his own fatigue took over and he, too, fell dead to the world. It was most certainly excessive prudence, as the other celebrants had retreated into their tents, but Draco hadnâ€™t survived this long by being careless.

He sat with his back against Grangerâ€™s chaise longue and watched the last of the flames turn to embers.

After another hour, the edge of the pit had turned to ash. It stirred in the silent breeze, then settled, white upon white.

~

Dawn broke fresh and bright, spilling gold over the Orkney Islands under the cries of wheeling seabirds.

Draco awoke with a crick in his neck and a nose gone numb from the cold.

As for Granger, she looked perfectly comfortable, tucked up in his cloak. Draco wondered when he had become such a virtuous fucking martyr, sacrificing his own comfort for bloody Granger of all people?

He stomped off on frozen feet to take a piss.

When he returned, Granger was up and examining his Transfiguration handiwork. The chaise had held up through the night, which was a pleasant surprise to Draco, anyway.

Granger saw him coming and grew flustered. â€œYou shouldâ€™ve woken me! You didnâ€™t sign up to be my manservant on top of everything else. You made me a chaise? Itâ€™s lovely. Thank you. I had a wonderful sleep, which is terribly odd, considering. Oh â€“ and your cloak. Here. Thank you for lending it to me. Whatâ€™s it made of? Itâ€™s so warm. Youâ€™re moving terribly. Is it your neck? Can I look at it?â€

Draco took his cloak, swatted Grangerâ€™s hands away from his neck, and expressed a curt wish for a hot coffee and a prompt departure.

Granger pulled her hands back into her chest. â€œI saw someone unfurling an entire kitchenette, a few tents down. You might convince him to spare a cup. Iâ€™m going to collect my sample.â€

Draco went in search of this salvation, leaving Granger kneeling next to the fire pit, scooping ash into test tubes.

As it turned out, the kitchenette-unfurling wizard was willing to spare two cups and slightly dodgy croissants in exchange for the Sickle that Draco wordlessly offered him.

The hot coffee was worth the ridiculous premium. After the first sip, Draco felt slightly less inclined to murder everyone.

Granger annoyed him afresh by not being where he had left her. After a brief, wand-grippy search, he found her a few fires over, speaking with a couple dismantling their tent.

She forestalled his lecture with news: the ferry back to Thurso would be here in fifteen minutes. To Draco, this was merely good news, as he didnâ€™t fancy another flight in his sleep deprived state. To Granger, it was excellent news. She even asked to carry Old Glory to the dock, wanting to return the broomstick to the ferry master, and rid herself of it forever.

They wandered through the weathered standing stones to the vestigial docks. Granger was lively and bouncy and gave Draco an unasked-for history of Orkneyâ€™s Neolithic peoples, using the broom to point at areas of interest on the monoliths.

Seeing that Draco did not match her enthusiasm, she gave him her own coffee to pep him up further, and most of her croissant.

The sea breeze picked up as they neared the shore, a beautiful mix of salt and sand and new grass.

They boarded the ferry. Old Glory was reunited with her master. Draco said to keep the deposit. He and Granger had a dispute over whether or not she owed him any money, as she tried to pay him back. He shut her down by threatening to buy the broom outright and kidnapping her for further flights if she didnâ€™t leave off.

Then, as the ferry reached open waters, he kipped down on a bench for a well-deserved nap.

Granger quietly Transfigured the benchâ€™s wood top into plush velour when she thought heâ€™d fallen asleep.

~

â€œWho knew the Knob would offer such an excellent breakfast?â€ exclaimed Granger, piling scrambled eggs onto a piece of toast.

Granger looked prim and said it wasnâ€™t her fault that he interpreted innocent remarks as boorishly as possible. But she did know a handy charm for trachaeic expulsions, so he could continue to giggle about penises as he pleased â€“ she would save him from choking.

Granger finished eating far before he did, which meant that she had ample time to watch him not quite move properly, because of his neck. She began a spontaneous lecture on cervical muscle spasms, pondered the health of his spinal accessory nerve, described in detail what she would do to his sterno-cleido-mastoid, if only he would let her, and generally badgered him until he was no longer enjoying his eggs.

â€œFine,â€ snarled Draco, shrugging off his cloak and pulling his robes aside to expose his neck.

The tip of her wand found the juncture where his neck met his shoulder. â€œThat's better, isn't it? I know itâ€™s a Muggle remedy and you wonâ€™t do it, but I would recommend heat therapy if this still feels tender tomorrow. Itâ€™d help with blood flow.â€

â€œYou had a horrid night because of me, and Iâ€™m sorry,â€ said Granger.

â€œLet me eat.â€

Granger reached for the Floo powder pot at the precise moment that Draco did, resulting in a skimming of hands and immediate retraction from both parties. Then they did the idiotic thing where they insisted that the other go first for a long and annoying minute.

Draco, his patience thin, waved his wand at the pot and levitated it firmly into Grangerâ€™s chest. â€œGo.â€

â€œUgh,â€ said Granger, hugging the pot to herself before it dropped.

She pried the lid open and looked ready to fling the Floo powder into the fire and leave in a huff. However, she stopped and turned back to Draco instead.

â€œMalfoy, I â€“ I wouldnâ€™t have been able to collect my sample without you. I wouldâ€™ve had to put off my project until the next Beltane festival, if it wasnâ€™t for you being there. I would never have made that flight by myself.â€

Draco had never been one to shy away from receiving the praise that was his due â€“ in fact, he tended to bask in it â€“ but something about Grangerâ€™s guileless sincerity and gratitude made this frightfully awkward.

Plus, it was Granger. Her being nice gave him the heebie-jeebies.

Granger threw a fistful of powder into the flames. â€œOkay. Iâ€™m glad you came. Iâ€™m goingtogonowthanksagainbye. The Mitre.â€

A few minutes later, Draco was dusting soot from his cloak, in his own parlour. He was very much looking forward to a bath and bed. Henriette, who had materialised upon his arrival, was sent off to run the bath, as hot as she could make it.

His cloak still smelled like Granger and peat smoke.

He sent her the note.

Draco Malfoy, Oblivious Idiot

Chapter Notes

Earning the oblivious idiots tag pretty hard in this chapter.

The dissertation on heat therapy notwithstanding, Draco had little contact with Granger through the merry month of May. He and his fellow Aurors were kept occupied by new and exciting criminal behaviours throughout the country (a wizard who had Imperiused the entirety of a Muggle village and lived as their king; werewolves targeting infants; a theft at Gringotts; a few kidnappings for variety).

Mid-May found Draco cleaning up a messy case â€“ a potioneer in Sheffield, posing as something called a â€œlove psychic,â€ selling love potions to Muggles. Draco was in the midst of confiscating a stash and Obliviating a Muggle when his wand hummed an alarm at him. That specific alarm signaled that someone was setting off Grangerâ€™s wards. And not her office or her laboratory: her home.

Draco finished up with the Muggle briskly and Disapparated to the nearest Floo. That took him to the Mitre, followed by an Apparition to Grangerâ€™s cottage, wand out and Disillusioned.

Between his wandâ€™s alarm and his arrival, Draco estimated that three minutes had passed. But it was three minutes too late; whoever had been poking about had left. Dracoâ€™s revelation spells indicated no human presence nearby save for Grangerâ€™s Muggle next door neighbour, who was napping.

Draco cast a delicate magic detection spell. His warding around the property glowed brightly under it, but he ignored that in favour of examining the ground around Grangerâ€™s cottage. He held his wand aloft until he found what he sought: a faintly visible trace in the air, left by a being who had used magic here moments earlier.

The faintly glowing trail ended suddenly in the middle of the field behind Grangerâ€™s cottage: a Disapparition or Portkey, perhaps.

Draco did not like this. It might only have been a curious wizard, or even a thief â€“ that was the best case scenario. It might also be a first indicator that someone had their eyes on Granger and that Shackleboltâ€™s paranoia wasnâ€™t for naught.

Draco sent a quick note to Granger: Someone set off your wards. We need to talk.

When Granger didnâ€™t respond immediately, he checked her schedule. She was currently lecturing in Muggle Cambridge.

Draco decided to join her there â€“ he was essentially next door, anyway.

Iâ€™m coming to you, he wrote.

Still Disillusioned, he Apparated to Trinity College.

~

Grangerâ€™s lecture had been on the cusp of ending. Draco only had to wait for ten minutes outside the door of the small classroom. A half-dozen students filed out as he, all but invisible to Muggle eyes, slipped through them into the room.

The chalkboard indicated that the dayâ€™s topic had been â€˜Conjugated monoclonal antibodies.â€™ Draco was pleased that these antibodies knew their verb tenses, if nothing else.

Granger, unaware of his presence, was packing papers (sans wand) into a briefcase. She wore a pinstripe blouse tucked into high-waisted trousers â€“ pieces that Draco wouldnâ€™t have immediately thought of as complementary, and yet, on Granger, the ensemble was rather flattering.

As the last student filed out, Granger pulled her Jotter out of her pocket. It gave Draco a strange pleasure to watch her flip the Jotter open and grow visibly interested when she saw that it was a message from him.

She read the note and drew her eyebrows into a frown. She began to compose a response. Draco supposed that he ought to reveal himself, as the responding buzz from his own Jotter would soon give him away.

He came to stand in front of her and dismissed his Disillusionment.

Granger gave a kind of gasping shriek, jumped back, and tripped over her chair.

Draco caught her by the wrist, preventing an outright tumble. Granger landed awkwardly in the chair.

Draco leaned against the desk and said, conversationally: â€œYou know, I wish youâ€™d go for your wand and shriek out a curse rather than a scream. You saw my message?â€

Granger was not ready to talk about the message. His ring told him that her heart was racing. â€œYou've just frightened me out of my wits! How long have you been here? Warn me, next time!â€

â€œI did warn you that I was coming,â€ said Draco.

Which was true, but Granger nevertheless looked irascible. â€œI read that message a millisecond before you materialised before me like the Bloody Bollocksing Baron!â€

â€œItâ€™s not my fault you were too busy conjugating antibodies.â€

Grangerâ€™s expression shifted from cross to confused. â€œI â€“ what?â€

Draco jutted his chin towards the chalkboard.

Draco cut her off because he, frankly, wasnâ€™t interested. â€œIâ€™m here to talk about who is nosing around your cottage. And why.â€

His interruption earned him a scathing glare. However, Granger took a deep breath and seemed to quell whatever intemperate urges he had roused.

She folded her hands on the desk in a facsimile of serenity. â€œSit. And tell me what happened.â€

Draco sent a Colloportus towards the classroomâ€™s door. Then he levitated a chair towards them and sat in it across from Granger. Something about this shifted the dynamic between them. He was on the student side of the desk, feeling rather like he was about to be examined.

She crossed her arms and waited, her eyes fixed on his face. The weight of the entire attention of the great Granger brain pressed upon Draco, ready to acquire his information and make meaning of it.

â€œOne of my wards triggered an alarm round the back of your cottage,â€ said Draco. â€œSomeone was either testing the warding or attempting a disarming. â€œHow?â€ interjected Granger.

â€œObviously it wasnâ€™t just the postie. Iâ€™m alerted to magical interactions, otherwise Iâ€™d be fielding alarms whenever a robin lands on your wisteria.â€

â€œYes. But you said yourself it might very well have been a housebreaker on the prowl.â€ Even as she repeated this supposition, Granger looked sceptical.

â€œBut why your cottage, specifically?â€

â€œI donâ€™t believe in coincidence, not when youâ€™re involved.â€

â€œNeither do I.â€ Granger looked as troubled as Draco felt about the entire affair. She was bouncing one of her feet under the desk, as she was wont to do when she was irked. Again, Draco was reminded of the annoyed swish of a catâ€™s tail.

â€œIf someone leaked something, and there are people sniffing about, this situation is no longer the same as it was in January when we were taking precautionary measures. â€œI understand. And I hope there isnâ€™t another such incident. Iâ€™d rather no one know anything until Iâ€™m ready to go public. Youâ€™ll probably force me into hiding or something equally inordinate.â€

Draco regarded her seriously. â€œIf you think Iâ€™d force you into hiding, then this thing must be Big.â€

â€œItâ€™s Big. But itâ€™s also Good. But it will upset some people.â€

The urge to use Legilimency was strong. The Big and Good thing was at the forefront of Grangerâ€™s mind at the moment. She wasnâ€™t Occluding, because at some point in the past few months, she had begun to trust him.

In fact, right now, Granger was in an utterly unguarded state, her gaze openly meeting his. She awaited his retort or further questioning. He could be in her mind and see the thing before she could Occlude, and then heâ€™d know. Sheâ€™d be furious, and never trust him again, but heâ€™d know.

Draco, gripping his wand in his pocket, found that he couldnâ€™t do it. He told himself that it was because he didnâ€™t want to endure the righteously angry shrieking that would be sure to follow. And that it had nothing whatsoever to do with the weight of that new trust, with the preciousness of it.

Granger ran her hands up and down her arms as though she were cold. â€œI find this entire thing disquieting. I donâ€™t like it. I really hope it was a stupid burglar.â€

â€œIf it wasnâ€™t a stupid burglar, well â€“ the baddies now know that youâ€™re well protected.â€

â€œIs that good or bad?â€Â 

Draco shrugged. â€œBoth. Itâ€™ll tell them that you â€“ or the Ministry â€“ are aware of the risks and have taken precautions. That youâ€™re being guarded. That might scare them off. Or it might drive them to nastier manoeuvres.â€

â€œI was rather thinking the latter,â€ said Granger, concern drawing her brows together. â€œHowever, Iâ€™ve got the ring and Iâ€™ve got you. Thatâ€™s something.â€

The unasked-for earnestness there made Draco want to flee the room. Why did she have to inflict such sincerity upon him? He wanted to squirm.

â€œAnd Iâ€™m not exactly a defenceless imbecile,â€ continued Granger. â€œShrieking and falling over chairs because of you notwithstanding. â€œThere are advantages to ancient abodes,â€ said Draco. He wasnâ€™t trying to sound smug; it was true.

â€œNo,â€ said Draco. â€œBut I wasnâ€™t looking. Iâ€™m sure the buggerâ€™s fine.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t tell him you called him that,â€ said Granger. â€œHeâ€™s only just stopped hissing when I talk to him about you.â€

â€œHe likes to be kept informed. Helps him decide how much fur to make you eat.â€

â€œTell him I think heâ€™s a fine animal.â€

â€œI will.â€

â€œThe most impressive specimen of a half-Kneazle Iâ€™ve ever seen.â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œWhere on earth did you hear about those?â€

"I know. The victims are being checked in on by medis for the next fortnight.â€

â€œWell,â€ she said finally, â€œItâ€™s Amortentia.â€

â€œEr â€“ the one time in Slughornâ€™s class.â€

Dracoâ€™s own memory of his experience of the potion was vague: he recollected the smell of citrus, perhaps. This new version was rather nice. Another breath of it wafted towards him: this time it smelled like the vast sky, sea salt, and a faint trace of something clean-smelling.

â€œAmortentia is meant to smell like things you find appealing or attractive,â€ muttered Granger. â€œSo whyâ€¦?â€

Bit sarcastic, sometimes, was Granger.

They walked out of the building and into warm May sunshine. Draco, eating his soul-mate with his spoon, saw his revenge in the form of a strapping young lad cutting the lawn.

â€œLook, Granger â€“ your gardener is trimming the quad. Do you want me to talk to him for you?â€

That was when he discovered that Granger had Transfigured it into Flobberworm mucus.

â€œThat fucking witch,â€ said Draco.

The Tea Party

Dracoâ€™s Jotter sank into taciturn silence in the next few days. He assumed that Granger was pouting and that he wouldnâ€™t hear from her again until he prodded her about her next asterisk holiday.

He was therefore surprised to receive a missive from her before the week had elapsed.

Received invitation to tea from your mother. This Sunday.

Will you be nice and attend? asked Draco.

Not sure you deserve me being nice, said Granger.

Donâ€™t punish my mother because of me, said Draco. Besides, I ate Flobberworm mucus â€“ havenâ€™t I suffered enough?

Did you really eat it? asked Granger.

Yes, replied Draco.

Liar, said Granger.

Draco didnâ€™t respond, because she was right.

His Jotter buzzed again. Am only going if youâ€™ll be there. Not suffering alone.

I canâ€™t. I already fabricated a scheduling conflict for myself, said Draco.

Too bad, said Granger. Unmake it.

But thatâ€™s complicated, said Draco. He hoped that she could hear the whinge through the text.

So is attending an event at Malfoy Manor.

Draco straightened in his seat. So she was playing that card. He supposed he hadnâ€™t a choice, then. Understood. I will be there.

She didnâ€™t respond.

~

Sunday came around and with it the usual flurry of preparations that preceded Narcissa's functions. Draco remained in his chambers until the whirlwind of Henriette and her fellow elves had abated and the first guests had arrived.

Narcissa managed her guest lists with a strategy and refinement developed over decades of serving as the perfect hostess. Todayâ€™s invitees were a mix of higher level Ministry employees and academics. For Granger, the group would permit comfortable mingling with a familiar crowd. For Draco, it was a boon, as the categories of clingy dÃ©butantes and high level Ministry employees were normally mutually exclusive.

He caught Henriette and asked her, quietly, to let him know when Granger had arrived.

Then he made his way into the salon, which Narcissa had opened up onto the west terrace on this lovely May afternoon. Delicately wrought silver tables, piled high with finger sandwiches and cakes, spilled out onto the terrace. Guests were shielded from the sun by floating lace parasols that drifted over them.

Draco recognised some old school mates and wandered over to make small talk with Terry Boot (Department of Magical Accidents and Catastrophes), Davies (Magical Transportation), and Padma Patil (University of Edinburgh). The conversation moved from mutual ribbing about getting old, to the recent performance of the Falmouth Falcons, to children, at which point Draco lost interest and began to consider evasive manoeuvres.

Rescue came in the form of Henriette, who tugged at Dracoâ€™s sleeve to inform that Healer Granger had just Flooed in.

Draco found Granger dusting herself off in the Floo parlour. He had half expected her to arrive in Muggle attire to make a point. However, she had gone to the effort of wearing robes for the occasion. They were a light grey-blue in the French style, accentuating her collar bones and slender neck, and tailored high about the waist.

Granger looked pale but seemed preternaturally calm as she spotted Draco and asked, â€œWhy am I here, again?â€

Draco enumerated possibilities on his fingers: â€œA sudden interest in building bridges. To thank the Malfoys for making the Delacroix ward possible. Because you were personally invited by Narcissa Malfoy and no one says no to her. Because I coerced you. Take your pick.â€

â€œDonâ€™t flatter yourself â€“ you couldnâ€™t coerce me into anything.â€

â€œDonâ€™t challenge me, or I may decide to prove you wrong.â€

He and Granger exchanged mutually obstinate looks. However, Draco was more interested in the distinct lack of shaky hands or other trembles that usually marked Grangerâ€™s anxious states â€“ which todayâ€™s event ought to have triggered, given the location.

â€œYouâ€™ve taken a Calming Draught,â€ said Draco.

â€œWhatever gets me through it,â€ said Granger. â€œI neednâ€™t remind you of what my last sojourn under this roof was like.â€

â€œItâ€™s hardly the same roof,â€ said Draco, looking up at the grand white arc above them.

â€œWhat do you mean? Oh â€“ you said you had rebuilt.â€

Granger, too, looked up at the grand ceiling. She was quiet for a moment, and then said, â€œA thought experiment: is it still the same Manor if its original components were all replaced?â€

â€œThe Ship of Theseus,â€ said Draco. â€œWell â€“ Manor of Theseus, I suppose.â€

Granger turned her attention from the ceiling to him. Her expression flitted from surprised to impressed, then back to neutral. â€œPrecisely.â€

â€œTell me when youâ€™ve worked it out.â€ Draco held his arm towards the door. â€œShall we?â€

â€œNo,â€ said Granger, an arm wrapped around her midsection. â€œIâ€™d rather stay here and discuss the metaphysics of identity.â€

â€œHalf the guests here today are brains. You can discuss metaphysics to your little heartâ€™s content. The Patil twin who teaches at Edinburgh is here.â€

â€œOoh, Padmaâ€™s here?â€

This news spurred Granger on to follow Draco to the door that led to the entrance hall. She paused at the threshold and took a small, fortifying breath. Then she walked into the Manor proper. Draco, glancing behind him, noticed that she was keeping her head down and not looking about at all. Which was a pity, because substantial changes had been made since her last, unfortunate, visit.

â€œWe wanted to be rid of every reminder of theâ€¦ darker moments in our lives. Of Voldemortâ€™s stay here.â€ Dracoâ€™s comment drew Grangerâ€™s attention beyond her own feet. â€œItâ€™s changed a bit.â€

With an effort, Granger forced her gaze up and about. â€œOh â€“ itâ€™s muchâ€¦ much brighter than I remember.â€

Encouraged by this success, Draco decided to prattle on about the changes â€“ whatever kept Grangerâ€™s chin up. It wouldn't do for her to walk into the salon looking terrified.

â€œWe put in some new windows. Well â€“ that skylight was a huge bloody hole from some explosion. But we rather liked the sun being let into the foyer, so we had it glassed up instead of roofed.â€

They stopped at another large, oddly-shaped window that gave onto the East. â€œThis was a group-cast Bombarda by a bunch of Aurors. Didnâ€™t seem worth bricking back up again, not when it let the sunrise in so nicely.â€

Granger tilted her head, studying the decidedly non-traditional architectural feature. â€œYou know â€“ I rather like it.â€

â€œThe damage to the serpents and other grotesques led to a rather interesting discovery,â€ said Draco, gesturing to the arch mouldings above them. â€œWe found that theyâ€™d been built over angel iconography. Granger surveyed the half-dozen angels variously perched and soaring, up near the top of the ceiling. â€œOh. I wouldâ€™ve thought theyâ€™d always been serpents.â€

â€œSo did we. It seems some Malfoy ancestor in the eighteenth century got a bit excited about the familyâ€™s ties to Salazar Slytherin and decided to adopt the serpentine imagery whole-heartedly.â€

â€œYes. They wrote a report â€“ er â€“ itâ€™s somewhereâ€“â€

Finally, they made it to the salon. Draco heard a small intake of breath beside him. Granger had gasped. He himself was desensitised to his motherâ€™s decorations, but he supposed that the scene was rather pretty â€“ the sunlight, the terrace, the parasolsâ€¦

Draco noted his motherâ€™s use of Grangerâ€™s title and wondered how much she would scold him if she heard him refer to Granger as, well, Granger.

Narcissa, superb hostess that she was, eased Granger into the room through a tour of the most extravagant flower arrangements. There was a stiffness between the two of them, moderated by each witchâ€™s best attempt at neutral civility.

Narcissa swept Granger off towards an older Ministry crowd. Draco watched as Granger was introduced with a great deal of attention to her many accomplishments. In these circles, Granger hardly needed introduction, but her presence at Malfoy Manor was â€“ as Narcissa had hoped â€“ noted in quiet whispers.

Confident now that Granger wasnâ€™t about to faint in terror or flee the premises, Draco carried on with his mingling. The rebuilding of the Malfoy name and cachet had taken a decade and a half of work by himself and his mother. They were seeing the fruits of it now: the room was full of people with power, all of whom were glad to be seen at a Malfoy function, and thoroughly enjoying Narcissaâ€™s hospitality. Draco took note of who was in need of money, and who was in need of influence.

Tea was served. Granger had drifted into the Hogwarts crowd and was chatting with Patil and Boot. Draco was pleased to note that she stirred her tea correctly, back and forth, without clinking the spoon against the china. He was certain that his mother would also have noticed.

Yes â€“ Narcissa had just glanced over to Granger and her eyes had flitted to the stirring. Her gaze then slid to those that Granger was speaking with, observing the nature of her interactions.

A few days prior, Narcissa had confessed to Draco her surprise that 'the Granger girl' had accepted the invitation to tea. She had paced Dracoâ€™s study and enumerated the benefits at length: a Muggle-born, an intimate friend of Potterâ€™s, a Healer with an excellent reputation â€“ and, of course, a witch who had been on the Other Side of the war, who now condescended to join them at the Manor. She shouldâ€™ve thought of this before, really â€“ but Miss Granger had always been so cold and unsociable. What a stroke of luck that Draco had danced with her.

Narcissa regarded Grangerâ€™s attendance as something of a coup. Now she was watching it unfold with evident pleasure. Granger was being cordial, rather than standoffish as she mightâ€™ve been, and was behaving in a perfectly ladylike and witchlike manner. She laughed at the feeble jokes of important figures in the Ministry and spoke with authority on a great many subjects. She was effusive in her praise of the food, the rooms, the hosts. Altogether the ideal guest.

When everyone was properly stuffed with smoked salmon and cakes and jam, there was an exodus down the terrace steps and into the gardens. The guests, numbering about forty at Dracoâ€™s count, wandered through the hedges and spring flower beds as the sun began to set.

Those with a special interest in botany followed Narcissa into the greenhouses, where she led a tour of her rarer and more delicate specimens. Granger, of course, joined that group. Draco trailed behind, thinking vaguely that this gathering counted as a public event, and that he should therefore be on hand, should a guest lose their head and attack Granger in the presence of one of the Ministryâ€™s most notorious Aurors.

Granger took a special interest in the origin of Narcissaâ€™s hummingbird hyacinth, which his mother informed her had been imported from a wizard in Provence, many years ago.

Narcissa moved to the next row, along with the rest of the group. Granger stood and studied the hyacinth, whose clusters of flowers opened and closed their petals in shivering flitters, like their namesake hummingbirds.

â€œAre you admiring, or are you plotting something?â€ asked Draco, popping out from behind a giant fern.

Granger jumped. Then she looked annoyed. â€œNever you mind.â€

â€œThe latter, then.â€

â€œIâ€™m just thinking,â€ said Granger.

Draco came to stand beside her. â€œIf you need the flower for something, Iâ€™m sure my mother wouldnâ€™t mind. Sheâ€™d probably be overjoyed to contribute to whatever your endeavour is.â€

â€œNo.â€ Grangerâ€™s voice was vague and her eyes were unfocused. â€œNo, sheâ€™s already helped.â€

â€œHow?â€

â€œNothing; it doesnâ€™t matter,â€ said Granger, snapping back to the present. Which was a lie, but Draco decided not to press.

She cast about to see where the group had got to. However, something gave her pause. Draco followed her line of sight to the Manorâ€™s roofline, through the greenhouse glass.

Realisation dawned on her. â€œMalfoy, is this â€“ is this where the drawing room used to be?â€

â€œIt is.â€

A kind of shudder coursed through Granger. Then came defiance: a straightening of the back, a setting of the jaw. Then an odd reflexive clutching at one of her sleeves.

Now her face looked drawn and her breath was coming shallow. Had the Calming Draught worn off at such a truly unfortunate moment?

â€œLetâ€™s get out of here,â€ said Draco. He didnâ€™t give her the option to argue, threading his arm through hers and steering her out of the greenhouse. To any onlookers, he was being a gentleman escorting a lady past mud puddles, but his grip was iron.

He told himself that this solicitousness was because it would devastate his mother if Granger fainted away and caused a scene during one of her teas. It wasnâ€™t because he cared particularly about the witch holding his arm, who somehow vacillated between powerful and utterly fragile at the drop of a hat.

â€œMalfoy, Iâ€™m fine,â€ said Granger through clenched teeth. She tried to pull her arm away.

â€œLiar,â€ said Draco, not relinquishing his grip.

â€œAll right. Iâ€™ll be fine in a moment. I didnâ€™t expect to be soâ€¦â€

â€œIf you say weak, I shall be cross,â€ said Draco.

â€œOvercome, then.â€ Granger dabbed at her forehead. â€œEurgh, cold sweats.â€

â€œShould I fetch something? Draught of Peace?â€ asked Draco. However, just as Granger opened her mouth, he remembered: â€œNo, contraindicated within 24 hours of a Calming Draught. I almost forgot. Sit.â€

Granger sat on the stone bench that Draco had steered her towards.

And there, finally, were the trembling hands. She tried to hide them amongst the folds of her robes.

â€œIâ€™m fine, really,â€ said Granger.

â€œYour bravado is irritating to the highest degree,â€ said Draco.

He called a house-elf to fetch chocolate, which was immediately presented on a silver platter, in the form of one enormous slab, and two chocolate gÃ¢teaux.

Granger broke a piece of the slab off and let it melt in her mouth.

â€œBetter?â€ asked Draco.

â€œMm, endorphins,â€ said Granger. The attempt at levity was belied by her bloodless face.

â€œIf my mother asks what happened, weâ€™ll say we took a detour because you wanted to see the fountain.â€

â€œWhat fountain?â€ asked Granger.

â€œThat fountain,â€ said Draco.

Granger took stock of her surroundings for the first time and found herself looking at the fountain.


La Fontaine des Quatre Parties du Monde, Paris: our fountain inspiration for today. (Photo: eutouring.com)

â€œHippocampuses!â€ gasped Granger. â€œEr â€“ Hippocampodes!â€

Draco waved his wand at the fountain, activating the gurgle of sprays that truly made it come to life. â€œNow that Iâ€™ve seen them in person, this seems but a pale imitation.â€

â€œDonâ€™t be silly. It's beautiful. Who is it by?â€

â€œFremiet,â€ said Draco.

â€œOf course.â€

Draco regarded the statue critically. â€œThe scale is right, the proportions are perfect, the movement is gorgeous â€“ but itâ€™s hard to capture the majesty.â€

â€œExactly.â€

Draco leaned back onto his palms. â€œNow I fancy mulled wine.â€

They watched the play of the water over the rearing Hippocampuses in silence broken only by the gurgling of the jets. Granger ate another piece of chocolate. Draco had one of the cakes.

Light chit-chat about the fountain aside, Draco was wrestling with some uncomfortable feelings. He had convinced Granger to come to please his mother, but it hadnâ€™t been merely an afternoon outing at the home of a former enemy for her. Seeing her reaction to standing where that cursed drawing room had been helped Draco understand that this had been something greater and far more difficult.

To his mind, the house wasnâ€™t even the same house, and the drawing room didnâ€™t even exist anymore, but to Granger, this had been a visit to a scene of suffering. Her screams had echoed throughout these very grounds over many hours under Bellatrixâ€™s wand. During his more restless nights, he remembered them.

It hadn't been bravado â€“ it had been real bravery, to come here.

â€œI shouldnâ€™t have made you come,â€ said Draco, without looking at Granger, because admitting wrongdoing did not come easily to him. â€œDo you want to go home? Iâ€™ll take you back to the Floo parlour. We can say you were needed by one of your patients.â€

Granger glanced at him in a kind of muted surprise. Then she looked down at her hands, which had stopped shaking. â€œI think Iâ€™m all right now.â€

The colour had returned to her face and her breathing was back to normal. However, she hadnâ€™t returned to the level of unusual calmness that had marked her arrival here; the Draught had truly worn off.

Granger was looking at the greenhouse that stood in the place where she had been tortured. â€œI think itâ€™s good to come back. Possibly. Itâ€™s closure, isnâ€™t it? It marks the end of a terrible chapter.â€

The water danced. As the sun set, the gardenâ€™s magical illumination began to take over. The fountain was bathed in light; the Hippocampuses looked as though they breathed. The greenhouse glowed golden.

â€œGood things grow there, now,â€ said Granger. â€œEven your home isâ€¦ itâ€™s different. And I donâ€™t just mean the building. Itâ€™s touched by Light.â€

Draco said nothing. They had strayed into a strange new territory beyond quarrels and banter, and he did not have solid footing.

â€œSometimes I think fifteen years is so terribly far away," continued Granger. â€œHalf our lives, really. An age. And then I have moments like â€“ like what I just had, where it feels like it was yesterday. And everything is raw and hurts.â€

â€œI know,â€ said Draco. He knew exactly.

There was a long silence. The water danced and sang.

At length, Granger spoke again. â€œAt least youâ€™ve changed enough that I no longer see the bullying idiot from my school days.â€

â€œHave I?â€

â€œYes.â€ Granger smiled a tiny smile. â€œYouâ€™re just an idiot, now.â€

â€œWow,â€ said Draco.

â€œYouâ€™ve grown into your chin, too,â€ said Granger.

â€œThanks.â€

â€œAnd your feet â€“ more or less.â€

â€œContinue. This cataloguing is thrilling.â€

â€œWhat next?â€

â€œYou havenâ€™t insulted my hands yet,â€ said Draco.

â€œShow me.â€Â She took his hand in her small one and passed it over with a critical eye. â€œOverlarge. Perhaps you have another growth spurt in you.â€

â€œMaybe.â€

â€œBetter not, though,â€ said Granger, releasing his hand. â€œYouâ€™re already tall. You donâ€™t want to be gawky.â€

â€œAnything else youâ€™d like to critique about my proportions?â€

â€œI think Iâ€™ve inventoried the worst offenders.â€

â€œTch. Iâ€™m the golden ratio personified.â€

â€œHow do you mean?â€

â€œYou being generally minuscule,â€ said Draco, gesturing at Granger. â€œThat basis of comparison makes the rest of us look enormous.â€

â€œSeveral hairs, I think. You might have some Pixie heritage. It would explain the shrillness.â€

â€œItsy-bitsy?!â€

â€œMicroscopic, really. Youâ€™re the nanoparticle; you should talk to that Danish bloke and ask about your clinical applications.â€

Granger opened her mouth. Offence and amusement warred briefly across her features, then she burst into laughter.

â€œWhat emotion havenâ€™t you gone through today?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œFine,â€ sighed Granger. â€œI suppose there's enough to share.â€

â€œPure decadence, Granger, but I like your style.â€

They finished the gateau.

â€œI am truly feeling better,â€ said Granger, afterwards. â€œHadnâ€™t we better rejoin the others?â€

â€œI suppose,â€ said Draco.

Really, though, he didnâ€™t want to. Heâ€™d rather sit here and watch the sunset tinge the sky soft pink, and listen to the fountain, and enjoy the feel-good buzz that only wizarding chocolate could give. Perhaps spring an argument or two onto Granger, just for sport.

What topic would provoke her the most? Divination? Oxford outranking Cambridge? Her cat? Quizzing her on her project? Suggesting a group broom ride over the estate? Insulting Potter? House-elves?

Granger had a great deal of buttons.

However, before Draco had the luxury of launching his next missile, a wandering group of partygoers joined them in the courtyard and ruined the atmosphere with exclamations about the prettiness of the fountain.

Draco noticed that Granger had edged away from him on the bench. This amused him â€“ what did she think, that people would see them on a bench together and leap to some kind of conclusion? He was Draco Malfoy and she was Hermione Granger. That was utterly risible.

(Her distancing nevertheless made him feel sulky. He, too, shifted away from her on the bench.)

â€œZabini,â€ said Draco. â€œI didnâ€™t realise you were invited.â€

â€œIt is,â€ said Granger. She sounded surprised.

â€œWeâ€™ve established that, yes,â€ said Zabini. â€œAnd sheâ€™s gone from a precocious kidlet to a rather fiery kind of witch. Authoritative. Competent. That does things for me. But if you prefer to live in the past â€“ by all means, continue. I will happily find my amusement in the present.â€

Draco concluded that Zabini didnâ€™t know anything at all and that he was an idiot.

Solstice

Draco did not see Granger again until mid-June. She came into her laboratory at Trinity just as he was recasting her wards.

She looked as sweaty as he was, and rather more harried.

It was an Italian restaurant in an hour. Participant(s) unspecified.

Draco stuffed her schedule back into his pocket.

He had a certain suspicion that Granger had a date.

And he didnâ€™t care at all, and it certainly didnâ€™t irritate him for no reason.

He sent a Jot to Zabini, out of an abundance of â€“ well, heâ€™d call it caution â€“ asking him if he had any plans that evening. Zabini said no, but heâ€™d be glad to have plans; should they meet at the Macassar?

Draco sent back his agreement. Theo was invited too, who suggested they invite Pansy, who brought her Longbottomed plonker of a husband, who invited MacMillan, who arrived with three Ministry colleagues, and they ended up making quite an evening of it.

One of MacMillanâ€™s juniors was a witch with whom Draco had slept a few times over the years. She gave him her amorous attentions all evening and he accepted them with a kind of listlessness â€“ the touches at his thigh, the holding of his arm. However, when she trailed after him to the dark corridor leading to the loo, he found that he had no desire to pursue anything further with her. When he returned, very much un-mussed, and with an offended looking witch behind him, Zabini and Ernie both regarded him with a raised eyebrow.

Whatever. As he shot back his Firewhisky, Draco reflected that at least he could rest easy that it wasnâ€™t bloody Zabini that Granger was cosying up to tonight.

~

The journey from London to France went as smoothly as could be desired. Draco met Granger at one of the International Floo departures in London. After she pronounced herself satisfied with Dracoâ€™s holidaying Mugglewear (â€œQuite smart, really â€“ you look like you own a boat.â€) they stepped into the fire.Â 

Then, after a longish, three-minute whirl in the Floo that made Granger green, they found themselves at the hearth of the Tournesol in Aix-en-Provence.

From there, Granger took over, navigating them to a car hire place, and then driving the forty kilometres to the charming seaside town of Saint-Maximin-la-Sainte-Baume. Their suitcases were in the boot, their snacks were in the back seat, and the car stereo played something that wasnâ€™t Austrian folk music. Draco found it to be altogether a pleasant drive through olive groves, vineyards, and hilltops dotted with medieval ruins. Perhaps there was something to be said for the Mugglesâ€™ scenic routes, rather than the immediacy of Apparition.

Granger was full of a kind of nervous energy that manifested itself in a stream of informative babbling paired with peppy driving. Draco endured the former and rather enjoyed the latter. Their hired Peugeot had looked, to Dracoâ€™s unpractised eye, like a stodgy sort of car, but Granger had awakened a zeal for life in the thing.

They whizzed past meandering ProvenÃ§al traffic without issue until Granger found a challenger: a black CitroÃ«n whose chief joy was racing to catch up and pass them, and then slowing down again in a pissy sort of way.

â€œTwat,â€ said Draco, the third time this had happened.

â€œA Parisian, of course,â€ said Granger, observing the registration plate.

â€œIâ€™ve half a mind to hit him with a puncture,â€ said Draco, spinning his wand between his fingers.

â€œThat wouldnâ€™t be sporting,â€ said Granger. The road straightened out enough for her to attempt a pass. She shifted gears. â€œHold onto your trousers.â€

The Peugeotâ€™s engine whined in startled protest as Granger hit the accelerator. The car responded with an astonishing burst of speed. Dracoâ€™s head and body felt as though they were being pressed into the seat by the G-forces â€“ a delightful sensation that made him want to whoop.

The tyres squeaked and their small car surged ahead of the CitroÃ«n.

â€œCheers, dickhead,â€ said Draco, making the V-sign to the other driver as they passed.

The man in the car made an equally friendly gesture back.

As they whizzed down the road, Draco remarked, â€œI didnâ€™t think this car had that kind of verve. What did you put in her for petrol, Pepperup? Oi â€“ you had your wand out!â€

Granger was tucking something into her pocket. She started. â€œWhat? No.â€

â€œAnd you called me unsporting?â€

â€œI only gave us a bit of a boost,â€ said Granger, with a triumphant glare back at the other car through the rearview mirror.

Draco observed her. â€œGrangerâ€™s Paradox.â€

â€œI beg your pardon?â€

â€œYouâ€™re a speed demon, and yet you hate flying.â€

â€œYou ski, too. Isnâ€™t skiing rather an extreme sport? You launch yourself down the Alps at high velocity?â€

â€œOnly if you put it that wayâ€“â€

â€œFrom the top of a mountain,â€ said Draco. â€œThousands of metres in the air. Brooms will take you two hundred metres up, at the most extreme.â€

â€œItâ€™s different when thereâ€™s nothing below you.â€

A lengthy argument ensued. Meanwhile, the country around them grew wooded. They took a slip-road off to a rural road, winding down through gorges and then back up again. They passed through convivial medieval villages and then down a sinuous country lane, which eventually brought them to vast flatlands striped with lavender fields and, finally, the sea.

â€œOh, how beautiful,â€ sighed Granger, in a moment of uncharacteristic softness.

â€œA balm upon the soul,â€ said Draco, with enough of an edge to suggest cynicism, to cover the fact that he meant it.

The picturesque town of Saint-Maximin came into view under the afternoon sun.

â€œWeâ€™ll stay at the hotel tonight,â€ said Granger, â€œAnd weâ€™ll do the walk up and the â€“ the other activity â€“ tomorrow morning.â€

Draco felt her give him a sidelong look, to which he quirked an eyebrow. â€œWhat?â€

â€œThe nicer hotels were all booked up, so donâ€™t be a prat about the quality of the place. Itâ€™sâ€¦ older. The restaurant is apparently lovely, though.â€

â€œIs the hotel run by ogres?â€

â€œOf course not â€“ this is a Muggle town.â€

â€œThen itâ€™ll be fine.â€

â€œYouâ€™ve stayed in a place run by ogres?â€Â 

â€œYes,â€ said Draco. â€œA stakeout in Budle. I did learn a bed bug extermination spell as a result, so weâ€™ll be sorted if you feel anything scurrying up your legs tonight.â€

â€œEurgh,â€ shuddered Granger.

Grangerâ€™s mobile, which had been serving as a kind of live map for the duration of the drive, suddenly announced that the Hotel Plaisance was coming up on their right.

The hotel was old and tired, but beautifully situated.Â The small foyer was packed with other arrivals, all of whom were being served by a single, hard-of-hearing old woman, who moved with all of the agility of a mollusc. Eventually, it was their turn, and the woman gave them the key to their room and took their names down for a dinner reservation.

The tiny room had a bed of questionable structural integrity, a lamp, a caved-in sofa, and an afterthought of a bathroom.

There was a vague, fusty scent to the room, as though someone's great aunt had sprayed perfume and then died there in sad circumstances.

â€œAll mod cons, Granger,â€ said Draco as they took stock.

â€œSea view, at least?â€ said Granger, banging open the shutters to air things out.

The bed squeaked as Draco sat on it and then sank almost to the ground, with intimations that it was planning on collapsing entirely under his weight as soon as he was asleep.

Granger observed Draco where he sat, his knees almost at his chin.

â€œThe bed is yours,â€ she said with what sheâ€™d no doubt intended to sound like generosity. It sounded rather strategic to Dracoâ€™s ear. She had her eye on the sofa. â€œIâ€™ll Transfigure this into something serviceable for myself.â€

â€œSomething serviceable,â€ repeated Draco, as Granger undertook a complex, ten minute Transfiguration exercise, turning the sofa into a lovely, cushy-looking bed, in a regal burgundy.

Granger missed the raillery. â€œThat should do it,â€ she said, slightly breathless from the magical exertion. â€œNow. I should like a shower. What are your plans for the evening? Dinnerâ€™s at eight.â€

â€œMy job,â€ said Draco, already warding the window. â€œIâ€™m going to have a wander. Iâ€™ll meet you back here at quarter to.â€

â€œAll right,â€ said Granger. She had pulled out a list.

Granger grappled with her luggage, pulled out a change of clothes, and stepped into the bathroom.

Draco left her to it and stalked the hotel's dingy halls, warding as he went. He did not find any baddies. There were only Muggles present. Grangerâ€™s plan, at least for Day One, was unfurling smoothly.

Tomorrow was an entirely different story, of course. Draco returned to their room to read the tome on warding heâ€™d brought with him.

Granger had already left â€“ all the better for him to squeeze in another bit of studying. He kicked off his shoes and stretched out on Grangerâ€™s bed, the book floating above him as he flicked through pages.

Draco had been focusing his study on warding techniques on the Continent, but especially on the work of magical religious orders. He hoped that his readings on the warding systems of Cistercian and Dominican Monks would, at the very least, give him a clue tomorrow when he uncovered whatever the Benedictine Sisters had cast around their beloved relics.

She was chewing on something.

Draco held out his hand, his focus still on the book.

â€œNone left,â€ said Granger.

Draco floated the book lower so he could look into her eyes. â€œLiar.â€

â€œMm,â€ said Draco. â€œBless the French.â€

She squeezed onto the bed next to him. The book floated above them.

â€œThis isâ€“â€ began Draco.

â€œQuiet,â€ said Granger. â€œIâ€™m reading.â€

Draco lapsed into annoyed silence.

Granger did not read, by the way â€“ Granger devoured. Her reading speed outpaced Dracoâ€™s by fifty percent at his best guess, and he was himself a fast reader. However, he did not turn the pages to cater to her pace; he gave her a moral lecture about the importance of Absorbing the Information and Savouring the Text instead.

She responded with a long and dramatic sigh. Draco felt the expansion of her chest against his side. That made him aware that Granger was there in a different way than her impatient presence. It made him alert and twitchy, because he was lying down on a bed with a woman, and that woman was Hermione Granger. If heâ€™d ever been mad enough to imagine such a scene, he wouldâ€™ve pictured a moment of recoil, of distaste, probably, at this level of closeness with his childhood enemy.

Instead, she felt warm, and she smelled like sunshine and almonds, and her hair was touching his neck, and it was intimate and strange. He felt a kind of pleasurable paralysis, of not wanting to breathe, of not daring to move and accidentally touching her too much, or worse, causing her to move away.

He turned the page, with no idea what he had just read.

His eyes kept drifting from the book above them to her legs, which were bent at the knee, with one leg crossed over the other. Her dress was bunched up at her thighs, covering anything of interest â€“ there was nothing indecent about any of it, really â€“ and yet it felt illicit and thrilling, to see Grangerâ€™s legs from here. She had kicked off her sandals to join him on the bed. He could see the delicate arch of her bare foot, the tan lines where the sun had kissed her and then worked around the straps, the pink-painted toes.

The delicate foot started to bounce.

â€œYouâ€™re doing it on purpose to annoy me, being this slow,â€ said Granger.

Draco snapped his eyes back to the page. â€œNo, I am being attentive.â€

Granger waved her wand to tell the time â€“ it was eight on the dot. â€œUgh. We've got to go.â€

â€œThey might be,â€ said Draco. (He found that his brain was working in a kind of slow motion; it was still processing her thighs and the bunched-up dress, and had not yet joined him in the present.)

â€œWeâ€™ll have to be ever so careful tomorrow, if those things are as hair-trigger as this text suggests.â€

Granger was redoing her plait. Draco got a whiff of her shampoo. That brought his brain back to the present, because it liked it.

She was still going on about the chapter they had just read, and whether Draco felt that he needed more preparation, and whether they should revisit the plan, and if so, which parts they should modify. Perhaps she should feign illness in the monastery to distract the Sisters while Draco went into the crypt, to buy him more time? But no, he hadnâ€™t studied the maps as she had; it had taken her weeks to memorise the labyrinthine paths, &c. &c.

Which was excellent, as it gave Draco time to Get a Grip. What the fuck was wrong with him? He went to the bathroom to splash some cold water on his face, and hopefully some sense into his brain.

They made their way downstairs to dinner.

~

The restaurant was all a-bustle. It was a lovely outdoor installation on a long kind of wharf that extended out into the sea, crammed with as many tables as possible. Draco and Granger threaded their way through the other patrons to a table for two at the end of the wharf.

It being midsummer, the sun was still hanging over the horizon at this late hour, tinging the sea gold and orange. It was an utterly gorgeous June evening; the breeze played lazily with their hair, the sea splashed along the edge of the wharf in musical little wavelets, the sea-birds weaved their wheels above.

As it turned out, the half-deaf old lady who had taken their reservation had creatively interpreted their names.

The slate placard indicated that the table was reserved for Hormone et Crotch.

A solemn waiter came by to light the candles on the table. Grangerâ€™s lips were pressed tightly together. Draco felt an uncomfortable bubbling of hilarity.

â€œMonsieur, the wine list,â€ said the waiter, handing it to Draco.

â€œMerci,â€ said Draco.

The waiter recommended the red; Draco went with that, because all of his brain power was focused on not bursting into a scream of laughter.

Grangerâ€™s eyes flitted back to the placard. She let out a gurgle that she turned into a kind of cough.

The waiter enumerated the eveningâ€™s menu. Granger nodded her approval of the buttered sole while Draco croaked out a yes for the fillet mignon.

Granger was biting one of her knuckles. Draco heard her undertaking a deep breathing exercise.

Finally, the waiter left.

Granger collapsed onto the table. â€œCrotch,â€ she gasped, attempting to breathe.

â€œH-Hormone?â€ wheezed Draco.

Granger was a boneless mass of restrained laughter. Her shoulders shook. Draco fell back into his chair and actually felt himself disintegrate into mirth.

â€œMy god,â€ breathed Granger. â€œOh my godâ€¦ whyâ€¦ whyâ€¦â€

Draco attempted to sober up, but then he looked at the placard again, and Crotch looked back at him in a beautiful flowing script, and he brought his napkin to his mouth to muffle himself.

â€œTheyâ€™re going to think weâ€™re already pissed and kick us out,â€ said Draco, valiantly straightening up and attempting to regain control.

â€œObviously.â€

So Draco told her. He shared two or three of his favourite stories, which prominently featured his own heroics and wits. Why, indeed? Draco parried, and countered, and justified, and defended, until Granger was satisfied.

He poured himself a second glass of wine, finding himself rather wrung-out and thirsty after the interrogation. His tales were usually followed by praise and gushing, and starry-eyed gaspings about his bravery and sagacity. With Granger? Not a chance.

â€œAt least one of us will be feeling confident, which is better than none,â€ was her closing remark.

â€œYes.â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œYes.â€ Granger looked terribly amused.

Granger settled into a pose that Draco could only describe as professorial. She crossed her legs and held up her fork, ready to point to an invisible blackboard. â€œInstantaneous communication systems really took off in the Muggle world about 10 years ago. They already had a leg up over wizards with the telephone for the entirety of the twentieth century, but when email became common, and texting, and, later, instant messaging, wizarding communication methods went from old fashioned to utterly archaic. I created the Jotters to supplement those means of communication, not replace them â€“ I do love writing a good letter. I never expected them to be as popular as they are. The twins helped me bring them to market and they get a percentage of the profits.â€

Draco kept his features schooled into something neutral. The other option was a bug-eyed stare. Not only was this woman frighteningly intelligent, but she was also absolutely minted. Everyone had a Jotter. His own mother had a Jotter and was, judging by the buzzing in his pocket, rapidly gaining proficiency. Granger must be rolling in Galleons. They can have live calls with hundreds of participants. The Jotters are rudimentary. An improvement, but rudimentary.â€ Here Granger gave a shrug. â€œThe bar was rather low. â€œIs that what your project is about, too?â€ asked Draco. â€œA problem that is within your capacity to fix?â€

â€œExactly.â€ Granger regarded him seriously, now. â€œI neednâ€™t tell you that Iâ€™d prefer the truth about the Jotters to remain between us. I only told you because you were being so horridly insistent.â€

Granger laughed, but it was bitter. â€œNo. Developing new therapies is terribly expensive.â€

â€œIs it?â€

â€œYes.â€ Granger began to enumerate costs on her fingers, until she ran out of fingers. â€œMaterials, space, laboratory staff, medical leads, legal staff, protocol writers, data scientists, staticiansâ€¦ testing for safety and efficacy is spendy too, of course â€“ pharmacokinetic studies, preclinical toxicology testing, bioanalytical testing, and the clinical trials themselves. And the financial outlay to meet every requirement of the GCP, the GMP, the GLP, the MHRA, and the EMA is eye-watering.â€

Draco, whose eyes had largely glazed over, said, â€œOh.â€

Granger shifted in her seat in a discontented sort of way. â€œMy project involves complex biologics that are commercially unattractive and nigh incomprehensible to the monumentally idiotic wizards who hold the national purse strings for magical research.
