Iâ€™m still doing in vitro research, trying to confirm that my target can actually be affected by an exogenous compound in the first place. Money doesnâ€™t solve all problems, unfortunately.â€

The waiter returned to take their dessert orders. Granger flinched out an apology, having forgotten to even look at the menu, and made a haphazard selection of crÃ¨me caramel.

Meanwhile, Draco was struggling to understand the paradoxical phenomenon that was Granger. She could have been wealthy â€“ extravagantly so. And yet, she chose to fund her research instead of enjoying a life of leisure. She worked approximately twelve jobs. She couldâ€™ve had her own country house, but she lived in a cramped cottage in the outskirts of Cambridge. She could have a full staff of house-elves, but she only had a cat and a grim tin of tuna in her cupboards.

It made no sense. And yet, as Draco considered what he knew of the witch in front of him, it sort of did. She was too driven for a life of leisure. Too grounded for the extravagance of large homes and house-elves. Too much of a Do-Gooder to do anything but Good with that money. It was all terribly laudable. Dreadful, really.

Granger cleared her throat. Draco realised that heâ€™d been staring at her, and that the waiter was staring at him.

â€œMonsieurâ€™s dessert selection?â€

â€œWhat sheâ€™s having,â€ said Draco.

â€œUne crÃ¨me caramel pour Monsieur Crotch,â€ said the waiter, inscribing this precious information upon his notepad with care.

Granger touched eyes with Draco. She held a hand to her mouth.

The waiter left.

Granger squeaked out a giggle, struggled to control it, took a large breath, and was still.

â€œHormone,â€ said Draco.

Granger collapsed into a fit of uncontrollable giggling.

â€œI told you not to do that,â€ she gasped, coming back up for air.

â€œThere is something gratifying about making you utterly lose it.â€

Granger sniffed and dabbed at her lashes with a napkin. â€œItâ€™s a rare sight, I hope youâ€™re appreciating it.â€

â€œI am,â€ said Draco.

And he was. Grangerâ€™s dark eyes were bright with laughter. Her cheeks were flushed, her lips were reddened by wine. Her hair in its loose plait snaked down to her waist, a dark line against her white sundress. Her legs were curled under her; she looked dainty and fragile, and small enough to fit perfectly into a man's lap, if a man were thinking about such things. (Draco certainly wasn't.)

And the candlelight loved her. It kissed at her forehead and flickered warm touches across her collarbone. It danced in her eyes.

The effect was enchanting.

Draco sank, unaware, into a state of soft fascination.

An accordionist began to play, somewhere near the hotel, filling the air with romance.

â€œMonsieur, your crÃ¨me caramel.â€

The return to reality was jarring.

â€œMerci,â€ said Draco, instead of sod the fucking crÃ¨me caramel.

Granger was eating her dessert, blissfully unaware of Dracoâ€™s reverie, thank the gods. He decided to blame the wine for making him such a daft, moon-eyed cretin tonight. That and too few recent shags, clearly, if he was going to faff off and daydream about Granger, of all of the witches in his life.

It would help if she didnâ€™t look like a lovely Grecian dryad tonight, about to join Artemisâ€™ retinue.

Since when was Granger beautiful?

What an aggravating development.

â€œAre you all right?â€ asked Granger.

â€œWhy?â€ asked Draco, injecting some irritation into the syllable, to sound Absolutely Normal.

â€œYouâ€™ve hardly touched your dessert,â€ said Granger, gesturing to Dracoâ€™s crÃ¨me caramel with her spoon. â€œRather uncharacteristic.â€

There were other things going on that were rather uncharacteristic, but if that was the only one that the Brain was catching on to, that was fine by Draco.

â€œIâ€™m savouring it,â€ said Draco. He took a slow bite to demonstrate.

Grangerâ€™s eyebrow twitched. â€œStop that.â€

â€œStop what?â€ asked Draco.

â€œBeing indecent with the spoon.â€

â€œI am using the spoon. Anything else is a figment of your imagination.â€

Granger narrowed her eyes at him. Draco took another slow bite, maintaining an obnoxious level of eye contact. Granger looked away.

â€œNow you arenâ€™t eating yours,â€ pointed out Draco.

â€œIâ€™ve quite lost my appetite, watching you snog the cutlery,â€ sniffed Granger.

â€œYou arenâ€™t going to finish?â€

â€œNo. Do you want it?â€

â€œIâ€™d rather you choke it down and have strength for the monastery. If the nuns get shirty, tomorrow could be rather strenuous, magically speaking.â€

Granger finished her crÃ¨me caramel doggedly, if not with enthusiasm.

Draco found himself observing her now with a critical eye. When he had first met her, in long-ago January, he had been struck by the exhausted thinness that had made her face severe and gaunt. It seemed to him that she had a slightly healthier mien, now â€“ but only slightly. She was a little less bony, a little rosier in the cheeks.

Granger gestured to the waiter for the bill. â€œLâ€™addition, sâ€™il vous plaÃ®t.â€

Her raised arm made Draco realise that her dress had left her arms bare, something that Grangerâ€™s choice of attire normally trended against. And now, precisely because it was trying not to catch his attention, her left forearm caught his attention â€“ there was a Notice-Me-Not charm there.

He deliberately looked at the table next door, allowing Granger and her arm to slip into his peripheral vision. There: a blur across the skin of her inner arm.

He realised what the glamour was covering with a sickening plummeting sensation in his stomach. A vivid memory returned, of Bellatrixâ€™s handiwork, stark against Grangerâ€™s skin. Of Granger, limp and wrought-out, lying like a dead thing on the drawing room floor. Of the blood oozing out of the fresh-carved letters.

Draco had never used the word Mudblood again, after that.

Now there was something terribly sorrowful in Grangerâ€™s habit of wearing long sleeves. In the discreet glamour that sheâ€™d cast to be able to wear a pretty dress. Draco hid his own inner arm shame from the world, but he wouldâ€™ve thought that Granger, of all people, wouldâ€™ve been able to heal hers away. Clearly, she still bore the mark of Bellatrixâ€™s knife.

â€œMalfoy?â€

Draco blinked. â€œHm?â€

â€œYouâ€™ve gone quiet.â€

Granger had settled the bill with Muggle money. She was rising from her chair.

Draco rose with her. â€œJust thinking about tomorrow.â€

But really, he was thinking about a distant yesterday, when this witch had been mutilated in the halls of his home. And she still bore the scar, and she hid it, from him, and from everyone, but it was still there. A daily reminder for her, of cruelty and sick hate. Of how close sheâ€™d come to death. Of how near their world had come to a point of no return.

He wished to say something to her â€“ words of sorrow, or of apology â€“ but such words did not come easily to him, and he couldnâ€™t see such a conversation go anywhere but difficult, awkward places.

As they weaved their way through tables back off the wharf, Draco concluded that this was not quite the moment. But, watching the blur of the glamour brush against her skirts as she walked, he determined that there would be A Moment, and he would find the words. Not tonight, but some night.

The sun was finally setting, languidly, lazily, on this gorgeous evening, Midsummer less a day.

Granger was looking wistfully along the rocky beach. â€œThereâ€™s meant to be a marker along there, where the Magdalene wouldâ€™ve first set foot in France.â€

â€œI suppose that was on your itinerary?â€

â€œIt was, but I ran out of time.â€

â€œLetâ€™s go,â€ said Draco.

Granger looked at him in surprise. â€œYouâ€™d come?â€

Draco gave her his most nonchalant shrug. â€œI fancy a walk.â€

Grangerâ€™s surprise turned to a prudent kind of delight. â€œAll right, itâ€™s about a fifteen minute ramble, that way. So the guidebook said, anyway.â€

They clambered and slid down large boulders to the rocky beach, where they found a kind of coastal path. Granger led Draco along, pointing out features of geological or historical interest as they went. The views became progressively more dramatic as they left the shallow bay that the hotel was nestled in and made their way around the headland.

The tide began to come in. Draco rolled up his trousers and his shirtsleeves (ensuring, on the latter point, that his own glamour was in place), then tied his shoes together, and slung them over his shoulder. Granger carried her sandals hooked through her fingers. They splashed through salty rock pools, as warm as bathwater. The sound of the accordion on the wharf faded away; now it was only the heart-pulse of the waves.

They meandered into a flock of hundreds of seabirds, which took off around them and unravelled into the skies in a whirr of wingbeats and sea-cries. It was a startling moment of sublimity that took a bit of their souls with it. Granger watched the birdsâ€™ disappearance into the blue with a soft sigh, her fingertips on her collarbone, her lips parted.

Granger said, â€œBeautiful,â€ and Draco said, â€œYes,â€ but they were not talking about the same thing.

They continued. The marker for the Magdaleneâ€™s point of arrival was a modest stone, half-buried in sand, at the tip of the headland. A few cut flowers were scattered about, as well as candles gamely fighting to stay lit in the breeze.

Granger furnished Draco with a great many details about the legend of the Magdaleneâ€™s expulsion from the Holy Land, and what disciples were with her, and when she had reached this shore. Draco cared little for the details, but he was glad of the excuse to keep his attention on her, on the way the wind wended her plait hither and thither, on her bare legs trickling with seawater. At one point, she almost lost her balance on the wet stones and her fingers touched his arm. They were quickly withdrawn.

Draco said he supposed that there were worse places to land than Provence. Granger said she thought so, too. Draco asked whether the Magdalene wouldâ€™ve eaten marzipan-stuffed dates when she was here. Granger fancied that she was the one who had brought the recipe over from the Holy Land, in the first place. Draco said that stealing the credit for such a sublime culinary creation was a classically French thing to do. Granger agreed.

Then they lapsed into silence and they stood where the land met the sea, and breathed the sweet air, and were tickled by the salt breeze. Little waves strained to reach past their knees before atomising into brine.

Draco found a seastar. Granger was delighted by the discovery and squatted down to look at it, and interrogated Draco on what species it was, and Draco said he hadnâ€™t a sodding clue.

They turned to walk back to the hotel, splish-splashing through the warm tide pools, wavelets clinging foamily at their ankles. Their hands brushed a time or two, and they said sorry, and stepped away from each other, and kept walking, and then their elbows brushed, by accident, because theyâ€™d drifted together again.

The large boulders near the wharf presented more difficulty for Granger on the way up than down; she stood, irresolute, grasping the wand in her pocket, but there were Muggles about, and her plans to Transfigure a stairway were interrupted.

Draco came up behind her and lifted her in one smooth motion, and received an indignant squeal and a face-full of sandy skirts for his troubles. Her waist felt narrow and taut between his palms, and warm.

He didnâ€™t need her help to clamber up behind her, but he nevertheless accepted the small hand she reached towards him and took amusement in the serious effort she put into her pull.

They meandered back towards the hotel.

The sun poured gold across the horizon. With the brightness behind her, Granger looked like she was wearing nothing but light.

â€œA very fair attempt,â€ said Granger, patting him on the head. (He was too surprised to be indignant.)

â€œIâ€™m waiting for you to take pity on me,â€ panted Draco.

â€œWhy didnâ€™t you stay in Transfiguration?â€ asked Draco to interrupt the lecture. â€œWhy Healing?â€

Granger looked up from where she was transforming the worn coverlet into a plush blanket. â€œTransfigurationâ€™s practical applications peak at the Mastery level â€“ Doctoral studies veer into the abstruse and theoretical. Draco had nursed a suspicion that Granger was one of those hateful morning people. She proved it as soon as she could the next day, by launching herself out of bed at the unholy hour of half five.

The sun rose with her on this Solstice morning and seemed equally fixated on denying Draco his preferred nice, healthy lie-in till 11 a.m.

To further compound his irritation, Draco woke up hard. He remained unmoving, face down on the bed, as Granger faffed about with her suitcase, complained about getting naff all sleep, and finally got into the shower.

He waved away his indecency with his wand, trying to recollect when he had last woken up with such a rager. Bloody hell, he needed a shag.

Granger was quick in the shower. Then, smelling of soap and warm skin, she stood next to Dracoâ€™s bed and cleared her throat.

Draco nodded and slipped on the sunglasses that he had purchased for the occasion. They were heart-shaped and pink and wonderfully kitschy. Granger stared at them for a long moment, then declared that she wanted some too, and conjured a matching pair.


by catmintandthyme (there is a NSFW version!)

Thus equipped, they began the hike up towards the monastery; a nice, sweaty preamble to a sacrilegious violation of a priceless relic.

The way up was, as promised by Granger, a bit of a slog. It was early enough that the heat of the day didnâ€™t utterly flatten them. As they progressed upwards, they were protected from the worst of the sun by a cathedral of trees that filtered the light into cool greens. White hyacinths dotted the undergrowth. It smelled of earth and mushrooms.

Between gasps for breath, Granger provided Draco with histories of the various pilgrims who had walked this path, and the alleged Miracles that had followed.

Draco said that, as riveting as these histories were, he would advise her to save her breath for the climb and concentrate. She did not heed his advice. About halfway up a steep ascent, her lecture distracted her too much and she tripped off the path and into a ditch full of brambles and mud. Her wand, which sheâ€™d been using to sear away thorny overgrowth, remained on the path with Draco.

Draco, seeing that Granger was unhurt at the bottom of the ditch, took up a contemplative position, leaning his shoulder against a tree. â€œWhat youâ€™ve done there, Granger, is gone arse over tit.â€

â€œThank you for that instructive remark.â€ Granger was peevish, for some reason.

Draco then generously explained to her what Principles and Laws of physics she hadnâ€™t quite been applying correctly.

Granger attempted a clamber out, which only sank her further in brambles.

Draco observed with great interest. â€œBlondes really do have more fun.â€

Granger gave up on the climb, having been distracted by the torn-up state of her clothing, courtesy of the brambles. â€œUgh. These were new.â€

â€œYou look like youâ€™ve lost a square go with a Jack Russell,â€ said Draco.

Granger looked waspish. â€œAre you going to help me up?â€

â€œYouâ€™ve a broom,â€ said Draco.

â€œNo,â€ said Granger. â€œPass me my wand.â€

â€œBut the broom is right there. With you. In your pocket.â€

â€œNo. Are you mad? Itâ€™s your fastest broom. Iâ€™ll give myself a traumatic brain injury.â€

Granger glowered at him, both hands on her hips. Then she changed tack. â€œHowâ€™s your leg?â€

â€œ...Fine.â€

â€œLiar. Youâ€™ve been favouring it the past quarter hour.â€

Which was true, but Draco had hoped she hadnâ€™t noticed.

Draco considered the muddy witch at the bottom of the pit. Then he considered the hilarity of watching Granger attempt to ride his broom. Then he considered the pain in his knee.

The pain won out. He needed to be agile, for whatever the monastery was going to throw at them. Unfortunate.

Draco tossed Grangerâ€™s wand down to her.

She made quick work of her escape, thereafter. The earth before her split into a platform, which, propelled by thick roots, carried her back to the path.

Granger with her wand back in her hand looked rather more dangerous than the wandless one in the ditch. She was eyeing Draco with something less than kindness for his giggle at her expense. The heat of it rather promised Revenge.

However, a deal was a deal (bless her, you could always count on her for that) and Grangerâ€™s wand was soon pointed at Dracoâ€™s knee, and the relief of Healing spread across it.

â€œYes yes, youâ€™re right, of course. Letâ€™s get on. Weâ€™ve wasted enough time with your dilly-dallying in ditches.â€

Now sound of body, Draco strode up the path, with Granger scurrying behind him to keep up, muttering rude things at his back.

Finally, they came to the monastery. Granger had explained that it had been built at the entrance of the grotto where the Magdalene had first taken refuge, which now served as a chapel.

Draco and Granger took a moment to camouflage their wands upon their persons and rearrange their mutually hostile body language into that of Bumbling Muggle Newlyweds. They walked next to each other, Grangerâ€™s arm hooked through Dracoâ€™s.

Their first obstacle was the Sister at the monastery doorâ€“an older woman, observing their approach with a dour expression.

â€œAh non non non. Aucune visite aujourdâ€™hui; le monastÃ¨re est fermÃ©,â€ said the Sister.

Granger, wiping sweat from her brow, feigned shock, and asked why it was closed?

The Sister explained that it was Midsummer; everyone was at the Basilica below. They were welcome to join in the celebrations there. There would be no services in the monastery chapel today.

Granger made a fair approximation of distress. Draco jumped in with an explanation to the nun that the pilgrimage to the monastery was of Spiritual Significance to both of them, and that they had honeymooned here especially to visit. Wouldnâ€™t she consider making an exception?

Granger sniffed that all she wanted to do was light a candle and make a prayer to the Magdalene, because she was a Repentant Sinner, and needed Her sacred blessing.

Draco made a great show of comforting his sobbing wife. (It felt interesting to cradle Granger and feel her breath on his chest through his shirt. It felt surprisinglyâ€¦ nice. He would go with nice.)

He patted her bum theatrically; she stiffened and her grip on his arm grew pinchy.

He discovered that the sunglasses perched on their heads were the deciding factor: the nun concluded that they were gormless idiots, and that a brief visit would do no harm, despite the Prioressâ€™ instructions.

â€œTransfixed, you say.â€

â€œPierced. Impaled, even. Look away before you cut me to pieces.â€

Draco looked away, amused. He did not tell her that her eyes had a contrary effect â€“ of drawing one in, of pulling towards. Sometimes, if he wasnâ€™t guarded, locking eyes with her felt like falling, like plummeting head-first.

But enough nonsense about eyes.

They took stock of the grotto. It was far bigger than Draco had imagined â€“ rather more of a cave â€“ containing an entire chapel. The walls were dotted with votive candles. Fissures in the cave had been blocked up by stained glass, which bathed the place in deep reds and blues.

There was no one about. In a dark corner of the cave, Granger Transfigured two statues into kneeling replicas of herself and Draco, and put a cluster of candles in front of them. Should the guard nun check in on them, their silhouettes would be hunched in quiet contemplation at the far end of the grotto.

Meanwhile, Draco was casting his detection spells, which told him there were about five nuns on the premises. â€œThere might be more. This rock makes it hard to say. So thatâ€™s five witches and untold amounts of wards.â€

â€œMuch better than the usual fifty witches, anyroad,â€ said Granger.

Satisfied with the arrangement of their stone Doppelgangers, Granger crept round the edge of the grotto and poked her head into the passage that led from the grotto to the crypt.

Granger said, â€œPardon, je cherche les toilettes.â€

The nun was getting too worked up to play Bumbling with. Draco cut her fact-finding mission short, Stunning her without fanfare.

â€œShit,â€ said Granger. â€œBut, unfortunately, necessary.â€

â€œHalf an hour, unless sheâ€™s got Troll blood.â€

â€œGood.â€ Granger Transfigured the nun into a pew and floated her against the wall. â€œLetâ€™s get on.â€

As planned, Draco took the lead, doing a little recce around every corner before he let Granger follow. She dropped two more runes as they went.

They met the first alarm wards at the downwards stairway into the crypt. Draco dismissed these without issue, but proceeded more slowly thereafter â€“ now they were getting closer to where things might become interesting.

â€œThe Sisters arenâ€™t very nice,â€ she said. Draco could hear the frown in her voice.

â€œWow,â€ said Granger at the sight of this absurd, yet impressive, display.

â€œI bloody well hope not â€“ sheâ€™s probably back down in the village.â€

The Portkey sucked them through the Anti-Apparition Ward in a prolonged, sickening drag. Draco wasnâ€™t sure what he was gripping harder: his wand, Grangerâ€™s waist, or the broom between his legs.

(photo: theworldgeography.com)

Grangerâ€™s head swivelled about too, observing the place, her curiosity overrunning her fear of flight. A wisp of smoke emanated from her ring â€“ the last of the imperfect Portus fizzling out of existence.Â

â€œThat wouldâ€™ve been rather too convenient,â€ said Granger. â€œBut Iâ€™ll take this over the centre of a volcano â€“ and we didnâ€™t get Splinched by poorly executed Arithmancy. Well done.â€

Draco flew lower, casting detection spells towards the graveyard of ships. There was no living thing within.

â€œIâ€™m going to take us down. We need to rest â€“ weâ€™re both bollocksed.â€

â€œAgreed.â€

They landed amongst the rusting hulls and found a spot in the shade of a smaller ship.

She groped about her pocket until she found her Muggle device, which she pulled out in triumph. However, the triumph was short-lived. Granger paced, held the mobile up high, held it low, pressed a few buttons â€“ but whatever it was meant to do, it wasnâ€™t doing.

â€œNo service,â€ sighed Granger. â€œWeâ€™re out of range of Muggle telecommunications. Iâ€™d have liked to know where we are.â€

â€œA great bloody desert like this? Somewhere in Africa would be my guess.â€

â€œThat was mine, too,â€ said Granger. â€œThereâ€™s a place called the Skeleton Coast in Namibia, famous for shipwrecks amongst the dunes. But that theory is buggered by the rather conspicuous absence of the sea. Perhaps the boats will give us a clue.â€

â€œWhereâ€™s the skull?â€ he asked, all of a sudden, as the last ten minutes had been free of its croaky remarks.

â€œIn my pocket,â€ said Granger. â€œWith a Muffliato around her temporal bones. Iâ€™m tired of her running commentary.â€

â€œGood shout. Dâ€™you have anything to eat in that pocket?â€

â€œObviously.â€

Bits of rusted-out boat were minimally Transfigured into a makeshift low table and stools. Draco noted that none of Grangerâ€™s usual flourishes â€“ or concern for accuracy â€“ were on display. Now she was passing her fingers through the sand, digging up more desiccated bits of sea-life. Her eyes were alight with inquisitiveness. With her hair strewn with crypt dust, and a purplish line of Mind Flayer residue across her cheek, and her torn-up walking kit, she looked rather like a wild-eyed archaeologist, seeking answers amongst the endless sands.

The effect was quite fetching. Had anyone told Draco, months ago, that he wouldâ€™ve found a banged-up, dirt-smudged witch digging about in sand fetching, he wouldâ€™ve scoffed. But there it was.Â 

â€œThatâ€™s a Scaphopoda,â€ said Granger in reference to the shell in Dracoâ€™s hands. â€œBut I donâ€™t know what species, so that wonâ€™t help us narrow down our location.â€

â€œSea urchin,â€ she said, holding up another whitish thing, but round.

â€œFascinating.â€

Draco popped himself onto his elbows. â€œIâ€™m sorry, did you just say flight?â€

â€œAs in, use the broom?â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œYou? Willingly? Want to use a broom?â€

Granger looked a combination of miffed and harassed. â€œYes, all right? It ended up being terribly useful. Donâ€™t be smug about it.â€

â€œToo late.â€

â€œI can see that.â€

Oh yes, he was smug. Granger, with her Firmly Established Opinions on Everything, had changed her mind about flying, of all things. Just as Granger was nodding her agreement, an odd sort of groan echoed across the dunes towards them.

â€œA cow? That sounded like Weasel on the loo.â€

A herd of â€“ of something â€“ came into view over the dunes.


(photo: saiga-conservation.com)

They looked like gazelles who had been half-Transfigured into tapirs.

â€œOh, Iâ€™ve read about those â€“ theyâ€™re Saiga antelope!â€ said Granger, leaping to her feet.

The animals paused at the sudden movement. They eyed Granger as though she was the half-Transfigured oddity, and not them. Then, with a strange loping gait, they carried on.

â€œQueer looking things,â€ said Draco. â€œMagical?â€

â€œMundane.â€ Granger was on her tiptoes, watching the herd pass. â€œExceedingly rare, though.â€

The lead animal groaned its peculiar moo and the herd disappeared behind a dune.

Granger returned to the blanket and kneeled at her sandy map. â€œThis will help situate us. Those antelope have a narrow range. Weâ€™re somewhere in Central Asia.â€ Granger bit at her lip. â€œPopulation centres will be few and far in between.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll fly south or west, then,â€ said Draco. â€œDefinitely not north.â€

â€œAgreed â€“ nothing but Russiaâ€™s steppes that way.â€

â€œIâ€™d give it another hour,â€ said Draco, eyeing the sun as it sank behind the dunes. â€œThen we can fly.â€

â€œAnd we were almost outwitted by nuns.â€

â€œThose nuns were savage old birds. My next warding will be inspired. Shall I cast Beelzebub's Barrier at your lab?â€

â€œCould do. A spot of demonic possession would inject some vim into Trinityâ€™s halls.â€

Soon, the sun was nothing but a golden memory reflected in the firmament. There was no birdsong in the desert; all was quiet, save for the plaintive whistling of the wind amongst the rusted-out hulls.

The wind quietened as the world darkened. The moon emerged and painted the dunes a silvery white. Then, in the black stillness above them, constellation after constellation of stars glimmered into being, and galaxies, and nebulas innumerable.

Draco had never seen a sky like this one, so alight with its own brilliance, shimmering with mighty mysteries of worlds far away.

Together, in awed silence, Draco and Granger observed the whirling radiance above. Their hearts felt strangely full, and their troubles small and distant, under such living skies.

~

Neither Draco nor Granger had planned for a nap, but magical exhaustion took its toll and knocked them both out for two hours.

On the bright side, Draco awoke feeling positively rejuvenated, and ready to take on a hundred nuns, should circumstances require it. Granger, as she uncurled herself, also looked reinvigorated.

A few lively wand-waves packed up or erased all traces of their passing.

And then it was time to fly.

There mustâ€™ve been eagerness on Dracoâ€™s face, because Granger held the broom from him, and said, â€œJust because I think itâ€™s a good idea doesnâ€™t mean Iâ€™m going to enjoy it. Making me scream in terror is not the object of this exercise.â€

â€œI would never,â€ said Draco, feigning offence as he set aside nefarious plans to do just that.

Granger, with a look of profound mistrust, passed him the broom. Draco mounted, and then angled his way towards her for her to hop on. She twisted her hands together, took a breath, muttered about bloody brooms, and, finally, clambered on.

â€œYou do better when you donâ€™t have time to think about it,â€ remarked Draco as Granger wedged herself between his legs. â€œLike in the crypt.â€

â€œImminent death does push slightly-less-imminent death out of my mind,â€ said Granger with a tight jaw.

Draco cast the usual assortment of wind-breakers and warming spells. â€œReady?â€

â€œNo,â€ came the strangled response. â€œJust go.â€

Draco did not wait to be told twice. He kicked off with a will, eager to get lost in these skies with their millions upon millions of stars.

The post-apocalyptic scene of the corroded fleet of boats grew smaller and smaller, until the hulls were mere specks below.

As they reached flying altitude, Draco revelled in the views. There was no sea here, but an ocean of silver dunes, undulating without end all around them. Above, long lanes of stars streaked â€“ gates to strange eternities. It was Awesome in the true sense of the word and filled Draco with profound wonder.

To his surprise, Granger had her eyes open. She breathed out a single, stupefied, â€œWow,â€ and then went silent.

Draco struck a south-eastern course. His broom hummed under him, wanting to be given its head as they flew. But this broom, the newest model Ã‰tincelle, was the quickest in Dracoâ€™s collection and he dared not go faster than he already was. Despite the wind-breaking charms, Grangerâ€™s ponytail had half unravelled and was having its way with his face. And, of course, the witch herself would kill him upon landing.

After a time, Granger asked, â€œWhyâ€™s the broom buzzing at us?â€ Her question was laced in unspoken fear of a malfunction.

â€œShe wants to go fast,â€ said Draco.

There was a pause. Then, timidly, Granger asked, â€œHow fast?â€

Draco gave a momentâ€™s thought to his answer, which took the form of a question: â€œHow fast does your car go?â€

â€œIâ€™ve broken two hundred kilometres per hour â€“ in Germany, mind.â€

(Draco did not understand why Germany was relevant to this statement.)

â€œWe can do two hundred on the broom,â€ said Draco. â€œIf youâ€™re game.â€

Draco knew Grangerâ€™s body language enough now to see that she was torn, even without a view of her face. â€œThis is a bloody big desert,â€ she said after some musing.

â€œIt is.â€

â€œWeâ€™ve been flying for twenty minutes and we havenâ€™t seen a single sign of human habitation.â€

â€œCorrect.â€

â€œWeâ€™d cover much more ground at speed.â€

â€œWe would.â€

Granger straightened up between Dracoâ€™s arms. â€œLetâ€™s do it. Cast a few more wind-breakers â€“ Iâ€™m going to do something with my hair.â€

Which was excellent, because between Granger and her cat, Draco had now ingested enough hair to last the week. He slowed them down to cast his spells as Granger coiled her ponytail into a plait and tucked it into her top.

Grangerâ€™s voice was tightened by nerves. â€œDonâ€™t accelerate too fast or I shall fall.â€

â€œYou wonâ€™t fall. Iâ€™m holding you.â€

â€œI know.â€

â€œItâ€™ll be just like weâ€™re in your car,â€ said Draco, edging the broom up to speed.

â€œMy car has seat belts and is solidly on the earth at all tiiiiiiimesâ€“â€

Grangerâ€™s statement gave way to a shriek as the broom surged ahead. Draco wondered whether he ought to slow down â€“ and then he realised that the shriek had turned into a delighted, adrenaline-filled laugh.

The speed had Granger half enjoying herself, half frightened out of coherent thought.

â€œNow weâ€™re getting somewhere,â€ said Draco as the dunes turned to a silvery blur below them.

â€œOh my godddâ€“â€

â€œYou are keeping an eye out for lights, arenâ€™t you?â€

â€œUghfrlp.â€

â€œGood.â€

They streaked across the desert, meteoric. Draco wished for a shooting star, so that they might race it. Since Granger was doing so well, he gave the broom her head, and she spiritedly jetted forth even faster, and now the dunes were a silver radiance below, and the stars were a dazzling whirl.

He held Granger tightly, partially to keep her safe, partially because he wanted to, because the feel of it was enjoyable â€“ the holding of this slightly mad, brilliant witch, who passed her weekends skylarking about crypts, and who provoked him at every turn.

She was warm between his arms, and she smelled like travel dust and adventure and exhilaration.

The whole thing was mad â€“ the holding of Granger as though he wanted to, the flying over these unsettled wilds, the having no actual clue where on Earth they were, the illegal and unfinished Portus, the talking skull, the whole of it. Absolutely mental.

He had loved every minute.

â€œThere!â€ said Granger, suddenly.

She made the mistake of holding out her arm to point. At this speed, it was whipped backwards and smacked Draco in the temple.

â€œSorry!â€ blurted Granger. â€œBut â€“ look!â€

To the south of them glowed the yellow glow of Muggle lights. At first they dotted the sands, here and there, and then they began to form long, parallel lanes. Roads.

â€œA city!â€ said Granger.

Draco flew them lower and slower. As they slowed, Granger cast Disillusionments on the two of them, lest a Muggle be stargazing on a night like this.

They skimmed the rooftops now, looking for more clues on their location. Signs across shopfronts were in Cyrillic and, oddly, Arabic, with what looked like Korean Hangul thrown in to confuse any lost witches and wizards as much as possible.

Granger asked Draco to slow down further so that she could consult her mobile, now that they had reached civilisation.

â€œTashkent,â€ she said.

â€œBless you,â€ said Draco.

â€œNo, itâ€™s where we are. Weâ€™re in Uzbekistan.â€

â€œMy word,â€ said Draco. â€œThatâ€™s a step off the beaten path.â€

â€œThis is excellent. There's a British embassy here. Thereâ€™ll be a Magical consulate tucked in there with them. Weâ€™ll be able to Floo home.â€

With that, Granger's mobile began peppering directions out to Draco, which led them to the roof of the British embassy, which was closed for the night. Draco broke them in and sniffed out the Consulâ€™s chambers (his was the only trace of magic in the entire building), and they startled the poor wizard awake.

Draco intimidated the Consul into lighting the international Floo flue, despite their lack of any kind of documentation, and Granger Obliviated him, and Draco cast a Sleeping Charm on him, and then they were whisked back to London by blue flames.

Draco reflected that he and Granger made a rather decent team.

They were spat out on British soil twenty minutes later, after the longest and most dizzying Floo journey that either of them had ever experienced. Draco rolled out of it; Granger plopped down bonelessly.

Then, on the cold floor of the London warehouse that served as the Arrivals platform, Granger laid herself down and did not move.

Draco, who generally fared better than her in all things spinny, had a look about. His knee was stinging at him, unhappy with the way heâ€™d landed on the concrete.

â€œTheyâ€™ve put in a line of domestic Floo hearths,â€ he said, returning to Grangerâ€™s limp corpse. â€œWe can each Floo straight home.â€

â€œShanâ€™t,â€ said Granger.

Draco came to stand next to her and contemplated her greenish mien. â€œYou look ready to be sick.â€

â€œI feel it,â€ said Granger.

â€œItâ€™s one more little spin in the Floo.â€

â€œGo away and leave me to die,â€ came Grangerâ€™s feeble voice.

Draco, who fancied a hot shower and a nap, was moderately tempted, but leaving his Principal queasy and utterly prone on the floor was, unfortunately, contrary to protocol. â€œHavenâ€™t you some potion to take for the nausea?â€

â€œIf I so much as smell a potion, I shall decorate this floor with aubergine andâ€“â€

â€œShh,â€ said Draco.

Footsteps were ringing across the warehouse.

Draco knelt beside Granger. â€œThereâ€™s an agent coming and we havenâ€™t got an explanation for how we just got spat out of Tashkent with no papers, nor a stamp from the Consul. We have to go.â€

â€œShit,â€ said Granger, raising her head weakly off the floor. â€œTheyâ€™ll find my Extension charms, if they search us.â€

â€œAnd weâ€™ve still got the bloody skull. Thatâ€™s a stolen Artefact â€“ not to mention precious enough to spark an international incident.â€

â€œI heard an arrival, I tell you,â€ came a manâ€™s voice.

â€œImpossible,â€ came another. â€œThereâ€™s nothing scheduled till Istanbul at half-past.â€

Granger held out her arm and whispered, â€œDisapparate us.â€

â€œWhere?â€

â€œBloody anywhere!â€

Draco grasped her arm and Disapparated as quietly as he could.

~


by RunningQuill_art

The Seneca


by the wildly talented ivmaruva
~

The bath and the nap which had been at the forefront of Dracoâ€™s mind inspired his choice of destination. He and Granger materialised in the foyer of the Seneca, Londonâ€™s choicest wizarding hotel.

Draco hoisted Granger up to her feet. The employees at the Seneca were the epitome of discretion, including the witch who stepped out from behind the front desk, took no notice of their filthy clothing, and graciously asked if they were looking for a room, or dining at the hotel?

The mention of dining made Granger go dangerously green.

Draco propped her onto a bench and made arrangements for a room with the front desk witch. The woman, sensing that they wanted a room more than chit-chat about the hotelâ€™s amenities, summoned an ornate key, whisked them to the lifts, and enquired if they had any luggage? (No, nothing, and certainly no illegal skulls, thank you.)

And so Draco reached the end of this bizarre day, in one of the Senecaâ€™s famous suites, overlooking the Kensington Palace gardens, with a droopy Granger thrown decoratively across a chaise longue.

On the low table next to her, a carafe of water magically materialised, as well as a bucket. Thoughtful sort, that front desk witch.

Deciding that Granger had been sufficiently provided for, Draco went off to shower. That was a delightful experience, far more enjoyable than the small closet provided by the Hotel Plaisance. The Dinner / Draco Malfoy Almost Causes The Next Murder Sensation

Chapter Notes

In which Draco continues to be a terribly unreliable narrator. Featuring more of my favourite fanfic moments.

Please mind the slow burn tag! This is the Dramione story I wanted to read and UST is my kink (emphasis on the U). Expect false starts, hesitation, all manner of idiocy, and an eventual denouement in the endgame. This fic is not for short- or medium-term gratification seekers but rather for masochists who like to suffer.

If that is you, then please read on and let us suffer together.


'The Seneca' by the wonderful RunningQuill_art

~

To Dracoâ€™s devious pleasure, McLaggen took him up on the invitation to pop by the pitch a few weeks later.

An unfortunate sequence of events occurred, which had positively, absolutely nothing to do with Draco â€“ wet conditions, terribly aggressive Bludgers, temperamental brooms â€“ that resulted in McLaggen taking a tumble off his broom from 30 metres up.

â€œI say,â€ said Davies, watching McLaggen being carted off the pitch by mediwitches. â€œThat Bludger had it in for the bloke.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t even hit it that hard,â€ said Zabini.

â€œPoor old egg,â€ said Draco. â€œFirst time back on the broom in a while, as I understand it.â€

â€œPerhaps Bludgers can smell fear,â€ suggested Zabini.

â€œHope it doesnâ€™t put him off the sport,â€ said Davies. â€œWe need a decent Keeper. Bickfordâ€™s moving to Spain.â€

The general mood was a little subdued after the accident. The players decided to call it quits for the night, said their goodbyes, and Disapparated off to shower.

All except for Draco, who found, to the contrary, that the accident had had a stimulating effect on his morale. He left the pitch feeling quite invigorated.

~

Granger had a grievance to air. This development was heralded by her silvery otter, which found Draco the next evening. The timing was hideous; Draco was on a sensitive stakeout in Fowlmere, about to apprehend the notorious Thomas Talfryn.

â€œYou! You promised you wouldnâ€™t do anything!â€ shrieked Grangerâ€™s otter into Dracoâ€™s face. â€œYou are the worst!â€

The shrill sound of Grangerâ€™s voice echoed through the alley where Draco had been hidden.

â€œFucking fuck!â€ hissed Draco.

The otter, having conveyed its message, disappeared.

With a snarl, Draco pulled out Grangerâ€™s schedule. She was home. Which was perfect, because he was going to murder her.

He Apparated to her cottage in an exceedingly foul mood. He swept her wards aside and stormed up the path to her front door, which he proceeded to hammer.

â€œYouâ€™re a bloody idiot,â€ said Draco, by way of greeting.

â€œMe?â€ said Granger. She was wild about the eyes. â€œMe?! Youâ€™re the idiot! You werenâ€™t to touch McLaggen!â€

â€œI canâ€™t stand you!â€

Then they stood, tempers ablaze, lips parted, breaths coming quickly, and waited for the other to spit out a retort, so they might continue tearing off each otherâ€™s heads. Somehow, in the process of their screaming match and finger jabbing, they had come to stand close together. Granger was on the doorstop, so that, for once, her height almost matched Draco's. He felt her breath flutter against his chin.

Her anger made her glow; her gaze was afire with the heat of her conviction; her cheeks were flushed. She wanted to throttle him as much as he wanted to throttle her. And there was a moment of madness, where the fulcrum between rage and passion wavered and tilted, and he couldâ€™ve throttled her, or he couldâ€™ve crushed his mouth against hers, hard, to do something with the intensity of the feeling; to shut her up; to prove a point.

The mad possibility was contagious â€“ her eyes flitted to his mouth. Then she blinked and, like a thing awakening from a trance, looked distantly shocked.

Realising that he was still gripping at her hand, Draco released it, and took a large step back. Granger, too, took a large step away, and looked like sheâ€™d rather toddle back to the crypt and throw herself onto the Crucio carpet than be there. Her blush carried up from her cheeks to across the bridge of her nose.

Draco, feeling utterly thrown off-kilter by the Moment, cleared his throat, cast about for a thing to say (nothing was forthcoming), and then said heâ€™d best be off, as it was getting dark.

Granger looked anywhere but at him and said, â€œRight.â€

Mutually satisfied with this mature, robust conclusion to their quarrel, they stepped apart even further, and Granger made as though to shut the door.

There was a long, sustained meow from somewhere in the garden. In the shadows, an orangey blotch advanced towards them.

The cat paused at Dracoâ€™s feet, and then, as though it was bestowing a great gift upon him, it wound itself around his boots and coated his trousers in orange.

Draco was almost as wrong-footed by this as by the Moment with Granger. He hardly knew what to do with himself. However, when he bent down to stroke the cat, it hissed at him, and fled back into the dark garden.

â€œItâ€™s on his terms, and his terms only,â€ said Granger.

â€œPernickety creature.â€

â€œHe is.â€

â€œYes. Did McLaggen really end up with you last night?â€

â€œYes.â€

They muttered something that may have been, to the listener with impossibly acute ears, an apology, in a language principally consisting of mutters and throat-clearing. Their seething fury gave way now to a certain degree of abashedness, which Draco was more adept at hiding than Granger.

â€œAll. And a concussion, to boot.â€

The article described the theft of a relic from a monastery that Draco had certainly never heard of in his life. The burglars were described as uniquely powerful individuals with a penchant for arson, who had defeated nigh-impenetrable security measures, unbroken since 1008.

Our readers will be as flabbergasted as the investigators when they learn that the prized relic â€“ the skull of a saint â€“ was returned to the monastery anonymously a few days after the break-in. â€œI got my alliterative headline,â€ said Draco.

â€œYou did.â€ Granger twisted her hands together. â€œI got what I absolutely didnâ€™t want, which was publicity.â€

He was simply observing the distinction.

The grounds were illuminated at night by enchanted candles and lanterns at the foot of every tree, and strung along all of the footpaths. It was, however, terribly romantic. Henriette was laying it on rather thick, given that Draco had specified a colleague. He had had countless dinners and drinks with colleagues and collaborators al fresco over the summer, and Henriette had never once seen fit to decorate with roses. Red roses.

They ate. Granger was dainty about it, as she tended to be, and easily distracted by long looks out past the terrace and onto the candle-lit grounds. Now she had her chin propped onto the back of her hand, and was gazing at the evanescent beauty of a row of poplars, whose young leaves shivered in the breeze like silvery medallions.

Draco half wanted to interrupt her and bring her back to the important things (himself), but it was also rather nice to sit in companionable silence and sip their drinks. Dinners at the Manor were normally agenda-driven affairs, with either the guest or Draco having something to gain or something to lose. This one was unique for its lack of any of those pressures; Draco had no manoeuvering to do and knew he wasnâ€™t being manipulated against. They were merely eating together as he made small reparations for a burnt fish pie. Granger had no designs on his fortune or his person.

â€œI donâ€™t know. I havenâ€™t seen my parents in a few years.â€

â€œOh.â€

However, Granger continued. â€œI Obliviated both of them during the war. Sent them to Australia to keep them safe. Ah, yes, just what Draco had been hoping for. Some light-hearted reminiscing about wartime tragedies.

â€œIt did. At a cost.â€ Granger finished her wine. â€œAnyway â€“ itâ€™s too beautiful an evening to be maudlin. Letâ€™s talk of other things.â€

Draco finished his cognac so that her empty glass didnâ€™t feel lonely. He was sensitive that way.

Granger sank into the report, leaving her risotto to grow cold on her plate. She occasionally remembered Dracoâ€™s presence, which was signaled by an â€œOh!â€ and then a sharing of some fascinating snippet or other.

Henriette Apparated with the next course and gave Granger a reproving look when she took stock of the situation.

â€œMademoiselle! Jâ€™ose vous rappeler que vous Ãªtes Ã  table.â€

â€œTurbot poÃªlÃ©, artichauts poivrade et citron confit.â€ Henriette deposited Grangerâ€™s fish and artichokes with particular firmness, with intimations that if she did not consume it all, there would be Words to be had.

â€œWhat Proposal?â€ asked Granger in a kind of growl, as of a cat caught by the scruff of its neck.

Grangerâ€™s smile was quite fixed.

â€œYou would try the patience of a saint,â€ said Granger through a clenched jaw. â€œReturn my foot before I turn you into that cockroach.â€

She noticed. There was a flush of pink across her cheekbones. Possibly the wine. Possibly other things.

â€œIâ€™ve only spoken to one saint, and she quite liked me,â€ said Draco, running his hand through his hair.

â€œI saw a problem that was in my capacity to fix,â€ said Draco. â€œItâ€™s a life philosophy I learned from a rather clever witch.â€

â€œThat is a private matter and it would be best for you to forget it.â€

They finished their desserts.

Grangerâ€™s touch on his arm was light, at first, but after a few steps, her grip tightened. â€œShit. Is the ground a bit wobbly, or am I completely battered?â€

â€œWe are both steeped to the tonsils in wine,â€ said Draco.

â€œTupeyâ€™s attentions were â€“ unrelenting.â€

It was a miracle neither of them had said something tipsy and stupid yet â€“ but the night was young, and the path to the gardens beckoned, and the possibilities for stupidities glimmered like the candles that lined the way.

They wandered through a double row of lilacs heavy with bloom. On their right stood the greenhouse, its warm glow dappled by the riot of mauve blossoms. The breeze made the blossoms quiver in a butterfly-tremble; the light shimmered across the path.

In the mingling shadows, Granger held up her hand so that it was silhouetted against the light of the greenhouse.

It was steady.

It was her left hand that she held up. Her arm was bare and against the skin of her inner arm lay that blur.

Granger turned, intending to continue down the path, but Draco interrupted by committing the first of the eveningâ€™s stupidities. Later, he would blame the wine.

He took her wrist â€“ gently, but she nonetheless flinched â€“ and pulled it toward him.

Granger was shocked. â€œWhat are youâ€“?!â€

â€œI didnâ€™t realise you still had this,â€ said Draco.

He turned her wrist so that the blur of the glamour caught the vacillating light.

â€œWell â€“ I do.â€ Her voice was uncertain. She stared at him with a wide-eyed wariness â€“ a wild thing about to pull away and run. She smelled like the sweetness of the Sauternes.

Two heavy words that Draco had been carrying since Provence came out with difficulty. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

â€œIt was your mad aunt, not you.â€

â€œI did nothing to stop her.â€

To this, Granger gave no answer.

â€œI suppose that if there was a way to heal it away, you wouldâ€™ve found it,â€ said Draco.

â€œI wouldâ€™ve. I tried a great many things, butâ€¦â€

â€œSome things donâ€™t heal.â€

â€œNo. They donâ€™t.â€ Granger was quiet for a moment. Then she waved the glamour away to reveal the word. â€œUgly thing.â€

The old injury stood clear on her skin, as raw as the day it had been carved. It glistened still. Dracoâ€™s mouth was cottony and dry. For a moment she was 17, lying as though dead on the drawing room floor, mere metres from where they stood. Then she was Granger again, a burning intelligence, a world-changer, but still, for all that, marked. Dracoâ€™s hold on her wrist grew a little tighter â€“ shame and sorrow.

â€œDoes it still hurt?â€ asked Draco, because it looked too raw not to.

â€œSometimes. Iâ€™m used to it, now. Or I just forget.â€

Draco had never had any intention to show her his own inner arm shame â€“ all the more shameful because it had been willingly acquired.

And yet, he found himself unbuttoning his cuffs and rolling up his sleeve.

What was left on his arm was a distorted, half-faded Mark. It was a grotesque mix of black flesh and raised scar tissue, now, from failed attempts to remove it.

â€œOh,â€ gasped Granger.

â€œMineâ€™s uglier. In every way, Granger. I wanted it.â€

The gasp had been shock more than horror. She was observing the twisted flesh with a Healerâ€™s eye, one that had seen worse things.

Granger was silent for a long time. At length, she said, â€œBut you donâ€™t want it any more.â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œThatâ€™s what matters.â€Â 

â€œIt doesnâ€™t erase the past,â€ said Draco. The defiled arm he held between them was an eloquent attestation of that.

â€œNo. But the choices youâ€™ve made since define you more than those you made then.â€

â€œDo they?â€

â€œYou were sixteen years old. You were â€“ we were all â€“ child soldiers flung into a war, trying to do what we were taught was right. Trying to protect our loved ones.â€

â€œMust you be so terribly forgiving?â€

â€œItâ€™s been fifteen years,â€ said Granger. She lowered her own arm. She looked weary. â€œI can assure you that Iâ€™ve ruminated on the matter at length. Iâ€™ve forgiven those who deserve it.â€

â€œIt rather interferes with my wallowing in self-reproach.â€

â€œWallowing isnâ€™t productive.â€

Now it was Grangerâ€™s turn to take his wrist. She pulled it to a triangle of light amongst the shadows and leaned in to observe the Mark more closely. Draco wanted to pull away â€“ but she had been brave enough to let him look at hers, so he mustnâ€™t be a coward now.

Her finger brushed over scarred ridges and half-melted flesh that had never felt the touch of another's hand.

She looked heartsick. â€œYou tried to curse it off?â€

â€œYes,â€ said Draco. Amongst other things. â€œYears ago, now.â€

His arm twitched under her scrutiny. He wanted to put the Mark away again: it was so ugly, so misshapen, so full of hideous memories and shame.

â€œI donâ€™t think thereâ€™s much I could do with this one, either,â€ said Granger. â€œIn terms of Healing, I mean.â€ The thought seemed to make her sad.

â€œMine is a memento of some terrible decisions. Itâ€™s well deserved. Yours â€“ yours is a wretched tragedy.â€

â€œIt is,â€ said Granger. Then she added, â€œWell, theyâ€™re both tragedies in different ways.â€

More righteous forgiveness. It made Draco want to flee.

They stood in silence. And now she knew some of his griefs and he knew some of hers. There was an intimacy to it. To being seen. It was unfamiliar, tender to the touch, unnerving.

They stood in silence and yet it wasnâ€™t silence, it was thick and dense and whirling. It weighed upon their eardrums and chests like a pressure.


by RunningQuill_art

â€œI should like a pithy conclusion, or words of wisdom,â€ said Draco, to cut through it.

â€œYes, please,â€ said Granger. She seemed relieved.

â€œI meant from you.â€

Granger clasped her hands before her and looked up to the stars, as though she might find the pithiness there. â€œThe Ennervated cadaver of a man who gave us these scars is quite dead.â€

â€œAnd weâ€™re alive.â€

â€œI think thatâ€™s good enough.â€

Draco rolled his sleeve back down and did up his cufflinks. Granger glamoured her scar back to the discreet blur.

â€œItâ€™s too beautiful an evening to be maudlin,â€ said Draco.

â€œI do not sound that swotty,â€ said Granger.

â€œYou do. Shall we have a look at the roses? Have your feminine ecstasies at the ready.â€

They wandered down the path that curved through the candlelight until they reached the rose garden. At their feet, Midnight Violets peeped, here and there, lured out by the crescent moon.

Their footsteps were slow and drunk and deliciously aimless. It was perfect; Draco knew too little of roses to give a real tour and Granger was content to meander from one to the next without plan nor purpose, touching at their loosely cupped petals. Pretty names fell from her lips as she recognised a few: Annabelle, the Wildfire, the Apolline, the Duchess, Ivory Kiss, Claire, Crimson Romance.

Fairy lights twinkled amongst the rose bushes. Petals drifted onto the path. A nightingale sang and fountains gurgled. Granger, with a kind of dreamy-eyed tipsiness, said it was like being in an enchanted glade.

Draco wanted to have a go at her for being sentimental, but he found himself also in a soft, mellow kind of mood. The kind of mood in which he might tell a witch that yes, the roses were sweet, but she was the sweetest thing in the garden, just to see her blush.

He did not, because he was made of stronger stuff.

Fragrances, delicate and elusive, teased at their noses. Granger tried to name the scents and held up the roses to Draco, so that he could try, and he stood next to her, closer than necessary, and they made idle guesses together â€“ apple, vanilla, clove, myrrh, honey â€“ amongst the damask.

His wine-drenched mind collected impressions. Delectable nearness. Being close enough to feel her giving off warmth. The rose she held to his face, so close that his lips brushed its petals. The moonlight on her skin. The escaped curls of hair at her nape. The corner of her mouth. The biting of her lip. Eyelashes against a cheek.

They moved to the next rose. This one, Granger was convinced smelled of apricots. Draco came to stand behind her and leaned over her shoulder. To him, it was tangerine. Granger smelled it again, and said no, apricots, most certainly. And Draco leaned in closer and said no â€“ tangerine, donâ€™t be silly. Granger theorised that they mightâ€™ve found an Amortentia rose; that would explain the discrepancy. Draco said he would be sure to record this discovery.

They moved on to the next one, a splendid white rose. Granger cupped its heavy head and drew it out. Draco came behind her again and they both smelled it at the same time, and her cheek brushed his chin.

He caught himself, just in time, as he was about to put a hand on her waist.

That way lay madness.

The curve of her skirts brushed against the front of his trousers. Her hair tickled at the side of his face.

Granger said it was coconut and dared him to disagree. Draco disagreed as a matter of course â€“ it was kiwi.

Kiwi?! repeated Granger. Kiwi, said Draco. Granger said that she would have him sent to an otolaryngologist, if he didnâ€™t stop this nonsense. Draco said the only nonsense here was the word otolaryngologist.

The sweet paralysis was coming over him again, of not wanting to move, of lightness in his veins, of limbs feeling weightless and eyelids feeling heavy. He wanted to put his chin where her neck met her shoulder and just stand there. He wanted to say things in her ear and feel her shiver against him. He wanted to linger here, being stupid about kiwi, for an age or two. He wanted to float.

It was the wine, certainly. And the artichokes.

They moved to the next roses, small wild things that grew in bunches and smelled like vetiver. Granger asked if she might pick one. Draco did so for her; it seemed ungentlemanly not to. And he gave it to her, his arm wrapped around her from behind, and their fingertips touched, and that was as close as they could get â€“ touching fingertips over a rose.

She looked over her shoulder at him to say thank you, and their eyes met, and hers were dark and curious and his were light and keen, and it was universes colliding. It was all of those contrapositions of Light and Dark and Muggle-born and Pure-blood and Order and Death Eater and terrible incompatibility after terrible incompatibility. The violent polarities that made them who they were.

They fell into each other a bit, in that moment of collision, a bit drunk, a bit soul-tangled.

She slid the rose into her hair and turned away.

They came to the end of the rose garden, where the hedges grew thickest and stupidities might be said most freely. Where terrible incompatibilities stopped meaning so much, because, here amongst green boughs and the rustling breeze, they were just a man and a woman, meandering through a garden, being idiots about roses.

They found a seat on a stone bench near a fountain adorned with chubby Cupids. Granger curled her legs under herself. The rose in her hair was askew, so Draco reached over to fix it, expecting to do so suavely but finding instead that he was transfixed by a feeling of exquisite nervousness, the likes of which he hadnâ€™t felt since he was a teenager. Granger breathed out a thank you. Her cheeks were pink.

They talked of things trivial and not, of roses and cupboards and scars and war and artichokes and fish pie. They looked up at the smouldering stars, and the nightbirds warbled their unearthly cadences, and roses dropped their petals in beautiful melancholy. An hour drifted by, and then two, and then three â€“ though it felt like theyâ€™d only just sat down beside each other on this damp bench amongst the roses to witter away the evening.

The memory of that night would remain with Draco for a long time afterwards, moon-kissed and sweet. The light in her eyes, the taste of wine, the glitter of starshine in the fountain, the slow seduction of the roses.

Il faut se laisser ensorceler.

Chapter 18

I have something for you, came a Jot from Granger a week later. I think you lot would call it a lead. On the Nundu-baiter.

Well???, answered Draco.

Off to teach. Can you meet at 6? said Granger.

Where?

The cafÃ© at Trinity, said Granger. I've got another meeting there just before. If I run late, donâ€™t barge in shouting about brooms. Itâ€™s with a Muggle.

Draco was grateful for the instructions, as he typically arrived early and charged into cafÃ©s, shouting about brooms. He tossed the Jotter aside to check Grangerâ€™s schedule. The Muggle in question was Gunnar Larsen, the head of Skjern Pharmaceutics.

At 5.55 p.m. a Disillusioned Draco strode to the Muggle cafÃ© at Trinity College, curious about Grangerâ€™s ostensible lead on Talfryn.

He saw her through the cafÃ© window, still deep in talk with a man. Draco had formed a comfortable mental image of this Larsen fellow: a smallish and thin scientist type, probably balding and bespectacled.

Instead, sitting across the table from Granger, was a six-foot-something, eighteen stone hulk of a man. His hair was reddish-blonde, as was his rather impressive beard, and his eyes were a penetrating blue.

He was a Viking in a three-piece suit. There was probably more curly chest hair peeking over the top of his collar than Draco had grown since puberty.

Draco decided that he didnâ€™t like him.

Still Disillusioned, he slid into the cafÃ© after an exiting customer and leaned against a wall to eavesdrop. Granger and the Viking were chatting mostly in jargon (his, slightly accented). Granger was explaining, in that passionate way of hers, something about adaptive immune systems and microenvironments. Larsen responded something about checkpoint inhibitor therapy, to which Granger replied with vast enthusiasm.

The Vikingâ€™s eyes were riveted on Granger in a way that Draco didnâ€™t like. There was something predatory about it â€“ something hungry. And Granger was gesticulating away and too busy being excited about nanobiologics to notice. Suspicions began to percolate: was this meaty Muggle going to try to steal her ideas? Make money off her? Literally eat her?

There was only one way to find out.

Dracoâ€™s dive into the manâ€™s mind was over as soon as it began. He found himself butting against extremely sophisticated mental barriers, the likes of which only a highly trained Occlumens would have in place.

So Granger was wrong. The man wasnâ€™t a Muggle.

The Viking, feeling the attempted intrusion, turned to where Draco was Disillusioned. His piercing eyes roved across crowded tables, trying to pick out his attacker.

Granger asked him, â€œIs everything all right?â€

Larsen turned back to Granger. â€œYes â€“ my apologies, Professor. I thought Iâ€™d heard something.â€

They continued the conversation, though Larsenâ€™s responses were reduced to distracted monosyllables.

Draco's first reaction â€“ to supplex the man through a table and ask him what he was playing at â€“ was made difficult by the crowds. (To say nothing of the fact that Draco wasnâ€™t actually certain that he could throw him.)

His second thought was to Stun Larsen and rip through his mind to discover what his designs were, but again, the crowds, and besides, the man was an Occlumens. Heâ€™d need to soften him up first, then render his brain into purÃ©e.

Granger checked the time and rushed the meeting to its end. Larsen shook her hand (her entire arm, really) and weaved through the tables. Draco saw him systematically observe every patron in the cafÃ© as he walked to the door. Was this just to remember faces, or was he a Legilimens, too?

Draco followed Larsen into the street with vague thoughts of a Stunner to the back and a Side-Along to an Auror holding cell for a friendly chat. However, as soon as Larsen found a doorway out of view of the Muggle public, he Disapparated.

Draco did not like that at all.

He was a mixture of perplexed and irritable as he rejoined Granger at the cafÃ©, Disillusion removed. For her part, Granger hadnâ€™t any idea of what had just transpired, and she met his approach with a cheerful wave. She had bought him a coffee and one of those toffee panna cottas, but it was simply Not The Time.

â€œLetâ€™s go to your lab,â€ said Draco in lieu of a greeting. â€œWe need to talk in private.â€

Grangerâ€™s cheerfulness faded. â€œOh â€“ but Iâ€“â€

â€œIn private,â€ repeated Draco.

Granger snatched up the coffee and panna cotta as Draco swept her out of the cafÃ©.

When they arrived at Grangerâ€™s office, she sat at her desk and Draco began to storm from one end of the small room to the other.

â€œAre you going to tell me whatâ€™s wrong?â€ she asked.

Draco paused in his pacing, his Auror robes whipping dramatically about his boots as he did. â€œLarsen. Heâ€™s not a Muggle.â€

Grangerâ€™s eyebrows rose to her hairline. â€œ...What?â€

Grangerâ€™s lead ended up being rather a solid one. How could it be anything else? It was Granger.
